number of helpful: 1,744 of 1,767 people (99%) found this review helpful9 people found this review funny
content:
7, 2014
												Okay, where to start. I figured that there was no need for me to review this game as it is so successful, but, as always, All the Steam reviews on the front of the store page are one to two sentenced jokes instead of something actually helpful. Please thumbs-up this, if you like this review, for visibility.The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion is the sequel to the critically acclaimed The Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind. Knowledge of prior storylines are not needed to enjoy Oblivion, though a working understanding of TES world lore will always enhance your experience in any of The Elder Scrolls games. A good idea is to just read some of the in-game books, from time to time, as you play the game. Some of the fictional books are amazing little detours from the game world. Oblivion and Morrowind are less fantasy experience and more-so a virtual world that you live in. With mods, this experience feels more real to me than some of the Dungeons and Dragons campaigns I've played. It's incredibly easy to get immersed into this work.Oblivion's main story leaves some to be desired. You are a prisoner who meets the Emperor (voiced by Patrick Stewart) and his guards as he flees a rumored assassination attempt through hidden tunnels in the Imperial City prison. Suffice it to say, that its' not really a spoiler that you witness the Emperor's assassination. Before the Emperor's death, he tells you that you are fated by the gods to save the Empire and "close shut the jaws of Oblivion". Long story short, you flee the tunnels and are sent to track down the Emperor's last remaining illegitimate heir (voiced by Sean Bean) as well as pretty much single-handedly repel the invasion of Daedra from Mehrunes Dagon’s hellish plane of Oblivion.However, in classic Elder Scrolls fashion, the main quest isn’t even the largest part of the game. The entire Imperial province of Cyrodiil is open to you for exploration. There are many guilds to join, whether or not you want to be a mercenary, a mage, a thief, an assassin, or a holy crusader. There is an abundance of miscellaneous side and freeform quests for you to do. I recommend the purchase of a strategy guide, not so that you’ll have a walkthrough, but because you’ll need some way to keep track of where everything is! There are many quests and areas that you will miss if you don’t scour the world for them. You can easily spend around 350 hours if you finish all of the main, side, and faction quests as well as the DLC. Many people just wander across the world, not even touching the main story.The mechanics have long been applauded as an improvement over Morrowind, level scaling aside. Morrowind offers a better story and atmosphere, while Oblivion offers a more modern experience. The graphics are a bit dated by today’s standards, but I still sometimes catch myself stunned by the beauty of Cyrodiil. Skills are a lot more streamlined than Morrowind, which I consider a negative trait, although it does make the game friendlier to newcomers. Combat is not as bad as so many people claim. To me, it really feels like I’m actually swinging the sword. The magic system is a lot simpler than Morrowind’s but a lot easier to use. It is not as good as Skyrim’s magic system, but still useful.The DLC The Knights of the Nine and The Shivering Isles far trump Oblivion’s main quest. Knights of the Nine puts on a holy crusade to fight against Umariil the Unfeathered, an ancient Ayleid elf who has come to try to enslave men once more. The Shivering Isles sends you to the frankly breathtaking realm of Sheogorath, the Daedric  “Mad God”. Most of the dialogue in The Shivering Isles will have you chuckling to yourself and smiling. And the atmosphere of the realm brings nostalgia from Morrowind to mind.Now, I am going to discuss mods. Oblivion’s modding scene is unparalleled by Morrowind or Skyrim. There are enormous overhaul mods, plenty of lore friendly stories, and enthralling and immersive stories and factions. You can even reach an added five or six hundred more hours if you play through some quality mods. Morroblivion, brings the entire landmass of the previous game, Morrowind, as well as all of it’s quests, items, NPCs, creatures, etc. You can then travel between the two provinces with your same character. Other mods add some of the other provinces from Tamriel. And a few mods have been so well rated that they’ve become known as unofficial expansion packs.Oblivion is an astounding RPG that will draw you in and stick with you for a long, long time. The replayability of Oblivion is excellent. The game was released eight years ago and I am still playing it to this day. You will not regret buying this game. Get the Deluxe pack for $25 that comes with all the DLC, themed player lairs, and, yes, even horse armor. It is well worth the price and you will get your money’s worth over and over again.

content:
1, 2014
												I made a Khajit and he could punch stuff. I leveled up punching stuff, running places, and jumping to their maximum level but when I went to the arena I had trouble. I easily defeated my opponents by punching them until they could no longer stand up, then continuing to punch them as they lay bloody on the arena's dirt floor. I heard the crowd roaring as my fists crashed into the Grey Orc's skull; I felt their love wash over me like a crimson silk gown. Slowly, after the vampire scum gave out his last breath, I walked out of the arena. Not in triumph, not in victory, but in remorse. I had just punched my way through a dozen or more skulls, and for what? In my agony I gloomily set up at the The Bloated Float Inn, located in the Imperial City's Waterfront District. I woke up to the sounds of rustling, was confronted by a clearly beligerant bandit. The man had no idea I was the Arena Champion, he had not heard how I crushed the skulls of countless enemies with my punching, how I jumped clear over them with little effort, or even how I ran circles around the arena dodging every single attack thrown at me before pummeling my opponents into submission. The very idea of the man standing before me, a person unknowing of my athletic prowess, set me in to an uncontrollable rage. I don't recall what happened over then next ten minutes, but my memory picks back up again standing inside of the Inn owner's cabin covered head to toe in blood. I navigated back through the ship, which now more resembled a slaughter house, to try to find someone who could tell me what happened. Located in the messhall I found a naked shivering woman named Selene. I will never forget the look on her face when I approached her, a visage of fear so vivid the viewer can feel it. It was then I realized what event must had befallen the denizens of The Bloated Float Inn. The ingorance of that would-be bandit set me into a blood fueled rage. I slaughtered every person aboard the ship for his sin, that is, every person save for this trembling woman. I decided then and there to never use my fists again, I set off from the boat, WHICH HADN'T LEFT THE HARBOR, to embark on a pilgrimage. One that would encapsulate all nine divine shrines and eventually lead an unwilling khajit boxer to defeat the ancient Aylied king Umaril using only Talk good skill, run fast skill, and jump high skill. After defeating such an awesome foe I came to the conclusion that one need not fight with his fists to attain his goals. Through the use of hecka convincing words, speedy feet, and super strong legs, anyone can stamp out evil without ever lifting a finger.Oblivion taught me the greatest lesson of all, that fighting is evil.

content:
r 28, 2013
												While people complain that the Elder Scroll games can be quite bland and you play an expressionless psychopath mass murdering your way to the top of society, Oblivion is a sterling example of one of my favourite things about PC gaming - mods.   I have hundreds from total conversions to one that adds little street cats that wander around looking cute.  Oblivion really captures the DIY aspect of PC gaming I love in a shiny giant studio package, allowing me to change almost anything i don't like about vanilla.  Unlike console people, to merely review and make judgements based on vanilla is to miss the beauty of PC gaming.  It's that kind of community that keeps an aging game fresh interesting and addictive.As far as the extras in the GOTY go, whether you care about player houses shapes much of  the DLC, Mehrune's Razor quest is a large dungeon, nothing mind blowing if you play with Lost Spires mod, but some very shiny loot.  The Knights of the Nine was a fairly straight-forward quest, would call it a good DLC rather than an expansion pack as such.  However although you have to seriously stab someone at the end, at least some of the quests have variety in what you have to do a bit.  However Shivering Isles makes this edition worth your money imo.  It adds some much needed oddness to the game, the kind of thing where you pause to think 'wtf is that?' as some creature shuffles or leaps towards you.  Without getting into the whole 'which elder scrolls is best', one thing i felt was Oblivion and Skyrim settled with standard pseudo-medieval europe fantasy world, whereas Morrowind felt quite alien, but with it's own culture to be read about and discovered.  Shivering Isles brings that to Oblivion.  The books are a delight, and it's nice to experience a daedric realm aside from the Deadlands (which while fun, never felt like a place people lived).  All in all and bearing in mind what i said about the still quite vital mod community, I totally recommend you buy this game.

number of helpful: 262 of 273 people (96%) found this review helpful13 people found this review funny
content:
ry 6, 2015
												I've noticed that the reviews for Morrowind, Oblivion, and Skyrim tend to be about why that game is the best Elder Scrolls game and the others are terrible in comparison. I really enjoy all three of them (sorry, Arena and Daggerfall, you're just not very enjoyable by today's standards), so I figured I'll give reviews for each that focus on what's unique about each of them, and what kind of players that will appeal to.Oblivion was my first Elder Scrolls game (and my first open-world RPG in general), so it has a special place in my heart. Anytime I hear that music come up when I launch the game, it brings back all sorts of emotions and wonderful feelings related to discovering a whole new type of game that I thoroughly enjoy. As good as the music in Morrowind was, Oblivion's music is even better for me (both are better than Skyrim's).For positives, let's start with Oblivion being the most deliberate of the three games. What I mean by that is that things are the most contained and orderly in Oblivion. You don't "accidentally" do anything in this game, as opposed to Morrowind and even Skyrim to a degree. Leveling up is slower in Oblivion, and so you don't race through anything. It gives you plenty of time to savor everything. You don't start a new game and find yourself pimped out with super powerful gear or spells a couple hours later. The landscape is also fairly contained, with each region and city being unique in its own right, while not having any drastic changes. The most extreme the landscape gets (besides when you are transported to the hellish realm of Oblivion or the DLC that sends you to the Shivering Isles) is some snowy mountains in the north. And for this game, that works perfectly. You are in Cyrodiil, the center of the empire, and therefore the most refined. The somewhat subdued landscape fits into that perfectly. Compared to Morrowind and Skyrim, this game world is neat, orderly, and prim and proper. It makes you form an emotional attachment to the game, since you focus less on the landscape and more on people and feelings, while still enjoying beautiful scenery. And when you get to the Shivering Isles DLC, you're well versed in forming those emotional attachments, while now having some very bizarre and magnificent scenery to add to your playing experience.The biggest positive of Oblivion (for me) is one of the most pleasant surprises in the entire series. My single favorite thing in any TES game is what would seem to be some relatively minor DLC from this game. There are four distinct castles, lairs, caves, and towers available through the DLC. Each is geared towards a specific playstyle (warrior, assassin, thief, mage). There are all sorts of things available for each, and some questlines regarding them. I find myself spending a lot of time doing those quests and getting enough money to afford the upgrades, some of which are incredibly useful (alchemy ingredient gardens, a pirate crew that goes out and plunders for you every week, a dark shrine to Sithis that grants you potent powers based on your infamy, etc.). There are also unique items in each. Basically, they are the greatest player homes in any TES game, and they're official content, not mods. For the negatives of this game, we will actually revisit some of the positives I mentioned. It's slower than the others, which can sometimes make you feel bogged down. It's polished, nice, and orderly, but sometimes you want something more wild and rugged. Think of it as the difference between living in a nice suburb and living in a cabin in the Rocky Mountains.  There's not really anything wrong with this game, but it always stays in the safe zone. There are no glaring errors, but its peak is lower than the other games. Basically, Oblivion is content with always hitting singles or doubles, so that means that there are no strikeouts, but also no homeruns. Oblivion will disappoint you the least often of any of the three games, but also won't take your breath away like Morrowind or Skyrim does occasionally.

content:
3, 2014
												Bam. You're a prisoner. Then what? Oh, its just PICARD TELLING YOU YOU'RE IN HIS DREAMS. SECRET. PASSAGE. HE DIES (OH NOES) TAKE THIS SEXY AMULET. GET OUT OF THE SEWERS. EXPLORE FOR 100+ HOURS.Well, you can already tell this game will be incredible. But seriously, this game starts off very strong. You're a prisoner, with your crimes unknown to you. As long as you don't abuse the character creator (hehe...) you'll be able to mold your ideal elf, human, or orc... or cat... or lizard. But yes, many great awesome things happen in the first few minutes within the game. You may think the game is linear... until you exit that sewer. "Can I go anywhere?" "Can I follow this road?" "I want that horse. Can I steal it?" The answer to all this is a glorious "yes". Oblivion is at it's best when you're wondering along the vast land of Cyrodiil, exploring multiple dungeons, mines, and towns. Oblivion is outdated, but still pulls you into the world.Quests are great. Some surpass Skyrim's as far as story goes. (The Thieves’ Guild quest line is so much better.) There are both your typical quests with markers, and a well mix of a few. Ranging from some puzzle solving, to even being a detective, it'll keep you entertained. Help out a town by shutting down an Oblivion Gate (which furthers the main story), and now you can buy a house there, and buy upgrades for it, just for playing the main quest. Kill an innocent person, and have a very unique visitor appear, and follow a very dark path. Either way you'll be getting into all sorts of crazy situations, and it'll be a delight. Gameplay is more complex than Skyrim, yet not quite like Morrowind's. I consider it a perfect balance, as its tough, but very rewarding. If you're a weakling, maybe you shouldn't steal that horse just yet. Oblivion in a way pushes you to a certain type of major, as if you’re taking college classes. Keep shooting that bow, and you'll advance specially in that skill set, and use your experience to further develop this. But if you pull out a sword after not using it for three levels, well you might want to rethink what you're doing. It’s not hard, but the game defiantly wants to pick one type of combat and stick with it. This is fine to me, as I love dedicating my character to a specific type of combat. If I want to be good with a sword, and have some good magical ability as a side dish, I can do that. It'll just take time.This game probably has the greatest DLC ever. The horse armor has so much value... well not really THAT specific DLC, but Shivering Isles is a MUST HAVE. You're getting another free game when you purchase this. Knights of the Nine is harder to get access to due to the slow leveling progress, but is also pretty great. Get GOTYDeluxe, its worth the extra $5, you penny pincher. Mods, mods everywhere as well. There are some greats ones. In fact, this game taught me how to mod. I might of ruined my first save file(s) tough doing that, so be warned; there's no silky Steam Workshop bed waiting for you upstairs. You must use either your brain, or a Mod Manager application. For those complaining that it isn't working on Windows 7; The Steam (digital) version seems to work fine, and there's a mod called "Unofficial Oblivion Patch" which solves many conflicts and errors, and is stupidly simple to install. Get the latest version patched for your game as well. In fact, before even launching the game, you might want to do all these things I've mentioned. Also have the latest video drivers installed (derp).Oblivion may be old, but you shouldn't stick your nose up at it. It's great, and will always be great.

9, 2016
												When I was 8 years old, my dad pre ordered the original oblivion on Xbox 360 for me. At the time I knew nothing about the game, he just thought it would be fun for me to play as a knight ♥♥♥♥ing ♥♥♥♥ up doing hoodrat elder scrolls stuff. I had never played morrowind or daggerfall, but the second I made my character I was hooked. I played oblivion religiously, collecting the official game guide, multiple physical maps of tamriel, and I even kept journals of all of my quests and wrote in the first person as my character. I would then go to school and share these journals with my friends who also had the game and who also wrote their own adventures down. It became a sort of 'guild' group if you will.Time went on and Skyrim came out in 2011 when I was in junior high, thus causing me to forget about oblivion and move on as the dragonborn. But just recently I was going through some of my closets getting rid of old junk I had been hoarding, and I came across a stack of about fifteen books hidden underneath some blankets and boxes. They were my oblivion journals. Frantically I plugged in my xbox, located the game, and fired that ♥♥♥♥ up. My heart sunk when I realized the disk had been scratched long ago. So I went on to steam and saw that the game of the year adition was available for a rather cheap price. When I was younger I never even knew about the DLC because I was so lost in exploring and creating my own stories for my character.Today, as an 18 year old, getting ready to move out of my house, I can tell you that the extensive world of Oblivion is much bigger than I ever remembered it to be.And to this day, the music that plays when I  treck across the land still brings joy to my heart. Please play this game and download it's DLC. It is a near perfect gaming experience filled with lor and action. 100/10 would be an elementary school dweeb because of this game again.

												Well people can say w/e they want about the elder scrolls games but Oblivion for me is by far the greatest entry in the series. Why? (Spoilers included)1. You travel to Oblivion ✔2. You banish a daedric God for ever ✔3. You will never ride a mf dragon, but you get to make one yourself ✔4. No matter what you do, you will always lose both your current and future king ✔5. You will help make a mad god sane in a fashion... ✔6. You will make a bad elven dude who was dead for some millenia, stay dead forever ✔7. You get to kill all your fellow assassins if u play the dark brotherhood quests ✔8. You get to steal an elder scroll and feel badass about it ✔9. You can feel like spartacus doing the arena quests ✔10. You will get to talk and meet the most polite and good natured vampires and still u will kill them ✔11. You will explore the most beautiful landscapes u have ever seen ✔12. You get to have sword shield and do magic at the same time ✔13. You have  tons of mods. ✔14. You get to do more magic stuff ✔15. You get to experience a medieval sims game by making potions/crafting stuff/sleeping (alot)/fixing things/buying stuff/selling stuff/making a house/upgrading your house/eating/cooking and making life altering choices that affect an entire continent ✔20. You get to use cheats everytime u are bored and experience the ultimate thrill of being a God       (You can even kill everyone in the game with a single command) ✔Seriously though whats not to like?

number of helpful: 174 of 177 people (98%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
4, 2014
												First of all, if your question is "Should I buy this game, period?", my answer is simply: Yes.If your question is "Should I buy this game, or skyrim?" the answer's a bit more complex. I would not say either one is better, but they're two different tastes, like vanilla and chocolate.In this case, I would say Oblivion is the vanilla. If you're looking for a straight-up, classic medieval fantasy, Oblivion might be more your thing than Skyrim, which is "themed" around the viking-style Nords. Likewise, Oblivion has the default fantasy setting of castles and forests and rolling green plains, where Skyrim is, again, Nordic themed, and focused mostly on mountains and snow.Because of that, and some differences in art styles, Skyrim and Oblivion look very different, to the point where I would almost say that might be the deciding factor in which game is right for you. Skyrim is very much a modern game, with fairly realistic art, and that includes the recent trend of realistic games to be primarily brown and gray. Oblivion, on the other hand, is vibrant and colorful, and perhaps a bit stylized. If you are longing for a colorful first person fantasy game, Oblivion is for you (if you're looking for a sidescroller, I'd recommend Trine). If you've been wading through the Real-Is-Brown trend, the sheer vibrance of Oblivion can be a real breath of fresh air.As for gameplay, the two games are relatively similar. I personally prefer the spellcasting setup in Oblivion over that in Skyrim - in Oblivion, you equip spells in their own slot, rather than in a hand (which could instead be holding a weapon), whereas Skyrim just treats spells like a sword that has to be put in one of your hands. Speaking of which, you cannot dual wield in this game. If you want to play a classic sword-and-shield knight, this particular difference in mechanics is more or less irrelevant, except that it's easier in Oblivion to cast the occasional healing spell.Furthermore, Oblivion offers a much greater degree of freedom in spellcasting than Skyrim. You can create your own spells by adding effects and designating whether the spell is a projectile, area of effect, etc. Enchanting and Alchemy are slightly more complex than in Skyrim, as well. If you like playing spellcasters, I'd say Oblivion is probably a better choice than Skyrim, which has you simply pick from pre-determined spells, and has a far more limited alchemy and enchanting system.The biggest mechanical difference is the level up system. Without a doubt, Skyrim's level up system is more user friendly and intuitive. It might be a little more friendly to those who want to play these games casually, where Oblivion requires a little more care, planning, and effort. In Skyrim, you level up your skills as you use them, and after you've increased any combination of skills by a certain amount, you can go up a character level (on the spot, even). When you do, you increase one of your three stats (yes, only three: health, mana, stamina), and pick a talent tree to put a talent point in, which gives you bonuses - with different talent slots unlocking as you raise the respective skill. In Oblivion it is completely different. For one thing, you have several stats, each tied to three skills. The number of times you level any combination of skills attached to a given stat affects how much you could POTENTIALLY increase that stat by when you level up (and if you dont' get those +5s, you will find that the game swiftly outlevels you). By the way, you only level up when you raise ten points in any combination of your class's seven major skills, and only when you sleep. Skyrim has no classes, and therefore no major skills. This makes Skyrim's character-building system a little bit more freeform, as you can, if you want, change directions as you go, if you decide you don't like a particular aspect. Oblivion allows you to create a custom class, but you're basically stuck with that choice after you finish the tutorial.In short, Skyrim has a simpler, more intuitive, more fluid leveling dynamic, good for building your character as you go according to what feels natural, while Oblivion might be better for those who like to plan or min-max, and requires a bit more thinking ahead.I should also mention that on certain computer systems, the music in this game may not work. It certainly doesn't work on my system, but otherwise the game runs just fine. From what I understand this is an issue with the CODECs and may be related to Windows 7.One other thing I think is important to mention is that this game, despite being a fantasy, is surprisingly arachniphobe friendly. As someone with arachniphobia, I find it hard to deal with how ubiquitous giant spiders are in fantasy games. Skyrim's spiders are particularly horrifying. But Oblivion has no (true) spiders at all. It does have the Spider Daedra, which are essentially spider-centaurs, but I didn't find them particularly phobia-triggering. They're also very rare outside of the oblivion gates, so you won't often find yourself being jumped by one unexpectedly. If you are an arachniphobe looking for a fantasy game, I HIGHLY recommend Oblivion, especially if you're comparing it to Skyrim.Also, this game has Martin Septim.That's reason enough to buy it.

number of helpful: 501 of 582 people (86%) found this review helpful29 people found this review funny
content:
er 20, 2014
												Oblivion, in my opinion, is the best game of all time. It gets a bad reputation among fans of other elder scrolls games, you see the argument that Morrowind is the game for patient players that can enjoy an older game, and skyrim is this big new awesome RPG, and so Oblivion is seen as some weird spot in the middle of the two. Yet I repeat, oblivion is the best game I have ever played. Many Morrowind players dislike Oblivion with the argument that it is less inclusive and immersive than Morrowind. But then why is Skyrim the only game on par with Morrowind? Skyrim, the game with less weapon types, the game with the worst alchemy, the game with the worst magic? Skyrim's graphics barely surpass the incredibly captured beauty of Cyrodil, and they had five years to make skyrim. They had four to make Oblivion, and your blind grandma could easily tell the difference between that and Morrowind graphically. The gameplay was also a complete overhaul from morrowind to oblivion. People talk about how Morrowind's or Skyrim's fighting systems are so much better, with Morrowind's realistic feel that you have to be good with the weapon type or you will be awful, or with skyrim's realistic feeling combat but Oblivion completely build anew the combat system of morrowind, made it insanely more realistic, and remains the only game in the series that you can have a sword, shield, and spell at the same time. From Morrowind to skyrim each game got easier. Morrowind is the most difficult of the three, with no quest markers on a compass, and no advice or help whatsoever. But when I went to play skyrim it was the easiest thing in the world. Anyone can take a nord with a battleaxe and beat the game. Oblivion is in the middle. Oblivion isn't like the insane difficulty of morrowind, showing how hard each quest would be were you actually to do it in real life and record the words that someone said to find a secret location. Oblivion helps you, but is not easy. The game has an easier start, but if you can remain powerful past level 30, that's when you know you're good. Skyrim is just always easy. Progress through oblivion is kind of like progress through life. The lower your level, the less you have to worry. But as you grow into the game it takes constant effort and maintenance to remain successful. In oblivion you have to have a gameplan. Will you be a thief that goes around and gets rich to make sure they have the best equipment in the game, and talks your way out of hard situations? Will you be the the brute warrior that relies on lots of stamina and power to take down less physically gifted enemies? Or will you be my personal favorite, the mage that can go about every situation in a million different ways? Sure, you can mesh these things to any degree, but the point is that if you don't go about it correctly with skills that make sense together or you use the wrong race, you won't be successful later on.You could go on forever about the systems in place in oblivion that make it unique and amazing but Oblivion is the game that revolutionizes combat and especially graphics (Oblivion had some of the best graphics the world had ever seen, and was made on such a large scale that's almost an unimaginable feat) but sticks true to the elder scrolls mentality. Skyrim is a game to pull people into the franchise. Skyrim is the start of a new generation, a worse generation, of TES players. Oblivion is the peak in the series.

number of helpful: 603 of 717 people (84%) found this review helpful84 people found this review funny
content:
er 2, 2014
												What can I say about Oblivion. I was gifted the game when it came out on the Xbox 360. And after that, I continued to play it till I gave the game to my girlfriend 6 years later and bought the GOTY version on PC, which I'm playing at this moment. I have a lot more hours on PC Skyrim simply because I thought it would be better.  I was wrong. I'm now adding to my collection of inhuman hours of Xbox 360 Oblivion.  Don't get me wrong, dear Skyrim fanboy. It IS a great game, with amazing atmosphere and graphics. It one-ups Oblivion on graphics, since it's 4 years younger. But when it comes to atmosphere, Skyrim might as well be a cardboard box. Here's why:  Oblivion's soundtrack is rich and beautiful, unlike Skyrim's flat "Dovahkiin" "Badass" default track every time you get in a battle.  Skyrim's main questline is almost nessisary, since it contains the Shouts that are so very fun to use. Oblivion's main questline, however, is lots of fun, and optional. You'll miss out on items, but you'll never be lacking in a critical game ability that was the gimick of the entire launch.  Skyrim is flat and snowy, with SOME differences around the eastern and southwest parts of the map. And when you are in those green areas, it still feels like it's about to freeze over. Oblivion has snow, beautiful snow in fact, but it's SO diversive in the enviorment section. Beaches, forests, mountains, valleys, rivers, lakes, ponds, actual Oblivion, it's all amazing. And the colors are so vivid, with reds and greens and yellows and blues and OH GOD ITS GREAT.  When you fight a bandit in Skyrim, you're swinging a pool noodle at a mural. When you fight a bandit in Oblivion, it's head will twist to the left when you deliver the final blow with your Elven Mace, it's body crumpling to the ground, ready to plunder ( and sometimes teabag ). No silly spinning death animations that need a mod to disable like I have, just ragdoll. Like real life.  All in all, Oblivion is ahead of it's days. It was an improvement to Skyrim in the atmosphere department, not graphics. I LOVE Skyrim for all of her faults ( one of my favorite gaming moments of all time were my first 2 hours in the Forgotten Vale, absolutely breathtaking ) but Oblivion takes the cake. Morrowind? That's a different story. Totally different subject. I don't have much experience with the game honestly, so I can't effectively make a decision over who wins in the entire trilogy. And yeah, it's a trilogy. ( EDIT, I know Elder Scrolls isn't a trilogy. I was tired and wrote this half-arsed. Stop commenting on it :) ) ESO sucks ♥♥♥♥. I said it.  Buy this game, with the DLC. It ain't no map pack, it's two seperate and amazing questlines. Just buy the game. Right now.

content:
5, 2016
												I love this game. I love the atmosphere. I love the Sidequests. I love the main quest. I love the ARENA!! (which was absent in Skyrim) I love the cities, especially Anvil. I love the fact that there were only like 13 voice actors for the entire game. I love that there seemed to be 2 voice actors for 1 person sometimes. you can be talking to a beggar and he will weakly say  "I can eat for a whole week with just a single coin." so you give him a coin. And he he will boomingly say "BLESSINGS OF AKATOSH UPONG YE!!" in a completely different tone that makes it sound like a different voice actor. I love wedging myelf between a bookshelf and the ceiling and jumping nonstop for a good 30 minutes to raise my acrobatics. I love murdering the adoring fan at the top of that one mountain or just leaving him standing out in the middle of nowhere and leaving him there for days. I love how when you walk into different buildings it actually felt like you were in a different place(every building in Skyrim felt the same to me) I love the persuation wheel thing that changes the NPCs facial expression. I love randomly exploring the world at times with no point or destination. I love how you can spend hours, and hours, and hours, and hours, and hours trying to level up your mercantilism by just 3 points. I love delving into bottomless caves and ruins just to find someones lost sword. I love hearing the sound of goblins getting wrecked by a longsword. I love jumping on top of roofs and shooting an almost endless supply of guards. I love the lockpicking.I love talking to Ma'iq the Liar outside Leyawiin and trying to keep up with him as he runs off. I love, love, LOVE the soundtrack. In fact I love the soundtrack to this game so much that I use part of one of the songs as the ringtone to my phone. I love finding that one enchanted glass helmet of the coast near Anvil. I love this game. And you should love it too. I dont have many hours on it on steam but I put over 500 hours on this game when I was a but a young teen on the PS3. Do yourself a favor and buy this game.

number of helpful: 140 of 148 people (95%) found this review helpful24 people found this review funny
content:
, 2016
												The first time I played Oblivion, I hated it. I thought it had the worst character models of all time, and the combat took too long and felt unnecessarily difficult, I immediately developed the opinion that Skyrim was the best game in every regard. That was probably one of the biggest mistakes I've ever made concerning a video game. The thing about oblivion that makes it the polar opposite of Skyrim is that, the more you play Oblivion, the better it gets. Meanwhile Skyrim is magical at first, and then progressively gets way too easy and tedious. So heres why you need to play Oblivion in 2016:1) The combatAs mentioned antecedently, Oblivion combat system is ♥♥♥♥ing ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ at first, but then, very similarly to Morrowind, you feel yourself getting progressively more powerful. You start as someone less dangerous than a native american toddler with cerebral palsy, but turn into one of the most epic warriors on the face of Tamriel. It also requires more skill, you need to strafe and blocking actually consistently makes a difference in who falls first in an engagement. Although there are no fancy decapitation animations, it still rewards more of a sense of completion, since you know that you have to be powerful to slay this person or creature.2) The StoryOblivions many storylines, particulary the Dark Brotherhoods, blow skyrim out of the water. The characters have so much more depth than, "I came from X and I'm gonna hostile to you now but after one ♥♥♥♥ing quest I'm gonna worship the ground you walk on" They will start to like you more after every few assassinations, depending on how well you perform them, and when its done, you wont just be their favorite warrior, you will be their leader. Same with the main quest, rather than just running around dungeon to dungeon, killing the draugr "boss" at the end. There are many different types of quests within the main storyline, and honestly it feels like a complete movie at a certain point.3) The questsYou know whats better than having to go into a tunnel fight the draugr minions, fix a puzzle with the directions right in front of you, and have it be the same puzzle every time? EVERYTHING is the answer to that. Oblivion has such a vast arsenal of different variations of quests that it can throw at you, poisoning someones food, chasing a unicorn, etc4) The worldThe final point I'm going to rant about is that the world of Oblivion is more interesting than Skyrims in almost every regard. The people have their own conversations, and the game somehow manages to give personality to all of the random conversations as well. For example, when a nord and an imperial had a conversation, the imperial said, "those nords sure are hostile" and he immediately said goodbye. That sort of discomfort in the face of racism adds so much personality and says alot about the world itself, and the bigotry is hurled in every direction from every direction. It also, despite a weaker engine, still looks prettier, due to its bright colors rather than white and brown. BY AZURA BY AZURA BY AZURA

content:
18, 2015
-Quick Review-The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion is a massive open world game developed by Bethesda and released March 20, 2006. It would take too long to list all the various quests, armor, weapons, enchantments, and magic spells you can learn/create, simply trust me when I say this game is an adventure waiting to happen.-Detailed breakdown review-Story: This is probably one of my personal favorite parts of Elder Scrolls of Oblivion, once you get out of the starting area you can make your own story, or follow the main story, or go search for your own quest. If you wanted, you could become a villain, you could also become a hero. The choices are completely up to you.The whole Elder Scrolls series is very rich is lore and diversity of environment, you can read in-game books and learn useful facts about the monsters you fight. Not everyone will do this, but I ended up learning what all Trolls are weak against, and I've been using it in all Elder Scrolls games since.I won't say much more about the story, because most of the fun is in finding the quests and stories yourself, and of course forging your own tale.... however there is one additional thing to note, in the Game of the Year Edition you get the Shivering Isles Expansion, and there you meet my favorite character in the whole series.Game Play: You can control the camera to play in third person, or first person. (personally I always thought third person looked silly... the knee's bend funny, and when you jump your legs stay straight. seems like an indication of "play in first person").You could be a necromancer and summon skeleton hoards, you could be a thief and sneak into combat, you could be a warrior and smash your enemies faces in, you can be a mage and even create your own skills, you can be a ranger and pew pew, a monk, an acrobat or any hybrid combination of what I've said and much much more.Achievements: There are no Steam Achievements in this game, you can certainly find plenty of challenges online to test your skill in the game, or simply increase the difficulty of the game.Price The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion Game of the Year Edition is priced at $19.99, as always, I suggest you wait for a sale, but if you already know you like this style of game you won't lose money out of it, since the game is getting "old" *cough cough cough* you should probably look for a good deal out of the game, it goes on sale often.Conclusion: This was the first Open world game I ever played, I absolutely loved it, and I still remember the fun I had playing the game. The stories/quests are very memorable and the game play was dynamic and very fluid. I recommend this game to anyone who enjoys open world or RPG's.------Edits and updates------Edit/Update March 18, 2015:I redid my review for Oblivion, thereby normalizing it into the framework I do for all my reviews. (No one ever read the old review anyway, you're not missing anything)Update June 23, 2015:Corrected release date from 2007, to 2006.Update September 14, 2015:Here's the URL to see my review for  Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim (Including links for Skyrim DLC reviews!)

ber 27, 2016
												I played Skyrim before Oblivion, but still feels Oblivion has much to impress me.After I saved Kvatch, people started calling me "Hero of Kvatch".After the Bruma Battle, a statue of my character was built beside the city gate, which was generated based on my weapon and armors instead of using a pre-set one.After the main quest line, all the guards hail me as Champion of Cyrodill when I pass by.After I became head of a guild, I recieve unique benefits like a real man in charge.After I became Grand Champion of the Arena, there is an adoring fan who wants to worship the ground I walk.All these details make me feel like that I am really living in the world and making a difference. I am really changing my place in the age of chaos through hard battle and honest work.Instead, in Skyrim, guards still call me a sneak thief after I saved Skyrim from dragons. Nobody on Solstheim recognizes me even after I saved their asses from Miraak. I helped a Jarl to reclaim his throne but all I got afterwards is "You are not as dumb as you look".Bethesda, WTF?============================================================pros:+Not bad graphic as a game in 2006. +Despite some strange looking NPCs and their strange chit-chats, Cyrodill is a much better place than Skyrim, considering climate, city scale, politeness of the guards, etc.+The Woold Elves are so cute.+The Shocking Oblivion Gates.+Elder Scrolls music never fails to impress.+Magic crafting. College of Winterhold looks like a bunch of rookies in comparison.+Newspaper about the quests you have done. I don't know why they cancel this in Skyrim.+Shivering Isle is really something you should not miss.cons:-Bug. Bug never changes.-Poor motion design. Takes some getting used to.-Awkward NPC chatting systems. Mother and daughter greet each other like strangers, have some random talk, say goodbye, and then immediately greet each other again.-Useless followers.-Dungeons are like f**king labyrinths and have little to offer other than common monsters and meaningless random loots. No related quests. No background info.  I can see why Bethesda hired experienced level designers to construct dungeons in Skyrim.-It ruined my life like Skyrim did.

It has inspired me to eventually buy morrowind as ive become so interested in the lore behind the elder scrolls because of this game. It feels so much more authentic than skyrim. I enjoy the combat so much more. And it is so much more immersive than skyrim wil ever be. And i only have very few mods for the game. The exploration aspect of the game is so much more rewarding than skyrim's and you actually have to put in a lot of work to become even somewhat powerful. number of helpful: 134 of 148 people (91%) found this review helpful13 people found this review funny
content:
13, 2015
OverviewThe Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion is the fourth installment of the series and one of the most known and loved fantasy RPG in gaming. Released in 2006 by Bethesda, the game is still very played to this day, and has a very active modding community, which is a testament of the life-span of a great game. Embark on a journey full of lore, quests and dungeon explorations in this masterpiece of a game.The Pros
Enticing Gameplay - Oblivion is a game that really nails it when it comes to gameplay. You always find some new quest to do or a new dungeon to explore, people to gossip, barter or fight with. The large, open map provides many opportunities to explore and create your own adventure. Even if you already completed the game and know the majority of quests, it’s still fun to replay them. The quests are very well done, and much more diverse than one might expect, primarily due to the rich backstory they provide.Long Completion Time - Don’t worry about running out of things to do. There are over 200 quests and 400 locations to discover, explore and loot. Not to mention this is a Role-Playing Game. You can have multiple playthroughs, each with it’s own different approach on what and who you are, how you attack, and how you respond at moral decisions in quests.Beautiful Soundtrack - This game has, in my opinion, the best soundtrack in the history of gaming. The music is very well made for each situation. It is relaxing when wandering, thrilling when in battle. Jeremy Soule really hit the nail on its head on this one. Modding - Head on over to Oblivion Nexus to download and install a few of thousands of available mods, that fix most if not all problems vanilla oblivion has. Bug fixes, texture enhancements, ENBs, UI redesigns, quest mods, item mods, gameplay tweaks, and so much more are being offered by the modding community. This is one of Oblivions strongest points, and will definitely make the game several times more enjoyable. Just make sure you take your time to research, download and organise them before you start playing. Expansion Packs - We all know the famous “Horse Armor” DLC fiasco, but let’s not get in the way of its actual expansion packs, namely Knights of the Nine and The Shivering Isles. The latter is considered one of the best expansion packs that were ever released, and comes included in the Game of the Year version on Steam. It adds lots of new content, including maps, items, quests, characters and  gameplay elements.The Cons
Vanilla Version - This is just informing you that the vanilla game you get when you first download it is a bit underselling. The graphics are outdated(Duh! 2006 game) and there are quite a few (hundred) small bugs and other inconsistencies that may occur during gameplay, the faces of characters look… well, hideously ugly in some cases. All of these problems and many more are easily fixed with a few tweaks and mods and you can enjoy a better, prettier, and more stable version by installing them. There are loads of bits and pieces I could write long rants about, but there’s a mod for all of them, so I won’t bother. I will concentrate only on the things inherently bad about the game that cannot be fixed (in most cases)Voice Casting - Given that Patrik Steward voiced about 5 minutes of emperor Uriel’s lines, the budget was already out the window, so we are left with about… a few handfuls of voice actors, each representing their race. This makes it a little weird having every member of a gender and race sound the same, with a few exceptions. Albeit, in order to do this, each actor recorded the entirety of the dialogues, even ones that would never be used by their characters, for safe-proofing. A lot of work to be admired, however the problem of little to no diversity between characters’ voices is a little disappointing. Which isn’t to say they sound awful. The sound quality is good and the actors are talented. It’s just that everything sounds the same. Also, you may encounter beggars that change voices radically between different topics.Totalitarian Crime System - There is a running gag of the telepathic guards that roam Oblivion in search for you. Doing any murder, even in complete and utter stealth, even in the most devoid of any witnesses location, that crime will be recorded, a bounty will be placed on your head, and sometimes guards might leave the cities in search for you and they know exactly where you are. Not only this, but touching items is a crime. You are a guest in someone’s home. You see a misplaced fork on the table and just want to nudge it a bit to align it with the plate. Yup, you are going to be arrested. Or say you broke in someone’s house late at night, and you steal an apple. That apple is now known throughout the entire province of Cyrodill as being stolen and cannot be sold to anyone but thief guild fences. You can come to a merchant with 20 apples, but he will specifically know that only 18 of them are righteously yours. You can’t sell the other two. How!? Why!?Uneven Leveling System - (fixable by mods) The world seems to be leveling with you, which seems stupid. By about level 20, every common bandit you find will be equipped with the best grade weapons and armor, which breaks the immersion and unbalances the game. Also, attaining the perfect character (max stats) requires a deep understanding of the leveling system and painstakingly much micro-management.ConclusionIt may seem the cons list is longer, but trust me, this game is amazing. It is one of my favorite games of all time, and have been rocking a lot more hours before I got it on Steam. If you like RPGs, then this is a must have. I recommend it with all my heart. Be sure to mod it and to try to find everything there is to do in it. To help you, here are some links:UESP Wiki[www.uesp.net] - Huge Wiki of everything you need to know.Modding Guide - List of my favorite mods, why and how to install them.If you enjoyed this review and want to see more of my work, consider joining my group and follow my curator page! Link to the right!Jad's List - Curator Group

content:
19, 2015
												A definite must-buy for a fan of The Elder Scrolls series. "Ermagerd Skyrim is better Oblivion sucks cus graphics!!!11! You're just an Oblivion fanboy!11!!!". Well no.I first started playing The Elder Scrolls series a few years back, when Skyrim first came out because of all the hype. Reason why it shows a ridiculously low number of Skyrim playtime hours on my Steam profile would be that I didn't get the Steam version as I didn't have a Steam account then. I finished the entire main storyline, finished all the DLC, 90% of all sidequests and explored almost 80% of the dungeons in Skyrim.Now, I only got Oblivion after much insistence by a few of my friends. At first, I was very turned off by the bad graphics and  combat system. I compared it a lot with Skyrim, but I tried to look past the graphics. It was then I got really surprised. Funnily enough, after playing Oblivion for awhile, I like it better than Skyrim. I appreciate and get attached to the characters in Oblivion more than the characters in Skyrim. Maybe it's because the character development in Skyrim pale in comparison? Or maybe it is because they hardly (almost never) kill off companions in Skyrim. In Oblivion, a lot of the main characters of the side quests  even the main quest  get killed off, and you cannot simply ressurect them using console  like if you accidentally kill off Lydia in Skyrim. Face it, everyone does that , because their death is crucial in that plot. I like the change of pace in Oblivion compared to the rest of the games I have played so far, because you are not the main hero here. You are just a Blade, assisting the next Emperor to take over the throne and stop Mehrunes Dagon. You do not get to do the final blow to the villian, you do not get to be "hero" at the end of the main storyline. Because someone else close to you will do it for you. And trust me, you will get this feeling of emptiness for a very long time after that.The soundtrack is really beautiful here, although it may make you feel lonely especially when you are exploring the wilderness. The horses actually make a satisfying galloping sound, although they are not as ridiculous in climbing vertical walls.If one were to compare Skyrim and Oblivion, I would say they are both incomparable. It's like comparing an apple and an orange. They are similar, but you cannot directly compare them both. If you are looking for something different, and something more story-based, and a f*ck ton of plot twists, go for Oblivion. But if you are more of the graphics, modern-day sandbox game which follows a linear plot, go for Skyrim instead. Overall, I enjoy this installment, will definitely put in more hours in this game.

content:
er 2, 2014
												Stop right there criminal scum! Oblivion needs you!--WARNING--Make sure you buy the GoTY DELUXE version of the game - if you don't, you'll miss out on all of the smaller DLC, as they are not sold seperately and cannot be purchased afterwards!EDIT:If you're looking for better graphics, check out Oblivion Reloaded @ Nexusmods, link here: http://www.nexusmods.com/oblivion/mods/45749/?Oblivion Reloaded replaces previous versions of OBGE and overall is more power and efficient than alternatives (possibly even ENB).So yep, the game is still being modded.--Reviewing Oblivion is a little tricky for me because I've had it for years. Many, many years. I've literally had it since sometime during good ol' 2007. Thousands of hours easily poured into the none-steam version of the game, and time I do not regret putting into the game.It was, simply put, a centrepiece to the later years of my childhood. I enjoyed it so much I bought it on Steam too, so in case I ever lose any of the disks for whatever reason, I've got the steam version as a backup.So beyond countless hours playing the game, I've also got another issue. Mods. One really should not review a game on the basis of what users have created out of it -- even if modding is a huge aspect of the game -- but I do have some difficulty doing so accurately doing so, so you may have to bare with me.Gameplay:Oblivion had unique gameplay. For someone who had never played anything like it, Oblivion was something above and beyond anything I'd ever played. To this day, Oblivion has a number of unique gameplay features that aren't present in, say, Skyrim. I'll give some big differences below.- An attribute system. Each attribute governs a number of different skills and has a number of affects. Attributes such as Endurance, Agility, Intelligence and so on. For many players such as myself, these attributes add something extra to the game.- Fame and Infamy system. Your actions have a limited impact on the world in terms of disposition. People will react to you differently - murder lots of people, and people will react to it in terms of their opinion of you.- Repair skill and durability of weapons and armour - you need to manage the integrity of your equipment, or else watch it degrade and eventually break. There is even a hand-to-hand skill, so you can train yourself to kill people with your bare fists if you want to.- Disposition system. People like you more or less depending on events, infamy/fame, quests and even the silly mini-game in the game you can use. Personality attribute also has a big impact.- Scaling in the game is, to be blunt, terrible. At the beginning of the game, you'll find a rather friendly and not so hostile world. Deer will roam the wilds and slaughterfish will slaughter you whilst mudcrabs pick at your corpse. Skyrim does this slightly better, but mods can fix this in Oblivion.- Birthsigns are selected at the beginning of the game and have a permanent effect. Your birthsign will have a number of effects, ranging from lesser and greater powers to minor impacts on your attributes. This initial decision may full well shape your character in ways you will not be able to change later.- Working item moving. It's much better in Oblivion than Skyrim - you have much more control over the moving of items around your house and all that, with fewer bugs and what-not.- Lots of different armour pieces. Greaves, Gauntlets, Chestplate, Helmet and Boots.And much more. Actually, there is an entire page dedicated to it right here, including the differences between Morrowind too: http://www.uesp.net/wiki/Differences_Between_Morrowind,_Oblivion,_and_SkyrimNow onto modding (my original review with minor edits). Beyond vanilla gameplay, which intitially I thought was great, mods can turn the game into something completely different. Add in Deadly Reflex or UV to get a deadly and bloody game, despite being somewhat unrealistic. Or maybe go for Duke Patrick's combat mods and find yourself playing a realistic combat game.Or download thousands of other mods and mix and match to create a game that is unique for you. Don't like the levelling and skill progression? No problem. Grab numerous mods that edit the system, changing it into something more casual, more hardcore or even something completely different. XP system? Gotcha.I've played the game through multiple times over the years. I have to say, I'm still not bored of it, though I did take a break for a couple of years whilst I played Skyrim and Morrowind.Graphics are a little bit dated. But plenty of mods around it to bring it up to Not-Quite-Skyrim quality.

content:
24, 2014
												90% of my time spent playing was: duplicating poisoned apples, placing them in guard barracks, and watching guards slowly die11/10 would buy horse armortl;dr: It may follow Bethesda's formula of open-world enjoyment, but this one (and Morrowind) doesn't hold your hand.  It has enough RPG elements to make one playthrough of the game different from another.  Combat and bugs are aplenty, but the quests and varied map make up for those shortcomings. 9/10I first played this game back when I was 13. This was the first Elder Scrolls game that I was subject to (I was slightly too young to be interested in Morrowind at the timeit was released).  I had never played a game that allowed for such open-ended exploration and freedom.  This blew my mind when I first played and it seemed like there was always something new to find out in the world.  As a kid obsessed with this new experience, much of the flaws never really surfaced.Fast forward 10 years.  For nostalgia's sake, I take another trip down memory lane.  It isn't as fantastic as I remember it (but nothing is as good as the first time).  The exploration is still the best part of this game (as it is with all Bethesda games), but the problem is, once you've seen everything, a game can get old quick when it relies heavily on exploration.  This is the problem with all future Bethesda games (but that's a conversation for another time).  The quests are what elevate Oblivion.  There are still some fetch quests, but I think those are few and far between in this game.  If there are fetch quests, they dress them up and throw in plenty of twists to make it interesting.  The best part is there are tons of quests in this game.  Reliving those, or trying out new ways to complete them made this second playthrough incredibly enjoyable. Oh, and do yourself a favor and play through the best DLC/expansion Bethesda has ever made.  Shivering Isles was so diverse and included so much content that I feel like I still haven't done everything to do there.  Downsides: Bugs, no real controller support, potato faces.

content:
ber 19, 2016
												TL;DR:Oblivion is my favorite game of all time. You should defiently buy it and never play any other game, ever. I'll give it a 10/10 for what it is. The game is just amazing, though bethesda REALLY seems to have a thing for tracking down sons/famiy members or people in their games.(Martin, "Dad", Shaun, the blade guy in Morrowind).P.S. This game is better than Skyrim in a lot of ways.Story:You start as a prisoner in the Imperial City Prison. Sentenced for unknown crimes (Great for having an RP backstory). The Emperor comes down into the dungeons, it turns out your jail cell just happens to have a badass escape route out of the city. You end up escaping the city with the emperor, along the way you find out a little about what's going on. The Emperor has the "Amulet of Kings" which is used to create a barrier between your realm and Oblivion (hell).Mehrunes Dagon (main antagonist), god of Oblivon, wants to invade your realm. His little idiotic cult followers called the "Mythic Dawn" help him do that. They assassinated the Emperors sons and now have came for the Emperor himself.Now it's your destiny to take the Amulet of Kings and locate the Emperors ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ son, kept in secret, hidden away & make him Emperor and "Shut close the jaws of Oblivion".The story is awesome really, though the game lacks as a choice-based RPG. There's no choices (There's a few in the Dark Brotherhood (Assassin Guild)). The storytelling is amazing, -------World Development:Oh boy, this is where the game really shines. Bethesda is known as MASTERS of world development & Oblivion is no different. The game is set in Cyrodiil. The world is a bright, beautiful & vibrant place. It's very diverse (The game is set in the center of the continent, so has bits of everything). From Anvil, a port town on the west coast, to Bruma, a city of the Nords, far to the north in the mountains near Skyrim, to Leyawiin, a city far to the south, mostly inhabited by the Argonians and Khajits (Lizard and Cat people, beast races) a dark, swampy-like town.Or even the Imperial City itself, the largest city on the continent, filled with all the races and culture from everyone. Also the arena where you can pay to watch people beat eachother to death.RPG-ness:It's not a choice-based RPG. You can't choose sides and nothing conflics, but honestly it's not a bad thing & i'm sure there's mods for it anyway. It's more of an RPG that expresses a sense of freedom for the player. You can literally walk anywhere and interact with things, drag objects in the world around using the game physics, kill almost anyone you see and just take in the world. Anywhere at anytime.If you do NEED a choice-based RPG for your library, i'd definetly reccomend Dragon Age Origins (probably my second favorite game).(Same music composer too, Inon Zur, known for The Elder Scrolls, Fallout, Star Trek, Pirates of the Carribean, Prince of PErsia and more)Races, characters, voices etc:Cyrodiil, being set in the center of the continent, is home to all races, it has a large feeling of diversity, each city generally has a larger population of the race that the city is closest to their home province. The voice acting is great for ever race and there's a large amount of culture to it too. You'll here ambient dialog from characters in the street talking about things around the world & all NPC's wander around openly, they all have their scripts that they follow daily, at certain times they'll do certain things. Counts and Countesses will sleep at night, then attend their courtroom during the day. Places open and shut and scripted times and everything acts like a real world.-----------Overall I LOVE this game, it's a MUST have for any RPG/Open-World/Fantasy lover. If there's anything more to say I might add more to this review later.

												I was first introduced to the Elder's Scrolls franchise through Skyrim. I like it so much that I decided to try Oblivion. I'm glad I did. After clocking more than 100 hours in, I can say I like it more than Skyrim for its quests, colorful world and great mechanics. Now that I played both games, I think Bethesda decided to make Skyrim more accessible. Oblivion will give you a world of opportunities and invite you to explore.The graphics aren't the best, and combat is weak, but if you enjoy roleplaying a character and exploring a fantasy world, consider Oblivion. You won't be disappointed. Also, if you can pick up the DLCs. They are worth it for this game.

content:
er 22, 2013
												There's no  way  a short review such as this   can do justice to a game like Oblivion, it's too massive and there' too much to experience, especially when you factor in the number of custom made modifications that are available for this game.  Almost approaching the same as Unreal Tournament and the early Battlefield games (BF1942, BFV and BF2); we're talking several hundred gigabytes of free content at least (I have around 500GB for Oblivion and over a Terabyte for Battlerfield 2).The initial stage of the game where you have to escape the cobwebbed, dark and sometimes dank dungeon is   a little depressing, but still   a pleasure to experience the first few times around (it’s one of only   a few  linear parts of the game - another one is where you get transported into a painting), then you hit the outside, exiting the dungeon via a sewer drain.  On my first time it was a moonlit night and I was actually awed by the sight that I beheld.  I could see   the dark shapes of mountains and   the moonlight gave an eerie look to the small clouds slowly passing by.  The sky was full of glittering stars and I could see some distance ahead to a small broken down castle keep, all of which, even in the dark looked amazing.  I thought Morrowind was fantastic, but this was even better. I waited utill sunrise and was even more impressed by the amazing vista before me, Mountains  clothed in forests, morning mist,   a sun rise that looked almost real and  amazing,  the lush grass waving in the breeze, and    a whole host of other things swamped my  visual cortex.  Every step of the way, I marvelled at how realistic the grass, rocks and other objects looked.  Buildings, the imperial city, villages and towns all had their own distinct feel and charm.  The transition from night to day and back to night  is a pleasure to see; with HDR lighting, bloom effects, specular highlights and  parallax mapping  giving the game    some of the best visuals I’ve seen to date (well, maybe not the last    couple of years of AAA  game releases).  The effects are amazing, even now seven years after its release it still looks brilliant.  You can get several mods that improve many of the textures (the largest of these is around 3GB in size).The usual RPG elements are present; for example, levelling up, plus  resource collection for  crafting magical weapons and  potions as well as stocking  yourself with  better armour, weapons , arrows, spears, potions etc.    Combat is nothing special, but still satisfying when swapping between bow, sword spear and magic.  Despatching enemies isn’t too hard, especially once you’ve got a steady stream of healing potions.If you still haven’t purchased this game, now is the time to get it.  It includes   the expansion The Shivering Isles and the mod package Knights of the Nine that contains several   new missions, etc.  You can see several videos HERE,  HERE, HERE, HERE and HERE.The first one is  the escape from the dungeon, the next  two videos are in and around Cyrodiil  and the last two relate to the Oblivion gates.

content:
r 11, 2014
												The Elder Scrolls: Oblivion is by far my favourite in the series. I have played the Elder Scrolls since Morrowind came out way back and have continued it's amazing legacy in my life to this very day. Of course, it comes with bugs and glitches but what do you expect from a massive RPG such as this? Anyways, besides from the graphics and quests, my favourite part of this game has always been the modding community and also being a part of it.My days began way back when I was 12/13 so a good 6 years ago, when I discovered mods and how awesome they were. Graphics were always an important thing in mind so mods such as Qarls Texture Pack 3 (the best one at the time and still is I believe) was an amazing thing to have. All the small mods, such as keychains, graphics, sound overhauls, OPEN CITIES etc were what made this game, and also the rest in the series truly amazing. Sure having a flying dragon or flying skyship was awesome, but it wasn't something you'd always be using and seeing. There were still many bugs in the later releases however an Unnofficial fix was released (many times) to fix what Bethesda could and did not. This helped greatly with smooth gameplay and to fix errors.I haven't covered nearly 5% of what I wanted to type as this game is just truly amazing and my favourite in The Elder Scrolls. Check out PlanetElderscrolls and The Nexus for mods and make sure you know what you're doing by reading the Readme files and guides.If you have only played Skyrim, you probably won't like Oblivion that much because everything isn't as 'immersive' graphics wise, but to us who started here, I think we can agree that the Replay Value outnumbers Skyrim's.

er 1, 2016
To this day, I still think Oblivion is the best Elder Scrolls game thus far.Yes, I've spent over one houe playing the PC version, but I've spent hundreds of hours playing the 360 version.However, this game is quite old, so while the graphics aren't terrible, your experience with this game would be ten times better with a few graphical enhancements.Graphics aside, the core plot is one full of mystery, adventure and sometimes shock. The side-quests (There are probably over one hundred of them) are quirky and range from being pretty short, to really long and complex.The environment, like many RPG games, can be repetitive and sometimes quite boring, however, this is countered with multiple buildings/shrines/portals scattered throughout.The alchemy system is, in my opinion, far more easier to learn and more rewarding to use than any other elder scrolls game. Not surprisingly, more complex potions can be made with a higher alchemy level.Unlike Skyrim, you don't "wield" spells, that is, you can walk around with a sword and still a spell equipped without any compromise.I recommend this game to those who are looking for some nostalgia.I recommend this game to newer players who don't mind installing some graphics mods.

												In Skyrim, if you use magic, all you need is Destruction Dual Casting, Impact, and four enchanted items to hit end game. In Oblivion, even the most cheap and knowledgable player who utilizes power leveling and walkthroughs to get the best gear/spells at the fastest rate possible will still experience a sense of progression and improvement far into the highest character levels.The musical score is god tier.Although repetitive, the voice acting is pleasant and cohesive (if you don't listen to the beggars).The environments are colorful and interesting, whereas Skyrim's world could have been created by a three year old with a pair of grey and white markers.If you like RPGs, Oblivion is a must.

ry 4
												In my Opinion Oblivion is still better than Skyrim. The story and the Quests are waaay better. Just as an example: Skyrim Magic University Mission is quickly over, and the uni itself doesn't even feel like a place people study. In Oblivion the questline is really long spread out over all major cities and the university is a giant place with the feel of an acutal university. And where as the ending of Skyrim is kinda meh (you fight a dragon, so what? You did that the entire game) The Ending in Oblivion is epic and memorable.Also Oblivion has the best expansion ever made aka shivering Isles.That is not to say Oblivion doesn't have its flaws. The major gripe I have with this game is the leveling system. It is really easy to "misslevel" you character, making it weaker the higer level you get. Leveling is almost stressful. You have to grind 5 levels per attribute or else you are missing out on stats. It is even benificial to only level up skills that are not your main skills as that makes you deal way more damage than you should have per level.

content:
r 22, 2016
												This being one of the first RPG i ever played, it blew me away. This game is just so well put together that it leaves me to want a remaster or something of the sort. However, the game isnt without its flaws. Specifically, the combat can seem dull and repetitive if you play it with an aggro mindset, not bothering to avoid attacks and spam health potions. Another flaw for me personally is the difficulty setting. Finding the perfect sweetspot varies from character to character. Enemies will either become total wimps getting one shot by any attack or be absolute tanks that drain your resources to nothing. What i would more prefer is something along the lines of fallout 4's survival mode damage, where you and enemies both have increased killing potential. That aside, this game has characteristics that far outweigh the cons. My personal favorite being the music. This game's soundtrack, in my honest opinion, is amazing. I feel myself getting lost in the harps, flutes, and violins when wandering the various cities. Ominous music kicking in when i enter an unexplored cave. But who could forget the epic tones of the games title screen. Another great thing about this game are the secrets hidden throughout the landscape. Perhaps a bow or chest that you would have never stumbled upon in a first playthrough. Another topic i wanted to touch on is how you play this game. If you are the type of person that loves getting to the end fast and wants instant gratification, maybe this isnt your game. I think you have to be the observant type, listen to the dialogue, read the books, dont rush through every quest like you are in a hurry like so many others do. You miss out on the little nuances the game so delicately hides. You can appreciate the game on another level. Though this game is very outdated, i feel it gives the game a certain charm that few others have. It was the RPG that paved the way for future games of its genre, and look where we are now. These are just my thoughts on the game, the may not be true or subjective, but i hope i can convince someone to experience this game the way i have. Much love and thank you for reading.

content:
, 2015
												Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion is a gem within the Elder Scroll series.What was good about Morrowind was brought over to this 4th installment of the series, and of course, what was bad. Was either taken out, or refined and polish for a much smoother experience.This game is huge, then what the game let's on. From quests just about almost everywhere you go. With impress lore and backstory. Not to mention the various challenges in these dark and creepy dungeons. Another great thing about Oblivion is it's class system. Unlike in Skyrim where you play as you want. Here you play based on a set of class. And therefore the game experience for you could either be hard or easy, Depending upon what class you play as. To add on the 500+ in Oblivion you got a stable (still active) modding community plus DLC quests like Knights of Nine and Shivering Isles. Which that place adds even MORE hours into Oblivion.  To add on this amazing experience is these beautiful towns and cities filled with the sam- der i mean different variety of characters each one having their own set schedule, personal opinon, and even the way they see you (through fame or infamy status) the world is very active around you within this game. There are at least two negatives about this game, that i can point out.1. NPC's are literally forgettable, this being the reason why Skyrim's NPCs are vastly superior than Oblivion's NPCs, and more flexiable than Morrowind's NPCs. The Oblivion character models are literally the same, except with a few minor face tweaks with the hair, nose, eye color and so on. Plus with the same voice acting it doesn't really help who is who in the world.2. Combat is sluggish, Yes. Even though it's a class based system. It will take a while, a long while before finding the right tune for your character to even remotely survive in the combat. Really it's just: block, lung, block, fire a spell, block. Rinse and repeat. Sometimes you are on the defensive the entire time or not even bothering going through that dungeon and just drinking buffer poitions outside the dungeon. Can you say it's because of the player level..perhaps. But even then the combat is still sub-par.If you love a cross between Morrowind and Skyrim. I highly recommend getting this game. This is the one to have in your RPG collection.

content:
er 15, 2013
												Fantastic game! Oblivion is one of those games that only comes from time to time, just imagine how much the developers put into this game, time, ideas , money. Thank you Bethesda! I confess it was the first game in the Elder Scrolls series I played, so I can not compare to Morrowind, and Skyrim I barely played, then I'll make a review based solely on impressions of the game.It took a while until I get to continue on a character and finish the main quest, the game requires dedication, Cyrodill world is vast , the possibilities in a TES game well, you need to explore,  learn about, otherwise you will getting lost as I did several times and so I abandoned the progress with other characters.The wealth of detail is impressive, the plot of the main quest not, but everything else makes up for this fact, the quests are very well written, some are so smart that I was surprised. The possibilities are endless too, this is a true Role Playing Game, you can make a character and be what you want from a killer thief going through a heroic warrior to a simple traveling merchant, or all together.The graphics are outdated and mechanics are strange at first sight, especially the combat and movement, and the animation of NPCs give the impression that they do not have emotions. Despite this the game is still very good, the graphics can be improved with mods, you get used to the mechanics and also the sound effects are well done. The community is huge and active, there are thousands of fan-made mods that help solve problems, improve gameplay, graphics and add content that make it practically a new game.I highly recommend it, but as said, you need to devote to it, it takes a while to get a feel and learn how the gameplay works, how the skill system and leveling for example. But there are wikis for it with everything you can know about TES: Oblivion, I recommend consulting to aid, but being careful with spoilers, of course.9/10
