content:
27, 2015
												Fresh off the boat from Vvardenfell, I was hard on Oblivion early on. It's appropriate to compare the two games, but not as closely as I did. And while I still got far more hours and enjoyment out of Morrowind, there was a depth of charm to its successor that I had long overlooked.On a technical level, I find little opposition that Oblivion broke new ground in making such a big world function as well as it did. The employment of Bethesda's new "Radiant AI" served as a welcome relief to the NPCs of Morrowind, whose highlight of day-to-day activity was walking twenty steps to the left. While there were aspects of this innovation that Skyrim would later improve upon, it was awesome to see the people around me wake up, go to work, go to the tavern, go hunting, eat, sleep, pray. Population centers felt alive and I started to feel the community instead of trusting that it was there.Voice acting was another... "improvement." You didn't have to read large blocks of text anymore because God forbid. Bethesda boasted that dialogue took up half of the game's data with over two full days of voice recording.When I first learned this, I felt reluctant. I feared that no matter how much voice acting one is willing to pack onto a DVD, there isn't enough time or money to capture the alluring exposition of Morrowind, the details of the relationships and backstories; no voice actor Bethesda got their hands on could hope to capture what I imagined when I spoke to a Telvanni lord.Well, I was right. Long, detailed information was butchered, mainstreamed. There were hardly any topics to discuss, and I didn't feel like I could have a true conversation with anyone the game didn't deem important enough. Talking to a random bystander about their trade not only developed a character, but the world. I didn't have that anymore. Every gender of each race (for the most part) had not only the same voice, but the same speech. It was almost silly. With the big step forward in immersion with Radiant AI and voice acting, it was a shame to take such a step back in what was perhaps my favorite aspect of Oblivion's predecessor.I also had mixed feelings about the induction of fast travel. I let it go; if I wanted the immersion, I could always refuse it (even though I knew any such commitments wouldn't last). Looking on the bright side, I could enjoy completing quests and keeping the story going. Returning instantly to the doorstep of my favorite places would help me savor and rediscover them, when before I might have put it off for dread of the trek until I was too powerful to care. So, while I will always appreciate the punishing journeys of Morowind, I suppose I can mark fast travel as a net positive.And they finally added horses to make travelling faster!Um... okay. Maybe they would provide some other combat or burden benefit?No. Not really. So, uh... moving on.The graphics are beautiful. Stunning. I was impulsively critical of the "normality" of the setting compared to Vvardenfell. Yes, Cyrodiil is more familiar, but in hindsight I don't see why I should have trouble accepting that this particular part of a much larger and dynamic fantasy world is simply inspired by Medieval Europe like many other works of fantasy whose familiarity I forgave, even welcomed. Maybe it's because I expect more from a game, maybe it's because the story left me wanting (which it did, but it's not that simple--- more on that shortly). The vistas of Cyrodiil ran unrivalled in gaming at the time, and few with today's technology can match its brilliance, especially when considering how interactive and detailed every yard of it is. Now, Dagon's plane of Oblivion, for which the game is named, that's where I stop defending the lack of inovation: classic Dante. And Daedric architecture was, altogether now, far more intriguing in Morrowind.Just as Oblivions's landscapes hold up today, the general facial designs of NPCs were subpar even then (aside from the beast folk, but then I resented that they were streamlined to equip footwear).But where did Oblivion shine? Where did Oblivion not only stand up to Morrowind but arguably surpass it?The faction questlines.The main questline was not very interesting (still blows away Skyrim), though it managed to turn out a few likeable characters (Baurus, Martin, uh... Jauffre was okay, I guess). But the faction quests were truly the greatest strength of a solid game. Morrowind's were less linear, giving players the choice of advancing through work in different parts of the map (the superior concept, in my opinion); Oblivion allowed a single path, but not only provided a heavier narrative, they gave the feeling that you were part of something. Both systems have their strengths and weaknesses, but Oblivion's Mages Guild combined the two...You had to impress the leader of each installment of the Mage's Guild, each with their own personality, style, and agenda, much like Morrowind. Once they are in agreement, you're rewarded with access to the previously locked mechanic of magic-making and enchanting in a place that felt like a functioning school. There, you work your way from grunt to archmage in a series of quests that begin benign but gradually rise in importance to the finale. Was it perfect? No. But the structure and pacing brought the experience to life for me. I enjoyed every quest.In terms of story, the best of Oblivion (and the series as of Skyrim) was the Dark Brotherhood. The characters, the atmosphere, the plot and the individual quests were beautiful. Sometimes it felt like a different game entirely. I'll never forget when it was all coming to a head, I stepped out of a lighthouse and the brutal, depressing scene it housed, and spent a quiet moment watching the sun break the horizon over the sea, uncertain of the future. It was magnificent.The Thieves' Guild came close to the mages guild in terms of structure, and close to the Dark Brotherhood in terms of story: a well-balanced and enjoyable adventure.Oblivion's factions set the bar, and I couldn't wait to see what Skyrim... well, we'll get to that another time.Finally, on to combat. Yes, it's more fun to swing a sword when the sword is going to hit its target, and the employment of modern physics made it satisfying to knock your enemy over a table with a deathblow to the face. What's more, Oblivion did what I would have sworn was impossible: it made magic even more useless than it was in Morrowind (at least then you could cast offensive spells through items--- laughably overpowered, but I loved it).When Bethesda made Oblivion, they set out to build a whole new game from the ground up. As to be expected, there were changes that I liked, changes that I didn't. Did Oblivion stand up to Morrowind? I think not, but given the style of its development, it didn't have to. I can't help but respect Bethesda's willingness to drop all their assets and start anew. While Oblivion belongs to a series, it belongs to its own part of the series, just as Cyrodiil itself lies as its own little world in widely-varied Tamriel, and in ways neither can nor should be compared to the others.In the end, we need to be realistic: how many games lie outside Bethesda's world so big, where no matter which road you choose, whether you take a road at all, you know you're going to find something worth seeing? That is the marvel of Bethesda, the greatest RPG developer there is.

content:
8, 2016
												'The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion' is one of my  favorites games and played this game way back in middle school. Coming from 'Morrowind' this game is a vast improvement in nearly every aspect. Morrowind is my personal favorite amongst the franchise, however, I'm not going to deny that Oblivion is an amazing game in nearly every aspect. Coming from Morrowind, this game blew me away back then since it vastly improved the visuals considering the dead and volcanic region of Morrowind is really contrasted with the bright and colorful vibrancy of Cyrodill. The whole game is alost like a painting since it embodies the typical fantasy aspect of Role-playing games since it's so bright, colorful, but has its dark corners that just beg to be explored. In terms of content, this is packed with several places to explore, all the guilds you are already familiar with if you're coming from 'Skyrim' (e.g.; Dark Brotherhood, Thieves Guild, Fighter's Guild, and Mage's Guild). With that said, Oblvion's flaw with exploring ruins is that the ruins are practically copy-and-pasted. You explore caves and ruins throughout the map of Oblivion, however, they all seem to be very similar in style to the point where you feel you're exploring the same ruins. I remember it was a bragging point from Bethesda prior to Skyrim's release that every dungeon was hand-crafted, meaning that no two places were the same. Although, if you're new to Oblivion, I believe you'll be enamored with the content of Oblivion that you'll always be entertained. Whether it be side-quests, guild quests, you'll be too busy having fun to notice this flaw until dozens of hours into it.Another preference I have for this game is that the aforementioned praise of Oblivion's vivid world also contrasts it from Skyrim since Skyrim is supposed to be more dark and appears to have a gray filter slapped on it. This game feels more alive in that sense, but it's all in preference since skyrim is practically the land of vikings and mountains so each Elder Scrolls game has appropriate tone to its environment. Furthermore, I much prefer the combat in Oblivion since I love the physics in this game. Seriously, you can shoot someone with an arrow and they'll do a backflip before they ragdoll to the floor. It's awesome. In Skyrim, it's meant to be more realistic so they improved the physics so that they fall more realistically and they even added dual-wielding which was a big added feature. This game lacks dual-wielding, so if you're looking forward to that, sorry bud. On the bright side, the combat is much better to that of Morrowind's since they got rid of the "dice roll" mechanic where you would miss despite them being right in front of your face.

content:
, 2012
I saw a mudcrab the other day.Also N.B. I am not necessarily a fan of Role Playing Games.The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion is Bethesda Softworks' blockbuster and hugely popular open world lite role playing game, set in the medieval fantasy world of Cyrodiil.The gist of the main storyline is that the Emperor, Tiber Septim, is assassinated literally 10 minutes into the game by a cult worshipping Mehrunes Dagon, who aims to invade the mortal realm and ask the kitchen sink of humans, ogres, dwarves, elves and assorted petting zoo people, to submit to literal hell. Following your convenient escape from the Imperial Prison, you play tennis with the required artifacts with this cult and the Daedra, and your goal is to restore stability to this world.It's a 2006 game, and for its time I will admit, it looks decent. From a technical standpoint in particular, the real time shadows are remarkable, while artistically, the bloom post processing works rather well to give a fairy tale feeling. Unfortunately, the big graphical offenders are the crude animations and the character faces, good god.Voice acting is hit or miss, usually miss. The spoken voice lines often sound different between one another and there's no consistent tone. It feels like about 10 people total voiced every single character in this game. The rest of the sound design is just about average, with other small blemishes.Gameplay is where the big problems arise. Improving your skills is done by performing the feats associated with said skill: Armorer is increased by repairing weapons and armour, while Destruction governs use of offense magic spells. You have 7 Major Skills personally assigned at the start of the game, and increasing these skills by 10 points across the board will allow you to level up the next time you sleep, after which you decide which of your main Attributes you want to increase. In theory, sounds good. In practice, the existence of level scaling enemies means that, in the game's vanilla state, you have two practical choices: get your pen and paper out and keep track of exactly which Skills you have improved, to maximise your Attribute gains at the next level up, or outright skip levelling up and fight, loot or interact with whatever using just your beefed up skills. Attribute level up bonuses scale with how much you've improved your skills, so you can end up overlevelled and underskilled, and mincemeat for the other baddies in the game unless you either mod the game, keep track of your skills in a manner that defies roleplay, or outright skip levelling up, also defying roleplay. It is probably the worst levelling system I've seen, where unless you play in a specific way, you won't stand much chance against future game challenges without lowering the difficulty.The world is fairly large and stocked with places to venture into, and side quests to complete. For the most part, they're passable, they give me, an action guy, a chance to mash and bash things into pulp. The stealth system is fairly robust, though it gets ridiculous later on where a skill in the high 70s and a ring of 20% Chameleon will make you literally invisible to certain enemies, even as you push them around. MagicMagicka is an important asset to most every creature capable of casting it, with a variety of effects ranging from standard fireballs, lightning strikes, frost attacks, heals and buffs, to summoning minions to fight alongside you, granting water breathing or water walking, and even skipping the lockpicking and persuasion minigames. The lore is huuuuge, as kind of expected from a series apparently spanning 10 years from this game's launch. I'm sure avid followers of the lore will find every little error in continuity to nitpick on, but I'm personally rather impressed on the number of unique NPCs, lore books and other fluff to make it feel like a lively place. If anything, this does it better than stiff, robotic NPCs doing the same routine every day, but that one's partially excused because otherwise quests would be way harder to complete.The base game might be a mixed bag, but mods most certainly make it much more bearable, and much more fun. The modding community is incredibly devoted still to this 10+ year old game, continuously putting out updated graphics mods, a more modern and conventional levelling system done via quest completion, rebalances, new magic spells and weapons, new creatures, and even riding a Nine Divines damned dragon.The basic storyline with minimal sidequesting will last about 20 hours, but finding everything will take you way, way longer. It's kind of addicting, and it's got its own charm.If it's cheap enough and/or you're an RPG-lite fan, this is worth a play, most certainly. For everyone else, mods are your allies, and you should still give it a whip.

content:
27, 2014
												Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion is one of those games where you can fully immerse yourself within it's environment and society. The world (called Cyrodiil)  has multiple regions of landscape, all giving you a taste of wildlife and roleplaying elements, like old, swampy caves or a great fort in the uplands of Colovia. Everywhere you go you can interact with the environment, from plants and mushrooms to animals and NPCs.When you open the grate out of the sewer for the first time you realise the immense beauty of lake rumare, but thats the tip of the iceberg. You could if you wish, follow the main quest, and complete it how the developers thought it would be like. Or you can find your own path venture into an unknown cave, or explore the Imperial City's marketplace and see what it has to offer.The game has oppertunities to be each class as you will, and a race to go along with it. You could be a High Elf Mage, the Arch-Mage of the Arcane University, or a Nordic Warrior, leader of the Fighters guild. There is a great range of quests to complete and level up your character. You may want to find certain items and loot dungeons to find them, while selling what else you find.The Shivering Isle DLC, lets Sheogorath the Daedric Prince of Madness invite you to his realm, where everything is run a whole lot differently. The Knights of Nine DLC sends you on an epic quest, to defeat Umaril, who threatens Cyrodiil, while worshipping the Nine Divines. Depending on which pack you brought, one edition will come with four DLC houses, each with their own quest, and some other miscellaneous DLC.So go explore Cyrodiil in all its glory. Be a Warrior, or a Thief, or a Mage or even all of them together! Thats the thing with Oblivion, its an inviting world at your fingertips that will never get old.However they could patch up on the Havok Physics a bit.

content:
ber 11, 2014
												Oblivion is the sequal to the critically acclaimed TES 3 Morrowind, and predessessor to the well-known Skyrim (TES 5). This time it is set in Cyrodiil, the Imperial Province of lush forests, snowy mountain caps and dark swamps, all to be explored at will. There are nine major cities, Anvil, Kvatch, Skingrad, Chorral, Bravil, Leyawin, Bruma, Cheydinhal and the Imperial City, plus many other minor settlements, temples, farms etc. Right at after character creation, you are taken by the Emporers guards on an escape from the palace dungeons, before he tasks you with delivering the Amulet of Kings and shutting closed the jaws of Oblivion. From then on you have the entire province to explore at your own will. You can join guilds such as the fighters guild, basically the legal vigilanties of Tamriel, the mages guild, who are basically the wizards of the empire, the thieves guild, which is an illegal guild of robbers and thieves, the dark brotherhood, who are the spiritual assassins who worship Sithis and the Night Mother, and the Arena, which is pretty self explanetory.A good understanding of TES lore is recommended, and will always make the game feel more real. I recommend this series to bring you up to speed. https://www.youtube.com/user/ShoddyCast It will inform you on the many races, religions, provinces and more that exist on Nirn (It also explains what Nirn is). Or you could read the many ingame books as an alternative.The only downsides I can think of is the chat system, which is a little outdated, and the stupid essential NPCs. Unforunatly they removed Morrowinds 'you can kill anyone, as long as you can deal with the consequences' system in favor of appeal to casual gamers. These don't damage the overall game too much, however.9.1/10

content:
ry 9, 2015
												Say what you will about the repetitive oblivion gates and the potato face character models, this game is a triumph in open-world gaming.  Radiant AI makes the game feel much more alive than previous Elder Scrolls installments.  The Dark Brotherhood faction remains the single most intruiging questline I have ever played in a game.  You will hear npcs telling rumors of events that you yourself participated in, making you feel that your actions have had some impact in the world.    The Shivering Isles expansion that comes with this game is probably the best DLC I have ever played.  It is arguably a tighter experience than the base game.  Morrowind fans will likely experience a bit of nostalgia from the alien landscapes featured.  This game's only real problem is that everything that it tries to do doesn't always work as intended.  This is most obvious with how npcs interact both with you, and with each other.  You can have a perfectly pleasant conversation with an npc, only for him to tell you to shut up and leave him alone when you say your goodbyes.  While this is oftentimes comical, it is also immersion breaking, which is a bit hit for a game whose biggest draw is making you feel like an inhabitant in a living world.  Also, dungeons can feel a little repetitive, as designs are often reused.  It's hard to have every dungeon feel unique when there are so many of them in the game, but I would still expect a bit more variety than what we got.  I wholeheartedly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys rpgs or open world games.  The amount of solid content you're getting for 20 dollars or less is incredible, and should not be passed up.

content:
y 11
												Fantastic game and a masterpiece. While some of the voice acting and graphics are bad and outdated, the storytelling and the gameplay bring out the brilliance of this game. The lore of this game brings you into it's world and makes you feel as the adventurer you are playing as. Gameplay is well engaging except for some problems that affects leveling and monster scaling. Monster scaling was not implemented well, I personally had no problems with it but I know of past horror stories of "facing certain monsters is hard" or "the monsters were too easy once I started leveling". Certain scaling elements slow down the battling but not much that causes this game to be unplayable.The main story writing is great as it shows how you are not the main character but as the catalyst that brings the Oblivion Crisis forward. Each of the Guild's storytelling try it's best to make you a part of the guild. Each guild has different strengths and helps raise your character for leadership. Each of the DLC's has the Bethesda touch to them. A couple masterful story-based DLC and immersion DLC. A lot of people could argue that the Shivering Ilses DLC is better than the base game. Each character has their own backstory and motavation that is found out. Dialogue in-game is some of the best writing in any game. Sadly some characters lose their impact because of the voice direction choice, of each race having the same voice character with not many pitch or tone changes. But several characters stand out. The skill and attribute system is somewhat towards the classic RPG feel and actually effects your character in-game. Animations in the game are not super diversed but is immersive. After puttting in a lifetime of hours in Oblivion in all platforms PC is the ultimate tier of playing this game. Not only does PC help strenghten what consoles failed to work with being on PC offers mods. Mods also offer ways to fix the usually Bethesda glitches and mechanics. Mods have been made for more than 7 years now and is still being made today. Any RPG fan should definitely play this game and live through it's worlds.I could just sit here and tell you what Oblivion did better than Skyrim or Morrowind or tell you what Skyrim or Morrowind did better than Oblivion. But there is no reason, they might be continuations in the series and its lore but each game should be measured by themselves rather than the other games in the series.

content:
er 2, 2014
												The Elder Scrolls IV is a game that is munch between The Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind's gaming legacy and the extremely popular Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim. Many people would ask, Should I get (or still get) the Elder Scrolls IV? Of course. Oblivion is well known for its scenery, extensive side questlines, and a remarkable story. The game has aged and its skill system will make newcomers rage (the skill system is mediocre at best, but it not really good). Oblivion was one of the first role-playing game that I've purchased for the Xbox 360 back in 2006. The game was really popular back then with so much things to do. Spend hours exploring caves and dungeons. Become the Grand Champion in the Imperial Arena. Become the Grandmaster for the Mages Guild, the Leader of the Fighters Guild, the Master of Thieves for the Thieves Guild. Each character you encounter would have a unique personality and would have a quest for you to do. The soundtrack for the game is absolutely the best and it would make you just sit and relax just to listen. There are varieties of environments in the game, ranging from the spring-like setting, the pouring rain in the southern side of the map, to the blistering cold in Northern Cyrodiil. If the setting of Skyim makes you a bit..."dull" (meaning that you are tired of playing  the dominated wintery and snowy map of Skyrim), you can come back to Oblivion where all kinds of weather is featured in one game. Like other Elder Scrolls games, Oblivion should be in your gaming library. For gamers that had played Oblivion before, its time to return to Cyrodiil.

content:
ry 7, 2015
												I only have three hours clocked in on Steam, but on the 360, I've probably spent hundreds of hours of my freshman year in high school walking against a wall to build up my sneak skill.Oblivion was my gateway back into the world of RPG's after I had strayed off into the void of CoD and similar titles. A friend of my older brother had let us borrow a handful of games for the 360, and this was one of them. While my brother didn't touch it, I took the leap and tried it out. It was love at first sight.And I'm 99% sure that I never gave it back to the guy.Anyways, everyone looking at this game is probably comparing it against Skyrim: which should I buy? My answer is definitely both, they're both worth the money. I've literally bought both of these games twice, putting my investment into these games close to 200 bucks, and I don't regret it, not even a little bit, but if you have to choose between one or the other, here are the pro's and con's for both games.Oblivion:+Hundreds of hours of gameplay+Highly replayable+Great character customization+Great storyline+Great not-storyline, seriously, just wander into some town and you can    go days before you remember that the world is in chaos+I personally like the alchemy and speech functions in this game, but I    know some don't+Spell crafting, OMG!!!!-Graphics are now dated-On Steam, there is no controller interface :-(-No dual-wieldingSkyrim+Hundreds of hours of gameplay+Highly replayable+Great character customization+Great storyline+Great not-storyline, same as above+Dual wielding+DRAGONS!!!+Very deep-running political agendas in-game+SMITHING-Shouts are lame, I think :-p-Not as much weapon or spell variety as Oblivion-Graphics are better than Oblivion, but some things are just ehh-Landscape isn't nearly as pretty as in OblivionAll the negatives are purely from nit-picking, there is absolutely nothing about these games that I'd consider as being "deal breakers". Buy. Play. Devote your life to Talos today!

content:
r 4, 2014
												I cannot even begin to explain the massiveness of this game.  Very much like Skyrim it is completely open world, RPG brilliance.  From the very start the choices you make, and quests you complete start to define your character for the hero they will become.  Right off the bat i am going to give this game a 9/10.Story:  Oblivions story is centralized around the idea that Tamriel is in chaos because the emperor was mmurdered, and without a new emperor to light the dragonfires cyrodill will fall into darkness.  In addition to this massive panic towards the death of the emperor, Oblivion gates (Virtually gates to hell) start opening up all across the province.  It is your job to go in and destroy these gates, and crown the new emperor for Cyrodill.Factions:  I have to say that this is possibly one of the best faction systems in any game.  contrasted only by Skyrim.  The way it is set up allows for multiple factions at once, and allow you to become the almighty ruler of them all.  The factions are: Mages Guild, Fighters Guild, Dark Brotherhood, Thieves Guild, and The Arena, other lower end factions also exist but these are the ones with the most quests involved.  Each of these has a seperate unique storyline that from time to time will also cross into other factions.  Quite revelating.Visual Appeal:  My computer has an I5 processor and was able to handle almost everything on completely high res (with the exception of shadows and sometimes water), but with that in mind, and the fact that this game was released in 2006...8 YEARS OLD, its still incredibly beautiful!!  The view of the landscape that tranistions from Grasslands, to forests, to the jerall mountains, to the swampy regions of Leyawiin...Takes my breath away.  Though other Elder Scrolls games primarily focused on one regions appeal, morrowind to swamp, and skyrim more to snow, this game perfectly incorporated all regions as it was central bound.Gameplay:  This games main focus revolves around classes that fight in unique way, while also simaltaneously questing.  These mechanics are very strikingly similar to the Legend of Zelda, and if you have ever played a Zelda game, you know perfectly well how exquisetly it accomplishes this.  There are three basic classes, warrior, mage, and thief.  All three of these have their attriubtes, but the remarkable thing about this game is that you can freely choose what you want!  Though choosing your base class at the beginning with determine what skills you are more adept at, you are still able to combine any skills with any other skills.  If you want to be a battleaxe wielding, light armored elf with excellent conjuration skills. You are able to do that no problem.  This system allows you to perfectly mould out your character to what you feel would suit you best.Quests:  If you do somehow manage to beat all quests in the game, then sir i owe you a gold medal.  If i recall correctly i believe there are around 500 quests in the game to do.  Which some can be completed by simply delivering a package, while others like the main quest will make you toy around for 10 hours before being completed.  The multitude of quests in this game is astounding, and will have your interest hooked for the long haul.Final Impressions:  Oblivion is by far my favorite fantasy game of all time let alone my actual favorite game of all time.  I personally own about 5 different versions of the game because of my love for it.  Though it says on my steam profile i only have 9 hours on PC, i had approximately 50 hours on my other steam account, and on xbox...i would be baffled if it said anything less than 600.  This game has a deep connection with me because of Bethesdas brilliance to bring forth such a revolutionary game such as this one.  Even if this genre is something you cant see yourself getting into, i challenge you to play at least the tutorial, join a single faction, and kill a baddie or two and tell me it hasnt captured your interest like it did mine.  In conclusion this is an amazing game and a must buy for every person who has steam.

content:
ry 12
												My local mall had a Gamestop that is now a fragrance store. One day little old me wonders into Gamestop to look at the new games they have and Oblivion catches my eye. “Huh, Elder Scrolls? What's that? The cover and screenshots on the back look cool” I said to myself before going to the register. It was sunny and I had a cut on my hand from my grandmas cat. It's weird how you remember stuff like that. I go home and install the game on my families computer in the living room and was hooked on just about everything about the game. The freedom of exploring, the locations you get to visit, the quest lines, everything just blended together so well to create an open world fantasy RPG. Sure there's dumb stuff like characters looking like potato sacks and there only being 3 voice actors and some bugs, but they all added to the charm of the game. Oblivion is probably my favorite game of all time for sentimental reasons. I played the hell out of it and want to introduce it to my nephews(who are already into games like Zelda) when they get a little older but until then I would wholeheartedly recommend Oblivion.

content:
er 22, 2013
												The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion is by no means an inferior product to the excellence that is Skyrim... In fact, Oblivion thrusts you into a completely unique and enjoyable setting with it's very own quirks and traits. Gameplay is the most simple out of the trifecta (Morrowind, Skyrim), but it's the visuals, the outstanding soundtrack, and the immersive, breathing, world which lend to the game it's very own flair - it's own brand of flavor, not any worse, and yet, not any better then it's respective "siblings". With it's very own memorable moments - and yes, it's glitches, Oblivion still manages to dole out an impressive array of content (yes, even the horse armour...). Overall, Oblivion stands tall in regards to the quality of the given product, and is a must have for any fan of the Elder Scrolls series.

content:
y 20, 2014
												I can still remember when I first got The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion. My older cousin was playing it, and after only 20 minutes of running around as his character, I was utterly hooked. I was about...16 years old? Perhaps younger?The game itself is, for it's time, revolutionary, and it pioneered an entirely new kind of open world RPG, with 'no' invicible walls except for the required ones to put a limit on the generated world. Other then that, every door, was accessible somehow, and every plot of land was reachable. There was not a direction you could not go in Oblivion, and as an RPG, that made it priceless.The game also hosts rather higher tier voice acting. For example, Patrick Stewart(Also famous for starring as Xavier in X-Men, and Captain Jean Luc Picard in Star Trek: The Next Generation), lays voice to the majestic Emperor Uriel Septim, whom you meet during the tutorial of the game.The game, for customization, offers an impressive array of possibilities, with multiple races, hair styles, and direct face molding sliders to make you look truly unique(Or outright silly). It also offers a believably long winded skill system that permits you to become more talented in certain professions and skills as you perform them.As with most Bethesda developped games, Oblivions Engine is uniquely compatible with 3rd party Modification software, allowing Mesh, Animation, and Scripting artists etc. to work almost entirely independantly in the game, limited only by the game's graphical capabilities, and their own imagination. The amount of modifications(Or mods) released for Oblivion, is vast, but has since been passed by its successor; The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim(I should mention that Oblivion by storyline standards, happens 400 years before Skyrim does, and takes place in the Tamrielian province of Cyrodil, the homeland of the Imperials)Some individuals will argue that Oblivion is unplayable without mods, but I must say, Oblivion is one of the only games released by Bethesda that is truly a remarkable, fulfilled, well thought out and extremely precisely and expertly executed video game that by no means requires mods to be playable.On a scale of 10 hearts? I give Oblivion an 8.5 hearts. The game's higher tier voice actors, coupled with its engaging story, and the impressive free roam oppertunity, the large cult following and the engaging, high quality modding community, this game is, in on itself, a culture, and I would dare to say that you cannot call yourself a gamer without having walked the adventure filled, dangerously beautiful landscapes of Tamriel, and its many unique provinces.

number of helpful: 9 of 13 people (69%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
6, 2015
Don't Miss This Post-Modern ClassicAlthough I may view other games as being objectively better, The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion is the single-player game I will always go back to. It is more than a game to me. I view it as true Post-Modern art and something of a lifestyle choice. Bethesda tried to recreate little parts of reality in the interactions between customized NPCs and their scheduled AI. They failed horribly and created instead listless deformed humanoids that lack the intelligence to do little more than bump into one another and echo the same conversation they heard from their previous collision. They lack the social awareness not to steal apples in front of a crowd of guards, nonchalantly stumble over corpses in the town square, or calmly approach a man wearing the recently murdered Emperor's robes.These NPCs do not resemble human beings at all, questionably apart from their character models. They are insane, compulsive, and often ghoulish creatures. (Searching through random NPC houses will commonly unearth dead bodies, Dread Father shrines, and other signs of repulsive activity.) It is inspiring in a way to see a thing so close yet so distant in reference to human society.Bethesda realized all of this in a moment of unbearably historic revelation and started work on the game that marks their Self-Actualization -- Shivering Isles. The people of Sheogorath's realm, the Shivering Isles, are each driven mad and suffer from individualistic fixations. Creating a society of manic and demented people is precisely what Bethesda was meant to do with their perfect skillset of brilliant writing, AI that requires specific targets and times, awkward animations, and ugly character models. Instead of accidently creating a weird RPG, they intentionally directed their labor to the highest-valued function. Shivering Isles is absolutely entertaining to explore as a result.As a whole, there is an impossible amount of content to experience. For nearly 10 years of consistent play, every new game has revealed new quests (some that don't appear in the journal) that I somehow missed. The quests are consistently hilarious and even have expanded my vocabulary. Exploring is vastly rewarding, as you can discover schedules, backgrounds, and dark secrets of NPCs. There are a fair amount of treasure and unique items hidden about the world, as well. (This contrasts with Skyrim's limited content that ends in repeating quests and NPCs that reveal all there is to know about themselves in 20 minutes of town dialogue.) The game is not without its problems. The dungeons are cookie-cutter and rumors are oft repeated. The combat is stupid, but if you are playing Oblivion for the combat...(LOL). The clothes and armor are not as pretty and differentiated as Morrowind's, but you can still make a few cute outfits. If any of Oblivion's shortcomings bother you that much, though, the modding community has more talent and creativity than the devs.I unfortunately lost my disc 1 while moving, so I repurchased Oblivion on Steam recently. This edition has no problems on my Windows 7 and comes with Shivering Isles and the objectively trash Knights of the Nine thing. (It's boring, has rewards that could only impress a lvl 10 and can be completed in one sitting.) That's fine, tho', because Shivering Isles alone is worth the MSRP of this product. Heck, even just the soundtrack is worth the MSRP.

content:
22, 2016
												Before I bought this through Steam, I spent thousands of hours playing it. I'm so glad it's available here. No more scratched discs. You can't go wrong with a title that inludes "The Elder Scrolls," well, unless they put "Online" after it, but that's another story. The Elder Scrolls games are deep, rich RPGs with so much to do you can get lost in them for weeks of real time and forget the outside world exists. I find myself using terms and quotes from this game when I am forced into real life, hoping, desperately to find others like myself. If you do something to anger me? "Hope you rot, criminal scum!"There was a girl who suggested I play the previous Elder Scrolls game. She gave me a wonderful gift. I forget her name. I forget everything that happend after I got it installed. "Another satisfied customer."This is a true roleplaying game in that it lets you be whomever you wish, advance in whatever skills you like and live however you want. Go play the main quest, help the people out or just ignore all that and explore, find your own path. No one is going to force you to save the empire. Don't want to be a grand hero? Fine. How about becoming a thief instead? Perhaps you'd like to gather exotic ingredients and make powerful potions to try on people or even sell. Become a master mage or a truly accomplished assasin. Either way, make your mother proud. There's so much content I am incapable of writing intelligibly about it (or some would claim anything else). There are many races of people and humaoid creatures you can play. There's a full political game, crime awarness and punishment, people to impress or alienate, and a kingdom to save or doom. I'm sure others have written about all that. If you haven't guessed, I'm a fan, big-time. This is perhaps the best money I ever spent on Steam. I mean, if I calculate what i spent on every edition I have ever owned and divide by the number of enchanted hours I played, it would come down to less than a penny an hour to be absolutely delighted. Did I mention I like the game? The selection of weapons, armor, people, places and things to do is dizzying. As I said, I've played it thousands of hours before I bought it on Steam and I've never felt I've explored the entire game. I would MUCH rather go back and play it some more than write a decent review of it. There are currently 27,787 user-created MODs for this game on just one website, adding even more to the game. This makes the game infinately replayable. It also means a LOT of other people love it so much they made their own stuff to place in the game. Adding MODs to this game is very easy and extremely fun. I saw something about dated graphics, but here's where it gets good. There is a HUGE modding community that has not only added characters, quests, locations, and everything else conceivable to the game, but they have visual and sound creations to bring the dated game to modern standards.  I am delighted to announce that this game runs better than ever in 2016 in Windows 10. You can make it look and sound more wonderful than when it first shipped, back when it enslaved us in the greatest addiction of our lives. Okay, so I started the game in a dank, stinking prison cell. Wait. I thought this was supposed to be a fantasy. I don't like it when games are TOO close to real life.....

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
30, 2016
												I'm going to start off this review by saying that I've played this game from a disc since the year it came out (so pretty much for ten years lol)  and only recently got the steam version, so I would say I have 2000 hours + on this game. So I know what I'm talking about when I talk about this game. Character Customization The customization is great and leaves you with infinite possibilities to making a character.There are 21 skills and 8 attributes in Oblivion, allowing you to customise a class and a birthsign to give boots to certain skills and aspects of your character.This brings me onto the  leveling system At the start (when you choose a class) you can choose seven skills to be your "Major skills". You will get a +20 boost in each one and you will level up these skills much faster.Also, upgrading these skills allows you to progress to your characters next level. You can now upgrade your attributes based on the skills you learn. Story/Quests This game is story rich and you will absolutely fall in love with it if you like RPGs.The main quest itself is epic and will take you a while to finish, But the game has SO much more than that (not to mention DLC).With 200 + unique quests it will take you years to fully complete this game and even when you have, there's always Knights of the Nine and the Shivering Isles which add so much more to the game. Graphics/Visuals Obviously this game is no match for Skyrim and GTA V but the graphics are amazing for 2006 standards, and are still alright for today's standards.This game looks great in terms of landscape, it's full of colour and very vibrant. (In my opinion it looks better than skyrim)But overall this game's graphics are pretty good and the general visuals of this game are very appealing, and you can run the game on a toaster. Soundtrack This game's soundtrack is one of the best out there IMO. The main theme of this song is instantly recognisable and very fitting to the story. (The opening cutscene still gives me chills when I first hear the main theme) Interface You can enter the main interface by hitting Tab. This contains your Inventory, Spell menu, Journal, Map and an overview of your skills. Each category is like a drop down menu, which is very easy to navigate. Modding Modifying this game is very easy and mods can easily be activated and deactivated in the launch menu. Some recommended mods:- Midas Magic- The Lost Spires- Cheidenhall Pet Shop- Rebuild Kvatch DLC Buying DLCs adds so much more to the game, though i would only recommend the Shivering Isles and maybe the Knights of the Nine.The Shivering Isles is like another entire game. It has a completely different world (you can easily travel between the two using a portal), it has new monsters, spells, and of course quests, with one main quest and several side quests.The Isles itself is a very interesting place with insteresting places and people, including Sheogorath, the Madgod, the insane ruler of the Isles.I would give TSI 9/10.The Knights of the Nine is pretty much just another main quest added to the game, and I'm not going to lie it's pretty fun. I would give it a 7.5/10 SUMMARY (THANKS FOR READING THIS FAR) This game is simply everythig you could ask for in an RPG. It's exciting, epic and just a great experience. A must-have for RPG or Bethesda fans.If you haven't played an RPG before this is a great place to start. With adjustable difficulty you can learn the game pretty easily.I would completely 100% recommend this to anyone. It's just an all-round good game. If you are buying it I would recommend the shivering Isles too, as it adds alot to the expeience. MY FINAL RATING TES IV (without DLC): 9/10WITH DLC: 10/10!!!Just... just buy this game

												This game embodies what every open world game should be, the ability to choose how much of the main story and which elements you want to follow. You could do a mix of main and side quests as I do on most of my playthroughs. Another option is to only pursue the main quest line, and then once that's finished, delve into the rest of the world. Or you could choose to ignore the main quest entirely and play 40+ hours of interesting side quests fleshing out the rich, beautiful world the characters inhabit and then come back to the main quest line only once you've explored the entire rest of the world.I would also suggest looking into mods once you've played through the game a time or two as this could add hundreds of hours of gameplay, scenery, and characters that are as good or better than the quality of the original game.(Although I'm new to this game on steam, I've played hundreds of hours on my original physical copy.)

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2014
												Oblivion is a great game with some large problems. It has good enough graphics and a good story, with well-done guild missions and beautiful cities. Oblivion also has one of my favorite soundtracks, with music style changing based on where you go or who you meet. There is a lot to explore, such as Shivering Isles, and even more with mods. These add up to create very memorable moments; however, like all games, there are problems. The outdoor areas in this game are usually extremely bland and boring, making exploration repetitive after a few hours. You will not see all the varied landscapes such as in Skyrim, each one hand-crafted and beautiful. The enemies level up as you do, so you will not find rewards by leveling up. When you are level 5, bandits may have weak armor and weapons; when you are level 20, they have tough armor and good weapons. You will find them in very formulated patterns, such as when you walk along a trail and see each enemy standing the same distance away from each other, each one standing motionless in the middle of the trail. This makes the game feel less realistic. That leads me to the game's biggest fault; the combat. Combat is literally bonkers compared to Skyrim. Enemies soak arrows and take hits like a sponge. In Skyrim, I could take down an enemy fairly quickly by sneaking behind them and slitting their throat, I could take someone down with a few arrows, and I could kill with a few hits of a sword. In Oblivion, I can recall shooting about ebony twenty arrows (at least) from an ebony bow into a bear until it finally died. It took about 15 ebony arrows from an ebony bow and 10 flare spells (very weak) to kill a bandit. However, it is easy to enjoy the game while acknowledging these faults. Don't think the bad outweighs the good, because it doesn't. Oblivion is a great game, and if it had a good leveling system, combat, and hand-crafted environments, it would be the best Elder Scrolls game.

content:
ry 26, 2016
												If you are planning to buy the game be sure to get the Oblivion GOTY deluxe edition to avoid the disappointing discovery that you missed out on some DLC. There is no legit way to upgrade from the 'normal' GOTY to the GOTY deluxe version besides buying the whole game a second time. As Todd Howard said in an interview about Oblivion: 'We made the game for hardware that doesn't exist.' Ten years after release that turns out to be a good thing. You can play Oblivion in 4k right out of the box and it looks pretty good with all settings on ultra high. If you invest a little time in modding the visuals are on par with Skyrim. Don't take complaints about the dated graphics to seriously as more often than not the underwhelming hardware is to blame.Like in the other games of the TES series you face a huge open world and the main quest being not stellar is not bad either.But the main quest is not what most players love to do in an Elder Scrolls game. It is the masterfully created living and breathing world with hundreds of side quests that keep you playing for hours and hours with always something new to do for you. And some of the quests are really memorable and I would go so far as to say the best in the franchise.The soundtrack by Jeremy Soule is spot on and one of the best you'll hear in any game. Shivering Isles is the best expansion I've ever played. See? I could go on and on. I should at least mention the massive content the modding community has contributed over the years. Giving you many more hours of enjoyment.All this can be yours for a few Septims - I mean €/$. You owe it to yourself to try it out if you are into RPGs. Oblivion is not a perfect game by any means - but it is very good and a technical masterpiece.

And I feel a little stupid, this game is just as perfect as Skyrim and I can't wait to relive the Elder Scolls again!If you are unsure about Elder Scolls and unsure if you'll enjoy something different, as I did ( I play games like GTA )... Give it a couple of hours and it'll grow on you and become one of your best games!Weirdly, I recommend this game! and I recommend the series too!10/10 - Nice work!

content:
ry 25, 2016
"This is the 27th of Last Seed; the year of Akatosh 433. These are the closing days of the Third Era and the final hours.. of my life."And so begins one of the most popular RPGs of all time. A fantastic example of what a modding community can accomplish, The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion has nearly unanimous love amongst the community, even after 10 years since its release. If you've played any of the Elder Scrolls before, from Arena all the way to Skyrim, then you'll probably already know what's in store but if you're new to the series, then you absolutely owe it to yourself to play this as soon as possible.Though still a flawed gem, this revolutionised the role-playing genre back in the day and marked the bittersweet end of the isometric days of Baldur's Gate and its ilk. A huge step up and a breath of fresh air in a saturated market, the success of Oblivion was primarily due to its ability to perfectly combine so many elements together while still producing a coherent, easily accessible and, above all, extremely enjoyable game."You. I've seen you before. Let me see your face. You are the one from my dreams. Then the stars were right and this is the day."Threatened by total annihilation from the other-worldly Daedra, you alone are tasked to stand against the horrors that continue to pour into the world and save Cyrodiil from those that seek to destroy it. Ultimately, the world's fate is in your hands to do with as you please.Personally featuring my favourite campaign of the TES series, the huge range of activities, quests, factions and general shenanigans you can get up to is remarkable. While the implicit morality system tends to favour reasonably good characters, the grand campaign and truly epic final battle more than makes up for it. There's little else that has come close to achieving the experience of that final battle in the Imperial City. Plus Jeremy Soule's superb soundtrack will have you engrossed all the way through. Good times. Technically, this game is a marvel and will run excellently on nearly all rigs.  Oblivion has certainly dated, that's for sure, and if you're more interested in more recent games, then please be warned because, yes.. even back in 2006, PC games were filled with atrocious console UIs. Thankfully, there are plenty of mods and unofficial patches available, as well as graphical overhauls and ENBs to bring it up to looking its true and (breath-taking) best. The "Bethesda bugs" and the amusing A.I. remain the same, but almost have a charm to them now and, though noticeable, don't detract from your experience.Gameplay is a mixed bag. For its time, it's great and offered a great depth and freedom to the various playstyles the open-world/blank slate roleplaying encourages. Simply put, this has some fantastic dungeons. Yet by today's standards, if you're playing this for the first time, it will most likely frustrate you with supposedly clunky and repetitive combat. It certainly can also take some time to adapt and navigate the menus and inventory system. Though you've probably been hounded to play this classic, if you don't enjoy this sort of thing, then I cannot recommend it. However, if you do consider yourself to enjoy the fantasy/RPG genre, then this is the essential addition to your collection. It doesn't matter whether The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion is better or worse, or more or less watered-down than Skyrim, Morrowind or even Online. At the end of the day, it simply is a great game in its own right. So what are you waiting for? Stop right there, criminal scum and hit play already.

content:
ry 26, 2016
												Oblivion is probably feeling a bit forlorn these days, with most of the hardcore crowd sticking to Morrowind and most of everyone else abandoning it for Skyrim. And it's no great mystery why this is the case, but I still think Oblivion is a game that shouldn't be overlooked, with the proper precautions taken.It's no secret that Oblivion is an RPG full of problems. The most grievous one in my opinion is the level scaling system, which scales basically everything in the game from dungeon loot and quest rewards to enemy equipment, gradually making the game more tedious as you level up until you finally find yourself face to face with a highway bandit who somehow found a full suit of Daedric armor and you just have to wonder where your decisions went so wrong that led you to this moment. The persuasion system is literally a joke, in which you just play a little wheel minigame where you dish out your best knock knock jokes (or boasts, if they're into that) until they have no choice but to tell you everything they know so that you'll leave them alone. I still don't know what the Speech stat even does, because as far as I'm aware you can start working on your standup routine fresh out of prison and never suffer any penalty. There's very little feeling of character specialization, and there's no reason at all to not be the leader of every guild in the game, the owner of your own order of knights, and more because even if you want to play the game as a stealthy archer or something the game all but forces you to become a combat focused character where your major choice boils down to "magic or hitting things" and there are no guilds that are strictly designed around a certain playstyle, making each of them less interesting for the people who did specialize towards one guild. The main storyline in general is fairly boring, and even the Shivering Isles expansion is fairly dull, to the point that I didn't even think that the collective content of it as a whole was as amusing as the single little Sheogorath quest in the base game.The good thing is that thanks to the magic of mods, most of Oblivion's faults can be fixed, and when you can play through the game without being constantly reminded of its flaws there's a lot to like, instead happily focusing on preventing the game from crashing whenever it feels like it. While it certainly has its fair share of tedious quests, Oblivion has a surprising amount of actually interesting content. I found myself enjoying more sidequests than not, and there are a few that are up there with my favorite quests in any RPG, like a certain Dark Brotherhood quest. Most of the "organized" quests like the guilds (for reference, play the Dark Brotherhood if you want to have fun, play the Thieves Guild if you want to pretend to have fun, play the Mages Guild if you hate fun, and play the Fighters Guild if you really hate goblins) and main story fall flat and feel like they build up too quickly for an ultimately weak payoff, but the real good stuff is in the one-shot stories you'll find in the towns and wilderness. Another perk of Oblivion is that it's home to the outstanding mod Nehrim: At Fate's Edge, which is a massive total-conversion mod that is arguably better than any of the Elder Scrolls games.Ultimately, Oblivion isn't an amazing game, but it can be pretty great or at least good after a bit of tweaking. As a special note, if you buy the deluxe edition I would personally recommend just disabling every minor DLC instead of bothering to grab all their unofficial patches, because as a whole I found them majorly disappointing in that almost all of them were just cheap excuses to get you things for free, like a house that has an ability that lets you skip one of the longest sidequests in the game or a house that has everything you could ever need for alchemy or any other of like 5 houses, quickly leaving you desperate for a quest that doesn't end with a deed to a mansion after being overloaded with a dozen quests you don't know the first thing about the moment you leave the prison. Even Knights of the Nine, the not-expansion expansion, is fairly short and not really interesting at all, unless you just think the armor reward looks cool. Ideally I'd recommend just not buying the deluxe edition at all, since the regular game of the year edition comes with the two worthwhile bits of content, but since there doesn't seem to be any way to buy the rest of the dlcs separate if you're a completionist you may as well jump for it. But overall I think Oblivion is definitely worth playing, especially since it goes on sale fairly often.

content:
ry 24
												Oblivion is the worst TES game ever. Then Skyrim came around and a good half of the TES community kinda changed its opinion. Turns out that Oblivion's actually a pretty good game.Almost as soon as you get out of the prison you realize just how different this game is compared to Morrowind. A lot of people hated this, but this is not actually a bad thing - even Morrowind kinda gets boring after a while, so a change in the setting keeps this game varied. Especially since Oblivion is good at doing what it tries to do, which is to be a game with a pretty comfy medieval fantasy atmosphere. However, it's mostly Jeremy Soule's soundtrack that does this because the game's graphics are incredibly lame and make this game look like the painting world from one of the sidequests. Speaking of sidequests, they're actually better than Morrowind's. They're a lot more interesting and a little bit more varied, so they almost become these short self-contained stories. I personally think that Oblivion has some of the best guild questlines in TES games ever. Dark Brotherhood is simply amazing and Thieves Guild was also pretty cool and Thief 1-like, with a really neat final quest to boot. Other guilds were not that great, sadly, because there was almost no improvement to the way quests are structured in this game. For some reason, Bethesda thinks it's really great to do this thing where they give the guild quests a storyline that becomes clearer the more quests you do, but then start throwing you off the trail by giving you lame tasks. I found the sidequests to be the real icing on the cake, because the main quest was pretty lame and brought nothing unique to the table. Overall, the base game is actually pretty good. Sure, some things got dumbed down compared to Morrowind, but it's also not cool to hate this game anymore, so there you go.Then Shivering Isles came out. "And, behold, it was very good". It almost feels like more effort was put into this expansion pack rather than into the ginormous base game. It was very interesting to be in this weird world, meet all those strange oddball characters who, this time around, had actually good and almost unique voiceovers, and do these bizzare quests. And, of course, who could forget Sheogorath? It's worth playing the expansion for the single purpose of hearing his amazing voiceover and reading his hilarious dialogue. Sadly, I can't say that all quests and sidequests in this expansion were great, but it's still worth to play Oblivion simply for Shivering Isles only. By the way, it's an actually good expansion pack done by Bethesda -  that's one for the books!Knights of the Nine is also supposed to be an important thing. However, it's not. It's painfully average and incredibly short. It's supposed to consist of 11 linear main quests, yet a good 60% of them can be done in a matter of 30 minutes. The writing is almost nonexistant, but the armor and the bossfight in the sky were cool. If you think that's not too bad, then just remember the fact that this pathetic excuse for an "expansion pack" used to cost 10 or 20 buckaroos when it just came out.

content:
9, 2016
												The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion. I really love the game so far as it is fun to play and really enjoyable when I do quests for people. The game may have some bugs, but so far, I really haven't find any of the game-breaking bugs yet. But if I do, I'll edit this review of what bugs I have encountered. So let's talk about the game. So the setting is that the Emperor named Uriel Septim VII is being hunted down by the cult who follow the Daedric Prince of Destruction because in order for the Prince to enter the realm of Nirn, the dragon rulers must die and the Dragonfires are extinguise. Well by dragon rulers, I mean the decesendants of Tiber Septim who was the Dragonborn. So far, his three sons have died and he lives but not for long unless he escapes but it dosen't really matter. So he escapes through the Imperial City Prison where there is a secret escape. But when he and his guards called the Blades come to the cell, that's when they see the prisoner. Which that prisoner is you. So Uriel talks to you telling you that he saw you in one of his visions that was a sign of his doom. But you can help him by giving the Amulet of Kings to someone who can keep it while you search for the next heir. The reason why you are doing that is because as soon as you get through the training in the dungeon and see Uriel Septim one last time, he is then assassinated. So whenever you are done creating your character and giving him or her stats, that's when you finally get to explore Cyrodiil ever since The Elder Scrolls I: Arena. Here are the positive stuff and negative stuff that I found so far with in the game.Positive:Pretty good story (it's fine but there are some stuff that don't make sense)Awesome quests (with some plot to them and you can find some cool stuff along the way)Downloadable Content (except for the horse dlc but it's fine sort of but why cost money IDK)Explore Cyrodiil (IT'S HUGE! BIGGER THAN SKYRIM! But not as big as Arena or Daggerfall)Become whatever you want (like a thief, a champion of a arena, pretty much whatever you want)Join awesome factions (like the Fighters Guild, Mages Guild, Dark Brotherhood and more)Looks beautiful (if you get good graphics and a good computer)NPCs interacting with each other (giving some random conversations but fun to listen at times)Interact with NPCs with the emotion system (to get them to like you or hate you! yay!)Dungeons ('cause why not)Negative:NPCs kind of look ugly (but the ugliest ones are Orcs and Elves)Some bugs (if you get the Unofficial mods on Nexus, then the bugs won't happen :D)Terrible voice acting (THE ACTORS DIDN'T EVEN TRY! Except for the actors of Uriel Septim, Martin Septim and Sheogorath)With the negative, that's all I can think of. But so far, the game is great I definently recommand that you get it if you want to try it out. I give the game a 9/10. Definently try it out and you might like/love it. I hope you enjoy the game and I'll edit this review if I ever encounter anything else with in the game. Enjoy it! :D

content:
ry 25, 2014
												I am not so good at the whole review thing but here is my review on The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion® Game of the Year Edition!I don't know what it is about Oblivion that makes me keep coming back for more. It was the third Elder Scrolls that I ever played, and personally my favorite. Everything in this game was perfect. I could have played Skyrim with ease if it had everything that made Oblivion what it is. Skyrim, in my opinion, lacked something. Maybe it was the setting. Maybe it was the story. Maybe it was the higher sense of exploration and less emphasis on slashing your way through enemies. Maybe it was the breathtaking soundtrack. Here is my pros and cons list of this game and my final verdict.Pros: Masterful story, great combat although bow can be a pain sometimes, side quests that will keep you hooked for hundreds upon hundreds of hours, memorable characters, I could literally get so caught up in seeing what certain npc's would be doing and seeing how there everyday lives unfolded one time i remembered seeing Penniless Olvus dead next to the poor guy were a few guards my best guess of what happened to him is that since he begs he might not have been getting enough to live and tried his hand at pickpocketing someone and got caught because i saw a good amount of gold on his corpse.Cons: Bow combat can be annoying if you did not mean to pull it back because there is no way to retract it, potato faces which you can easily overlook, and not many voice actors but can also be overlooked seeing as how the quests are great.The point is, is that this game brings endless possibilities for you to experience and how you play the game is up to you. Will you be a great hero who fights off the mythic dawn and puts a stop to corruption, or will you be a crazy bloodthirsty serial killer who teases the guard egging them on to catch you, perhaps even becoming a adverage citizen earning money off of game, errands, and or investing in shops. The choice is yours, but i can what I can tell you is that you can not pass up on playing this game it is just such a well thought out game, I myself have put in over 1k hours on this game on console, steam, and pc disc combined. If you have not got this already go and get it now, trust me you will not regret it! Final result 5/5 WILL PLAY AGAIN!

At least 500 hours worth of gameplay, at least.This game has all that is needed to make it a great RPG.Quest, Magic, swords, clubs and monsters. content:
9, 2016
												A wonderfully rich game in the series and has hours and hours of content.  I remember when I first saw Oblvion at the E3 XBOX Conference I was astounded at how good this game looked.  I first played it on the XBOX 360 and have since seen it on the PS3 and the PC.  This game on PC was a hog when released, but on more modern machines, including more modest ones today can run this game looking as good as the developed had intended.  Many of the screenshots uploaded show off the rich environments of the Provence of Cyrodiil.  Like many games in the Elder Scrolls series you start the game as a no one and find yourself in fortunate circumstances which enables you to wonder the world.  Upon the first part of the character creation where you have a myriad of options to taylor your character exactly how you want you do find just how deep this game can be.  Game play for Oblivion has departed a little from previous entries as it is now more action based, where your states do not determine IF you will hit the enemy but how much damage, if they block and so on.  So it is not the TRUE RPG experience that many might have expected if you love Morrowind.  But it enables a player to quickly get into the swing of things and as you progress through the story you find yourself sometimes feeling more powerful than you are and will undertake some foes that are just out of your reach, BUT, with the mechanics of Oblivion it is not beyond impossible, creative ways to get objects between you and your enemy, knowing when to run, are all options if you find yourself in a sticky situtation. Many of the objectives in the game are leveled to your character so none of the quests seem too difficult and other than a small handful of quests you can do most (the others will not unlock until you reach a specific level).Leveling is easy, you have major and minor skills, get your Major skill up a level and you will level yourself.  Minor skills level up as well, at a slower rate.  This is where it will be a good indication as to how you will want to play your character since if you pick a warrior load out but find you want to sneak around then sneaking skills will take longer to level.  So to increase a skill you use it, fight enemies with a sword to increase your blade, hit them with damaging magic and your destruction will increase, sneak around the dark corners of the world (and there are many) and you will get better at doing do.The music by Jeremy Soule is one of the best sound tracks he has done and I even love listening to it as I find myself looking over the vistas the game presents.  The music dynamics do over an insight if you have annoyed an enemy, but it is a good indication especially when you do not know from where they are coming at you.  The biggest let down with an unmodded version are some of the sound glitches that happen, where audio will cut out, it will come back after a period of time but you will find yourself wondering the wilds and making no footsteps, but the most difficult one is the weapon strike and knowing when you have hit your enemy as it can disappear to.  But I believe there is an unofficial patch can fix many of these issues.Under newer operating systems this game might just crash from time to time, I have found when the in-game dialogs display as white and not textured it might be a good time to save.  Save often, make sure the auto saves are also set, on PC this takes no time and you will be welcoming it after a few crashes.All in all this is a top addition to the series and would highly recommend it to anyone who enjoys a solid RPG experience and a game that will sometimes make you just want to sit and enjoy the view.

												Oblivion is my personal favourite TES game in the series. Compared to Skyrim, it has less sidequests, and the world is less interesting. And that's both good and bad, because it limits your freedom, but you know who you'll be from the start; you also don't need to grind some skills like in Skyrim, because that skill is already higher from the class you selected. Overall, i think this game is really good, and if you played and enjoyed Skyrim you should enjoy this game too.

												I've actually owned this a loooooong time ago for the Xbox 360, but I liked it so much I bought it again. That and the mods.This game truly brings back memories of taking turns with my dad playing it and how bad we were at fighting in the Arena.Or the time when we beat up a bandit in full Ebony regailia, stole it, and wore it for the rest of the game. (which is sort of why part of my screen name is Ebon.)My "Good" Opinions:Feels very adventure-y/immersive, good to sink a couple hours into.Colorful and varied landscapes.Towns were filled with quests and cool characters.The player wasn't the BIG DEAL protagonist through the main campaign, but a very vital component to the campaign.Lots of different stats and class mixing.Major DLCs were fun and added more stuff to play with. (Plus Sheogorath is always a good reason to buy an expansion.)Can leave you with fond memories.The guilds were fun (even though the Mage's and the Fighter's Guild quests were a little bit boring.)Mods!My "Bad" Opinions:Buggy (it's a Bethesda game, what'd I expect?).Lack in variation to voice actors (also not a big suprise).Oblivion gates were boring and really had not much variety.Patrick Stewart never got to actually voice anything outside our beloved dead emperor.Dungeon delving gets boring after a while.So does repetitive quest goals.Persuasion is useless if I can just pay them cash to give me information.Vampirism is awful.Overall:It's a really good game that leaves you having a satisfying experience.9/10.

												Played this game for hundeds of hours on console recently got it on steam. Oblivion has always been my favourite game in The Elder Scrolls series and perhaps in my top 5 ever.The open world of Tamriel's central province Cyrodil is stunningly georgeous for a game made in 2005 and remains iconic to this day. And the best enchantments on weapons eat up your soul gems.Oblivions class system is somethinng I missed in Skyrim, It makes you focus and develop your Character along the 7 skills you chose though you still can master all skills though any skill you did not chose as a major skill doesn't level you up.The combat at levels 15+ clearly rises in difficulty. Enemies start staggering you in close quarters and you sniping skills need to improve fast along with adding some poisons and preferably an enchantment on your bow to keep getting those one shot kills.I could write a novel on the game but in short Oblivion is an excelent open world rpg with a great story fun characters and factions and always gives you something to do 10/10 if you havent played this get it asap

content:
er 17, 2014
												All in all, I find this game way more appeling than its more modern counter-part, Skyrim. In my opinion the guilds are a lot more immersive and in-depth as you work your way up the chain in a way that makes sense for that particular group; battling evil necromancers and getting recommendations for the arcane university, rather than Skyrim's cast a simple spell get into the arcane college. The main story is also pretty epic, as the invasion of the daedra draws near ever minute, you along with the local Blades need to take certain actions to stop this onslaught. Need a break from quests or need something else to do in the game? Well you can make your own adventures by clearing the local fort or dungeon, either by yourself or with a group of adept adventures behind your back. The only issues I came across dealt with the leveling up/character build mechanic. Cookie-cutter characters are hard to make as a wizard build has to be purely towards the most magicka to cast the higher tier spells; warrior builds and theif builds aren't as restricting, but are still a little rigid. Also at a certain point your character becomes "too good", as your attributes hit insane heights. You become really hard to kill, save for a room FILLED with top quality enemies or a named legendary enemy. I'll admit that the perk system of Skyrim is better, as it rewards using skills and allows for intresting characters to form. Would give this game around a 9.5/10. The DLC's are amazing btw.
