content:
10, 2016
												I played The Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind before ever playing this game, and I always felt that this game took a step forward from III with graphics, combat, and other mechanics.. but several steps backward with exploration, character-building, and true roleplay.I'm not reviewing Morrowind here, but I think it is fair to compare a game against its predecessor and look at what was improved and what was taken in the wrong direction.To begin, Oblivion did a lot of things right, when improving on mechanics compared to Morrowind. We'll start with combat. In Morrowind, your character's skill with your chosen weapon, along with one of your main stats, determined your chance to hit, as a percentage. If the game calculated that chance and determined that you would "miss" with that swing, your weapon would not damage the enemy at all, even if it appeared to go directly through them. Similar chances were put in place with blocking, where you simply had a chance to block while holding a shield, and when casting spells, where you had a percentage chance to fail at casting while still using up the magic required to try. This gave the game's combat a feeling more similar to traditional pen and paper RPGs and made combat feel more like a chore to some. Oblivion took the combat system and made it much more action-oriented and controlled by you, the player. Now, every attack hits, as long as YOU don't miss, as the player, and instead your damage is what's determined by your skills. Spells are cast, if you have the magic for it, and that magic cost decreases as your skill increases. Blocking, with a shield or not, is an active thing and more effective depending on the related skill. This made combat much more interested, when compared to Morrowind, and made tough fights actually FEEL tough!The stealth system, although improved as far as enemy detection and such, mostly stayed the same from the previous game to this one. You still have a symbol indicating whether you've been detected, you still deal more damage while sneaking, etc.The magic system also mostly stayed the same. Some spells went away from Morrowind to Oblivion, and we saw some new additions. Spellmaking is done differently, as is enchanting, and again, the mechanics of each of these systems is improved. A major gameplay difference this time is that you don't have to equip a spell INSTEAD of your weapon in order to use it; there is just a separate button to cast the chosen spell, even if you have a sword and shield equipped. This made combat much more strategic and made "utility" sorts of spells more fluid to cast or re-cast in combat. A few really neat improvements include new ways to get new enchantments (sigil stones) and spells (Spelltomes, from DLC).The world, unfortunately, seems to take a step backward. In Morrowind, the world felt gigantic, even after uncovering most of your map locations, and even near the end of my years playing almost nothing but Morrowind, I was still able to get entirely lost in the world - in a good way! - and discover locations I had never seen! For Oblivion, this can really only be said for the distant corners of the game's map, and I never had a reason to go there anyway! The world simply feels smaller, even without fast-traveling. Part of this smaller feeling is that most of the dungeons of the same "type" feel and look almost the same, unless they're different for the purposes of a quest. The Aylied Ruins all feel about the same, most of the abandoned forts feel about the same, most of the caves feel about the same.. It's all just very similar! Thinking back, I can still remember unique dungeons or ruins from Morrowind, but hardly any from Oblivion, if they didn't play a major part in the main or faction quests.My next point.. I'm really not sure if this one is a good or a bad thing. I think, really, it's neither. You aren't special, in Oblivion. In Morrowind, you're the Nerevarine (SPOILERS), and flash-forward to Skyrim, you're the Dragonborn (AHH, more SPOILERS!!). In Oblivion.. Nope! You're a prisoner who gets out and does some great things.. but you aren't special. You can't do anything that someone else in the game couldn't also do. The only difference between you and those other people is that you're in the right places at the right times and do the right things (or the wrong things, depending on your faction choices...), and if you choose to take part in the main storyline, you help Martin, who IS, in fact, special.All in all, I feel like Oblivion improved on plenty of points that were lacking in Morrowind, though the ones that were a step backward were BIG ones, like the world and dungeons. The game plays much better, but feels less spectacular.I still recommend the game, of course, and once you're done playing, I also recommend modding the game! This is what really gets me nostalgic about the game: the mods! Modding was definitely a thing for Morrowind; there were plenty! But, to me, it feels like modding really took off with Oblivion, and there are so many incredible ones to choose from! Have fun!

content:
10
												(This review is going to be astronomically long, so bear with me! TL:DR; is at the end.)I remember the first time I played Oblivion. It was at a friend's house when I was seven, back in 2007. I didn't understand it much, but I got to watch him play it on his old television and I got a small turn for a while. Eventually, I got my first Playstation 3 in 2009. Oblivion was one of the first games I ever bought for the system.Between the endless interesting quests, to the big open world that was the best for it's time, it was one of the best experiences in video gaming that I have ever experienced.Now it's 2017, and I have just started playing Oblivion again.I have two hundred or so hours on the retail version, and roughly 30 hours on the Steam version. Time and time again I find myself returning to Oblivion just to play through the Dark Brotherhood questline or to just explore all the dungeons and forts that the game had to offer.I would even daresay that this game beats Skyrim. Skyrim's graphics are certainly much better, but to me, the game dumbed down on a lot of the elements that made Oblivion great, including a mediocre story, poorly made (and much less) side-quests and a broken vanilla follower system.But enough about Skyrim, this is about Oblivion. I'm going to list all of the positives, negatives and other features that are a little in-between.POSITIVES+ Excellent main story.+ A plethora of side-quests that are even better then some of the main quests.+ The Thieves Guild and the Dark Brotherhood's questlines are excellent.+ Good controls.+ The Shivering Isles and Knights of the Nine are EXCELLENT DLCs and NEED to be purchased with this game.+ An all-star acting cast who do a very great job at their roles.+ Very well detailed dungeons, forts and caves.+ Many different cities with dozens of quests, along with many interesting characters.+ A lot of well-written books inside the game.+ Many different weapons to choose from.+ Customise your own class and what skills level up your character.+ A lot of spells to choose from, including many other ones that can be bought.+ The Mage Guild and the Fighters Guild. Their questlines were pretty good, however, they didn't return in their same form in Skyrim. The Companions in Skyrim represented the Fighter's Guild and the College of Winterhold represented the Mage Guild.+ An amazing soundtrack. From the quiet songs while you're trading with a merchant in the Imperial City, to the heart-wrenching song playing when you enter an Oblivion gate, this soundtrack is quite possibly the best in the Elder Scrolls series.+ Weapon degradation. You can use repair hammers to repair your weapons, where in Skyrim, you couldn't do that.+ Alchemy. I enjoyed the alchemy in this game a lot, especially when I needed to upgrade my Alchemy tools whenever I levelled higher!+ The voice acting is on-par with 2017 video games to date. With the famous 'Lucien Lachance' scene being one of the best scenes in the entire game, just because of how the actor portayed Lucien in that very scene.+ The visuals are pretty damn good. Skyrim's visuals were excellent, but felt very drab. Oblivion's visuals were perfect for how many players envisioned Cyrodil. From the beautiful green trees, to the snow near the Blade's temple at Bruma, the scenary and visuals are excellent.+ The end of the main quest. The end is very well done, and it's short and simple. Much better than Skyrim's in my opinion.+ The Arena. It may be repetitive sometimes, but for me, this was one of the best questlines in the entire game (taking a back-seat to the Dark Brotherhood). From the Gray Prince realising his true identity, to the many battles you will have to win to become the 'Grand Champion', this is another reason why Oblivion is so good.+ Random encounters. They may be less of them than Skyrim, but coming across a Highwayman when crossing a bridge near the Imperial City, or M'aiq the Liar outside of Leyawiin, I just found more enjoyment in those encounters.+ The Ayleid Ruins. Skyrim tried to replicate the Ayleid Ruins with the Dwemer Ruins. To me, I found them a lot less interesting than the Ayleid Ruins in Oblivion. The beautiful arcitecture and design, (along with the value of all the Welkyd stones that you could collect) made them a lot more fun to explore, then Skyrim's substitute.I think that covers all of the positives. Now, onto the features that are a little positive, and a little negative.AVERAGE~ All of the guards have the same voice actor, so good luck trying to find a certain guard if it involves a quest.~ The game stutters infrequently (at least for me) and it breaks immersion.~ The AI isn't very good, especially the Bandit and Mage AI, where they will just run right into my blade instead of being tactical or running away.~ Glarthir. That entire quest is absolute garbage. The only thing that's good about it, is being able (you can choose not to) kill him and take the reward.~ Merchants seem to have infinite gold. It makes no sense that if a Merchant has 800 gold, you can sell 795 gold worth of potions to them, and be able to sell them more as long as you keep the amount to under 800. The gold never depletes!~ Lucien LaChance's ending. I don't want to talk about that.~ I'm not going to say that the Zombies are hyper-realistic, but they are too scary for me.Now...onto the negatives.NEGATIVES- The UI. It is clearly designed with the Console in mind, and it can be extremely frustrating and sometimes un-usable due to it's awful inventory interface and merchant inventory interface. The only way to really use it, is if you download a UI mod for the game from the Nexus.- Levelling up. Being able to level up your stats while you're sleeping? Overall, the levelling up system is good, but I just found it really curious as to why we need to sleep to level up.- The Lockpicking. It is a good minigame, but the problem with it is, you can just Quicksave in front of a locked door, then reload whenever you are caught or break a lockpick.- The intense lag. The game can range from 30 to 200 FPS (only up to 90 in my case, and that's with a GTX 970). For a game that is over ten years old, intense lag in some places (such as Bravil or the Arena) is unnacceptable. Download mods to fix this and greatly reduce your lag.- The Adoring Fan. You know what I'm talking about if you've finished the Arena questline.- Invisible walls. Like in Skyrim, Oblivion has a LOT of invisible walls. Couldn't big mountains have been put in place to force the player to stop and not be able to hit an invisible wall? The only positive to this, is that when mods open up new lands to explore (Elsweyr Arquenia, etc), all you need to do is disable the invisible walls.- The fame and infamy system. Fame isn't such a problem to me, as it makes a lot of sense, but infamy seriously annoys me. I want to be able to complete the Dark Brotherhood and Thieves Guild questline, but I can't because each mission or murder grants you infamy (even when nobody sees you doing these crimes) and eventually, guards will attack on sight if your infamy is high enough.That's all I could think of.Oh, also, a massive positive.MODS. Enough said.TL:DR; Oblivion is an amazing game and is the best Elder Scrolls in the franchise and it is definitely worth picking up (ASWELL AS THE DLCs) and should not be missed at any cost. It overcomes it's shortcomings with an amazing story, world and cast of characters, that are unforgettable.GET. THIS. GAME.

content:
ry 9
												Quite literally, this game - nay, experience - is something that saved my life on innumerable occasions. It's best to not compare it to anything else - even other games in the series - and instead focus on it as a separate entity that provides a wondrous realm of vivid storytelling and escapism. Lose yourself in the bloom-lit ethereality with Jeremy Soule's transcendent soundtrack as a companion, and endless discoveries hidden just over that next green hill. Not all of us know how to appreciate Oblivion for what it really is, but enough of us understand it's essence to respect it in a way that presents the game as an escapist classic. I explored the rich and beautiful lands in this game on my Xbox 360 for several years, and it provided a profound sense of solace and reflection, strangely enough. Anyone in search of an experience or a portal to a place to simply lose oneself in (in a good way) should at least give Oblivion a try. For me, this will always be the best entry in the series due to that special, undefinably brilliant magic that's embedded in it and how it provided endless hours of whimsy and solace to me during times when I needed it most. And if you can't quite get what all my ramblings and praises represent, perhaps you haven't given the game enough time to let it get into your head (or, perhaps you're a longtime Morrowind fan who understandably detests the changes made in this entry). The DLC expands upon the game even moreso, and with select mods you can do no wong with taking a step back into this wondrous title.It feels like an entire era - a golden age in itself - that will forever be timeless. Just ignore the potato-headed NPCs and look beneath the surface of this game. There's magic there.

er 9, 2013
												This is the epitomy of the fantasy genre. It has perfect mechanics for getting into RPGs without being too streamlined or confusing. The environment is perfectly put together and will keep you invested for months at a time. The levelling is set up so that the game can actually get harder as you play, instead of easier and boring like another game in the series. This is the perfect game to play as a first RPG, and it will keep veterans just as entertained. This game is far over-shadowed by its comparatively mediocre sequel, and I highly recommend everyone to play this game and some of its predeccessors for an idea of what a true open-world fantasy experience should be.

												One of the best RPGs that I've ever played. You will have plenty of fun with this game and once you beat it vanilla, it's time to install mods! Mods for this game are soooo much fun. Anything that you can think of, they add to the game. Want new quests? Done. Want rebalancing of level? Easy. Do you want more weapons? How about a mod that adds 120 immersive weapons? Yes, there are many, many mods for this game.My only complaint with this game is that it may crash every once in a while, mods or not, because Bethesda games usually crash a whole bunch for no specific reason. Sure, you can have 8+ hour sessions where the game will run smooth and not crash whatsoever or you can be playing for about an hour and have it crash when you enter an interior. In my opinion, the game is badly optimized but that's the only con, and the pros outweight the cons by A LOT.

content:
7, 2015
												Oblivion. My favorite Elder scrolls game so far! I've played all of the main titles except for Daggerfall, and the Online one, but man, this game is fun! You can craft your own spells once you get to the Mages Guild in the Imperial City! I like Oblivion better than Skyrim, because you don’t feel like you’re carrying a backpack full of rocks, you can actually cast magic while holding a sword and a shield, and Cyrodiil is not as cold and miserable as the neighbor to the North!Another thing I like about ES4: Oblivion is once you level up your acrobatics and athletics a bit, you can run really fast and jump super high! I like this game better than Morrowind, because you don’t have to be a specific class build to actually land a blow, the only downside, is it discluded the levitation spell from Morrowind. I still have yet to beat the main quest line, but I beat the Mages Guild, beat Shivering Isles, and Started on the Dark Brotherhood, and it’s honestly one of my favorite RPG’s Ever! On a scale of 2, I give this game a 10. 10/2.Edit: So far, I see no need for mods, The game isn't as glitchy and broken as Skyrim, and the story and characters are fun enough, that I only play Vanilla!

												The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion Game of the Year Deluxe EditionBe prepared for a detailed review of this game. If you're considering purchasing this, have a read and see what you think before doing so!Positives:+ Pleasant graphics for a game almost a decade old (2006).+ A huge assortment of quest to complete, such as the Thieves' Guild, Dark Brotherhood, Fighter's Guild, Mage's Guild and Daedric God storylines. Lots of miscellaneous quests too.+ Massive map to explore, lots of locations including caves, bandit camps, forts and ancient ayleid ruins. Snowy regions and lush forest, open grasslands and swamps, very varied terrain.+ Wide array of weaponry, many, many skills to level up, use magic, archery or melee combat to strike down foes. Mix your own potions with alchemy, become a master of acrobatics or conjure powerful beasts to do your bidding. + Hundreds of hours of gameplay to engage in. Fun for the first 100-120. Anything in excess of level 40 starts to see boredom set in. I recommend taking regular breaks to avoid the repetition, in which case it won't be so noticeable. + Large mod community.Negatives:- Extremely flawed and stupid monster levelling, giving you no sense accomplishment when you progress to higher levels. Many creatures will be levelled to you, meaning that, at higher levels, you'll be required to spam click attacks for ages to get kills (ogres, goblin warlords, gloom wraiths). Keep in mind this is using the best weapons available, with the highest skill level. Much to your disdain, you'll spend hours clearing out caves or forts filled with insanely high hitpoint enemies. Not fun, not a challenge, just a complete and utter waste of time.- Caves, dungeons and other places have a lot of loot potential and you'll have fun in the beginning collecting fragments of armour, potions and gold to pay for adventuring supplies and purchasing houses. However, after awhile there's literally nothing to spend your cash on. All of the equipment I've sold has resulted in stockpiling over 300,000 coins, with nothing practical to spend it on. Every elder scrolls (even the latest instalment to the series, Skyrim) has had this issue.- Dumb AI that gets stuck when you jump onto rocks and cast magic or shoot arrows. It doesn't understand how to reach you. The AI scripting for conversations is also ridiculous. There are only a limited number of discussions citizens can have between each other and these all feel very, very unnatural. It's as if the designers didn't bother to implement realistic dialogue. - Many textures for forts or caves are re-used and do not look unique. This gets dull later, rather than sooner, but it's still a great downfall of the title. The layouts of many locations are similar. They might have different pathways, include an underwater cave or a bridge, but for all intents and purposes, most locations have a familiar feel to them. There's little excitement in that regard.- Modding requires excessive use of complicated tools that are not only time consuming but annoying. Not to mention the countless glitches that conflict with gameplay.- Character levelling comes to a sudden halt around levels 40+, it becomes so infrequent that you feel like you're achieving nothing at all, apart from going on errands for a number of characters you don't care much about.The Shivering Isles Expansion:Positives:+ New textures compared to the base game, an entirely new environment, new colours, new armour and weapons, new characters, new monsters and new quests. Consequently, this expansion does have a feeling of freshness to it. +Around 30 hours of additional content, which is not unreasonable for an expansion.Negatives:- Despite the fact that there are various changes and new features, the dreadful monster levelling system remains, which never fails to detract greatly from the experience (unless you go to the Shivering Isles at a lower level, at which point it becomes bearable).- Rather horrible voice acting for Sheogorath, too try-hard in its approach, quite off-putting and didn't seem like a genuine portrayal of the characteristics the developers wanted to exhibit, which was a God of Madness.Knights of the Nine Expansion:Positives:+ A new and intriguing storyline (for the most part) based around the Nine Divines, where you must complete a series of tests to retrieve the ancient armour of Crusader Pelinal Whitestrake, in an effort to defeat the infamous Umaril, a Daedra who poses a threat to Cyrodiil. + Some extra locations to explore which have been added to the map during the expansion, but nothing really new other than aesthetics (the Crusader armour and weapons). + There's a real feeling of reviving the old Knights of the Nine Order, as people will approach you to swear their allegiance. You'll fight side by side at the end against Umaril's minions in a big battle, which is cool.Negatives:- Many of the places you'll visit are filled with the standard enemies you'll encounter in the base game, there is little difference in the design of these locations to other ayleid ruins or forts in the base game as well.DLC Add-Ons:Positives:+ A number of new houses for those interested. There's a Wizard's Tower, a Castle and an underground Cave that can become new homes, some of them include enchanting and spellmaking areas for convenience.+ A few additional activities to partake in, like collecting dwarven artifacts stolen by bandits, to repair an Orrery at the Arcane University. You can also investigate the caverns beneath anvil to find the resting place of a pirate ship and the mystery behind it. In the East of Cyrodiil you can travel to Sundercliff Watch, a fortress that holds the powerful Daedric item, Mehrune's Razor.Negatives:- Some bugs which interfere with how the house DLC works, causing problems with them being unable to be purchased or relevant questlines not progressing.Overall Score: 7.5/10The Elder Scrolls: IV Oblivion is almost a decade old as of 2015. It's still a very entertaining and fun game, but one should also be aware of the numerous problems it has. Worth picking up on sale for under $10.

content:
er 18, 2015
												The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion PC ReviewThe Elder Scrolls IV might be one of the best open world rpg's of it's time so I decided to pick it up during the Discovery steam sale. This game consumed my life for 2-3 weeks while I was finishing guild quests, exploring this expansive world and getting immersed by the lore of this video game.Story: 9/10The Elder Scrolls IV has a mediocre main story but the Guild quests and side quests really make the story of this game one of the best in all Elder Scrolls games. If I was to do the main story of this game alone it would take me less than 8 hours and bore me to death but the side quests really where the majority of my 50 hours in Oblivion were spent. In some of the quests in the Dark Brotherhood I was having so much fun doing so many different contracts for them. Almost all the guild and side quests were exponentially better than the side quests of many other Rpg's because of their intriguing plots. Overall, The main story is mediocre but the side and guild quests are where oblivion's story shines.Gameplay: 7/10The gameplay of this is mediocre and could get boring at some times.Since I played through the game as a Warrior-Destruction mage most of the game was filled with mashing my mouse and keyboard while occasionally blocking just to get my block skill up. Even though the combat was mediocre the leveling system was horrible in my honest opinion because in this game you get weaker by leveling up. Even though the gameplay and leveling system were not so great all the other systems in the game were refined(Questing, Alchemy,Etc.). Another horrible aspect of Oblivion's gameplay is that the dungeons all look the same and also make you backtrack through them sadly. The only other gripe I have with this game is horrible map system that was really confusing to navigate. The gameplay might not be the best part of this game it isn't unplayable but can sometimes get enjoyable mashing away at hordes of dremora. Graphics-8/10The graphics in this game were awesome for it's time in 2006 however I can say that the graphics look beautiful some times however the character models look completely hideous at times really showing the age of this game. The dungeons also look horrendous as their is no variety in their aesthetics but some times as I'm riding through the world of Oblivion and the sun shines on the world making the game look awesome.Overall-8/10This game may not be the best rpg ever made but it's a must buy for gamers who like rpg's with expansive worlds like Skyrim and are willing to look past some gameplay and graphic issues. So this game gets a 8/10

content:
r 19, 2015
												10/10Pros:*Great Story*Great Soundtrack*Fun combat and leveling system*Memorable NPC's (Or maybe they're just burned into my memory because I played it so many times.)Cons:See, Oblivion has cons. I love the game too much to really care (biased review, oh nooo). But, for any cons you find... There's a 99% there's a mod for it.An awesome world with a gripping story and one that's told well. While the main story is pretty linear, the rest of the game is fairly open in choices. The impacts of your choice aren't as heavy as they perhaps should be, but it's still nice to be able to be a charming knight, a stoic wanderer, a powerful mage, a cunning assassin, or anything else you can think of. Due to the fact that it's on the PC and has mod availability, that only gives Oblivion a boost.Base game Oblivion with no DLC's or mods is still awesome if you can look past outdated graphics and appreciate the pretty colors. Plus, with the amazing soundtrack, just roaming around in the wilderness can be rewarding enough on it's own. There's a few factions to join and various side quests, some that are easily found, others you probably won't notice because of how far off in the corners they are. With DLC's, the content for the game is only added upon, and each DLC is a nice and fun little thing, particularly Mehrune's Razor, Knights of the Nine, and Shivering Isles. If we include mods, well. It's what you choose to make it.

												Hallo.If you're reading this review you most likely never played Oblivion before and wonder if it's still worth it.Yes.It doesn't feel outdated in any way. Of course the graphics are not as detailed as in current games - but it still looks beautiful and fits the game very well.The gameplay feels good and I actually prefer it to Skyrim.The open world feels big and open and getting from A to B is rarely tedious or annoyingPersonally I don't like the main quest that much but there are dozens of side quests, missions and things to explore that you can literally play hundreds of hours (including 2 very good DLCs and various brilliant fan made) without touching the main story.A lot of fan made mods let you personalize Oblivion and you have as many as you can wish for!In conclusionIf you are even slightly interested in this game and you think it might be for you - you should definitely give it a try!I'm pretty sure you won't regret it.

content:
1, 2016
												Oblivion: it feels like a parody of Skyrim. Not only are Skyrim's graphics better, but the world itself just feels more serious and realistic than its predecessor. The game is sort of a more relaxed Skyrim, that was my first impression.But nonetheless, I can guarantee you that I had more fun with Oblivion! There are few games that made me laugh so hard. But don't think that Oblivion is all about laughing. The game is filled with very entertaining and well made side quests that feel as if they aren't side quests, but the main story itself. I actually did not play much the main story, just because the side quests were so good!The graphics? Nothing special nowadays, but definately playable!  The game is just so good, that you will probably get more immersed than in Skyrim, even with the simpler graphics. Hours will fly by and you won't notice. I guess that the graphics also helped create more complex environments. The cities in Oblivion are much bigger than the ones in Skyrim. There are endless hours of fun in the cities, from messing around with the guards to exploring sewers and doing quests. It just feels more complex than Skyrim! Don't get me wrong, both are excellent games, but have slight different approaches. Skyrim is a masterpiece of beauty and thrilling adventure, while Oblivion focuses on the complexity and fun of its world. My suggestion? Buy both!(Don't trust Steam hour record! I have endless hours of offline play in both games!)

												If you kinda think about it, Most people who prefer skyrim are the type of people who only play a game for graphics. (In my opinion, at least)Like, Skyrim is cool and all and they're all different in their own ways. But honestly skyrim has no match for oblivion.Honestly I don't even know WHERE to begin. The game is so cool and it left me with a broken heart, tbh.The quests were so unique and so different. And the story itself is so amazing. (Especially if you're someone who likes backstories/lores)Oblivon felt more alive to me. It had more colors and life than skyrim. And I absolutely love the voice acts.But honestly as someone who really loves all elven races/beast races, I love the equality of the races in the game.Because skyrim was so racist towards elves and khajits which made me hate the nords more.Like I loved oblivion because I saw lots of races in one place, I was so sick of seeing only Humans in skyrim tbh.And I fell in love that you can "make" your own class. Instead of counting on the stones, You chose your perks and name your own class.And the fact that you can "talk" to NPCs made the game more alive. Like you can tell them jokes, Bribe them, Boast, etcit felt like the NPCs in the game are a living things. Instead of accessories or an "atmosphere".But really you could soo many stuff in your free time. Like, enter the arena for example !!You can even choose your own title and you'd have a fan following you.That's the least i could say without saying any spoilers. But I still feel like i left so many stuff unsaid.Can't blame me though, this game is so amazing and it left me speechless.But my advice is you should buy this game. It's honestly a great experience. 10/10

content:
18, 2016
												the elder scrolls iv: oblivion is not realistic. if you're looking for realism, go away. the elder scrolls iv: oblivion is not graphically impressive. if you're looking for impressive visuals, go away. the elder scrolls iv: oblivion has a lot of content. if you expect to finish this game in your lifetime, go away. seriously, leave. you are wasting your time reading this.with that out of the way, here's my review. this is the game that quite honestly set a foundation for modern RPGs. it has everything you would expect in your average RPG: spooky dungeons, loot, exploring, a large amount of quests... but here's the thing. oblivion isn't an average RPG. it has a LOT to offer for what its worth now, and frankly i found this to be more engaging than skyrim. here's why!as i mentioned at the beginning of this review, it does not hold up well to todays standards. everyone has baby butt faces and it seems everyone, including the scrawny elderly beggars, is voiced by the voice actors that portrayed the intimidating imperial guards... it just looks goofy. but, if you strip it down to its core functions, you get a pretty solid RPG with plenty of features to occupy your mind.it may seem redundant at first: whack whack whack, slice slice slice. you start to realize dungeons look almost exactly the same. but fear not! there are plenty of treats to keep you occupied as you level up. dungeons start being populated by more frightening enemies, you start to get better tiers of armor and weaponry... you also start exploring some of the guilds and their special quests. i found myself forgetting about the main quest after 50 hours of gameplay involving side quests and world exploration... then realizing i still have the amulet of kings in my inventory. sorry emperor!!one of the highlights of this game--one of the reasons i find it TONS more exciting than skyrim--you can LITERALLY GO TO HELL. is that cool or what?! i think so!! bethesda games aren't known for having the most engaging main quests but this is honestly one of the main reasons why i prefer oblivion above skyrim. the story just feels more intriguing to me. in the DLC shivering isles, you can go to this crazy "other world" that has new enemies, new dungeons, and more content. i like that skyrim has naturally fixed the majority of what made oblivion so goofy (mods have fixed most of these problems anyway) but i find myself coming back to oblivion, a game nearly a decade old, and playing hour after hour only realizing that my entire day consisted of waking up, sitting down for 14 hours, and going back to bed.i really, really, super duper wish i could talk about this game for hours. thing is, the elder scrolls is a series you have to play for yourself to understand. still though, i hope this review was helpful for you RPG-goers <3

content:
2, 2016
												Oblivion>Skyrim. Morrowind>Oblivion. If you like Bethesda RPG's and are tired of the over simplification of their games, Oblivion is a nice medium between "I have no idea what I'm doing in this game(Morrowind)" and "I wish the game didn't hold my hand so much(Skyrim)". I have beaten every quest in the game twice now so I am pretty comfortable in my viewpoint. When it came out it was a 9/10 in 2006... by todays standards I'm gonna give it a 7.5/10.My only compaint is that the environment scaling to the characters level completely destroys any sense of looting and novelty when exploring things. For instance, in Morrowind you may encounter a cave populated by extremely high level enemies at level 1. 99% of people are gonna die and just not come back until a higher level. But if you are intuitive, or can just really design a good build maybe you make it past them. And find some insane Daedric artifact or weapon, something ACTUALLY WORTHWHILE. I wish TES would go back to that type of system, it added such a huge element of surprise to the game and made exploring things actually worthwhile.

												Some people say Morrowind, some say Arx Fatalis and others will go for the Gothic Series. For me, it will never get better than Oblivion.When I first played this game in 2007 our (yes, OUR PC, I was young as hell and we were poor as ♥♥♥♥) could barely handle this at slightly below medium settings but I didn't care. Everything about this game just blew me the ♥♥♥♥ away. The music was amazing, the lands were fun to explore and the plot is still unique to this day. The story itself isn't very original: Ancient prophecy is broken so some duder has to unbreak some stuff so a bunch of duders don't kill all of the duders. That isn't what makes the plot unique. What makes this so different than normal is that you aren't the duder who's unbreaking things, you're a duder who breaks other things to help the main duder unbreak the stuff that wasn't supposed to be broken. You're just some ♥♥♥♥ that hits stuff with a sword when it gets in the way. You don't even play that big of a part in the story as a whole, you're just kind of there yet at the end of the day you feel more accomplished than you ever will in real life.Buy this game. If you don't then THIS IS THE PART WHERE YOU FALL DOWN AND BLEEED TO DEEEEEEEEEATH.

Personally, I always found that, at least for the moment, Oblivion mods are the easiest to find and most plentiful out of the TES games. Most MW mods seem scatter across various sites while the big Skyrim mods are still in deveiopement. Overall, I would say that it is still a pretty good game that definately is worth it.

content:
8, 2014
												"STOP RIGHT THERE, CRIMINAL SCUM!" These are words that summed up a game that cannot be possibly described in words. Building off the success and standard set by Morrowind, The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion far more than its predecessor sucked us into a rich, breathing world filled with breath-taking scenery, towns with believable NPCs with voiced dialog, factions to join, houses to purchase. horses to ride and a vast amount to see and do. Oblivion like Morrowind before it was a game you poured hours into and could still not have seen even a fraction of the game's content. The sheer fidelity, quality, and scope of Oblivion set a standard for Western RPGs to come and heavily influenced the development of Fallout 3. Patrick Stewart even lends his talents to provide the voice of Emperor Uriel Septim.Once again, the reason why Oblivion has remained its legacy is the mod community. Oblivion has strong mod support and  countless mods have been created that add to the game and change the experience in significant ways. Among these is an Oblivion version of MOG*MOD. There is a wealth of content in this game, and with both expansions included, there is a lot to lose sleep over in this game.Out of the most recent The Elder Scrolls games, Oblivion to me seems to have aged the least well. Part of this is due to the way the leveling system can work against you, especially if you're a new player and make poor decisions leveling and allocating points. This leads to the "leveling problem" where at high levels you have an underpowered character but all other enemies have leveled appropriately. The other issue is the models themselves where most NPCs have an uncanny look to them and the odd decision not to include modeled facial hair (which was rectified in Skyrim). Thankfully there are mods to fix both these problems.Overall Oblivion is a fantastic and almost perfect game, overshadowed only by its successor Skyrim.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
y 10
												For sure, one of the greatest fantasy games to-date.  I've cleared more than 300 hours in this incarnation, so time to write a review.I first purchased Oblivion while still in a life and death struggle (in more ways than one) with Morrowind, so I sat on it for a long time before I started playing.  When I did start playing, it was like a breath of fresh air.  The vanilla game was more than a little buggy but no worse than Morrowind.  It now looks very dated compared to more modern games (let's face it, it is ten years old).  It also frustrated me that the entire world levelled up with me.  As my characters gained in ability, so did the world around me, meaning progress quickly became entirely meaningless.This opens up one of Oblivion's better points.Since Oblivion was released, the modding community have updated and improved pretty much every aspect of the game.   Enhancements to textures and display features can transform the game's appearance.  The content of the open world has become even more open, with huge game-world additions, many of which being 'lore friendly', offering a deeper and wider world to explore.  Game mechanisms have also been updated and improved, and new spells, magical items, enemies and quests are available in vast numbers.  In my build, the world no longer levels with me.  Even the game's audio is open to enhancement.All of this choice will then introduce a dilemma.  These add-ons are not always stable, and the more one adds, the less stable the game becomes.  A gaming evening on Oblivion without crashes is unknown to me, and I have spent a great deal of time building the best possible platform I can.  Despite this, I count the crashes as part of the cost of having Oblivion with all of the extra content I have, and I would not want to play the game without that content.  And let's be clear:  Oblivion was not above random crashes even in its 'as shipped' state.So, what have I added that keeps Oblivion alive for me?I wouldn't play without Oscuro's Oblivion Overhaul, the Unofficial Patches, Better Cities, and Unique Landscapes.  Despite some issues, Oblivion Reloaded has also become part of my standard build.  CM Partners adds two new dimensions - many more characters to interact and quest with, and a whole new level of instability to live with (which means I currently have it disabled).  Add to this a raft of game-play modifications and you have my basic build.This build allows me to explore a large game-play world that is a thing of beauty.  The original content was very extensive but the Mods expand it further.  Most of that additional content is good, although there are some moments that make me cringe.  At 2.5 Ghz and with Nvidia 970M my frame-rates are good - especially during indoor game-play.  Avoiding the crashes (or saving when recognising the signs of an imminent crash) has become part of the game-play.The biggest negative - No network play (as designed, and no mods to allow it so far as I am aware)So, to sum up.  A vast and flawed masterpiece.  Not as vast as Morrowind but not so flawed.  Above all, a game of great beauty that influenced many that followed.  Even today, it is worth the time and effort needed to keep it working at the optimum level for me.  My optimum level may be something different to everyone else's but that is another plus.  With a little effort (and more than likely a lot of patience) it can be configured however you want it.To borrow a well used phrase:10/10.  Would spend hundreds of hours perfecting my modlist again.

But it is a world begging for adventure.If you like stories of questing and heroes then this is for you.A gem among RPGs.

												this game is such a pain in the ♥♥♥ to mod. unlike nv which is on the same engine, all the limitations of the software with this one make it incredibly unstable once you start fooling around with more complex graphical upgrades or anything with too much scripting. I think this is in part tied to the games inability to properly utilize modern hardware and any ram over 2 gigabytes (there is the 4gb patcher but it kind of doesn't work great in my experience with oblivion). so once you throw qarls on, maybe oco, maybe oscuros, a sprinkle of hgec and roberts, a dash of better cities, and oh say the graphics extender upgrade recently released and an enb upgraded to x64 enboost, it starts to not recognize what you've done, and then runs choppy anyway. and don't get me started on modding nehrim graphically. what a mess. which sucks because nehrim is so. cool.er anyway I put like 200 hours into this game on Xbox when I was younger and also like 100 hours into a wine skinned Mac port of it before I really got into pc gaming. it's a good game for what it is, buggy, expansive, uncanny, unruly, poor design of dungeons, excellent mid 2000s immersion. it's hard to go wrong with Bethesda for a very very baseline power fantasy, they don't do anything particularly great but the scope and freedom offered within its passable husk (bug testing notwithstanding) can def become addictive.

content:
y 23
												My favorite game of all time, Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion is truly a masterpiece. I have spent thousands of hours playing through it on the Xbox 360 back when that was a thing, and will likely match that feat again on the PC.The gameplay is stellar, the explorable world is massive, beautiful, and filled with interesting dungeons, quests, and fights, the AI is revolutionary, and overall it is just extraordinarily fun.My only gripes with it are the graphics, which are universally agreed to have not aged well (a problem solved relatively easily with mods), and that Bethesda has yet to remaster it (here's hoping).Don't get me wrong, Skyrim is amazing, a work of art in and of itself, but it doesn't quite compare to Oblivion for me. In fact, no game does, and I hate to think no other game ever will. But whether or not this is the case, I am glad to have played Oblivion in my lifetime.

content:
er 31, 2015
												There's a big chance that you're looking at Oblivion because you played Skyrim and wanted to check the other Elder Scrolls games. This review is mainly going to be a comparison between the 2.Main story of Oblivion revolves around Martin Septim, the last remaining son of the emperor. He has to deal with Mehrunes Dagon, daedric prince who starts to open portals across Cyrodiil. You play as the Hero of Kvatch and help Martin by fetching him some important items and defeating a not so strong boss. Quests: There are no quest arrows in Oblivion. Markers are present on the compass.Quests themselves, at least a lot of them, just like in Skyrim, require dungeon crawling. The entire Fighters Guild questline is pretty much just this. Leveling: Leveling is quite different in Oblivion. At the start of the game, you choose your major skills. Training them allows you to level up. The minor skills can be trained as well though. In order to successfully level up and be able to choose which attributes to give points to, you have to sleep. Combat: Combat in Oblivion is a lot clunkier than in Skyrim. Also some enemies can make you fall and that is not fun to fight against, even though they barely scratch your health.Weapons and armor in Oblivion also have health. The more damaged they get, the less effective they are. In order to repair them, you need to buy or find repair hammers.You cannot fight while on a horse, but at least you have a first person camera. Alchemy: In Oblivion you don't need Alchemy stations, but you will need to find at least a mortar and a pestle, an item which lets you mix potions wherever you want, as long as there are no enemies nearby. Like in Skyrim, you can sample raw ingredients and level up your alchemy skill. Spells: Spells in Oblivion come from the schools that are in Skyrim plus the Mysticism school. If you are a Mage's Guild member and have access to the Arcane University you will be able to create your own spells. The more powerful the spell is, the more gold will be required.Enchanting is present as well. Enchanted items can be created from the sigil stones found in the Oblivion gates and the Altar of Enchanting found at the Arcane University. You can put as much effects as you want at an altar, but it will cost gold. Graphics: Obviously, Skyrim has the better graphics, but Oblivion can be modded as well, with overhauls and stuff.Overall, to me, Oblivion is an older Skyrim with different quests. The differences are not that big.

content:
er 4, 2016
												How to level up skills:* means it can be done AFK-Sneak*: auto-run while crouching into a corner where you fight the goblin shaman in the tutorial, keeping the rats in the pen alive so that they can detect you-magic skills*: make minimum cost/effect spells of the 6 magic categories, find something to weigh down the cast magic button (for destruction, make the first spell effect heal you for the same ammount the destruction magic damages you)-alchemy: EAT ALL THE INGRDIENTS!-Armorer: you can find repair hammers as loot in unowned containers in dungeons and cities, which saves you money...-Mercantile: ...and then sell merhcants repaired, looted gear you won't use at 2-3 steps up in the haggle slider, selling everything one by one, instead of all at once-Athletics*: run everywhere until maxed...-Acrobatics: ...then bunnyhop everywhere until maxed-Block/Aromor skills: equip shield and armor from armor type(light or heavy) that you will use...-Blade/Blunt weapons: ...and block enemy attacks until they stagger, then hit them with the lowest damage weapon from the class you'll use(clubs or rusty iron daggers are my recommendation) until they aren't staggered, repeat until maxed-Marksmanship: use your maxed acrobatics to get to a spot melee enemies can't reach you, use a rusty iron bow and iron arrows, and turn them into pincussions-Security: get the Skeleton Key from Nocturnal's Daedric quest and this becomes useless-Speechcraft: spam the wheel choices in the minigame as fast as possible, or ignore this and use Charm spells from Illusion-Hand-to-Hand: Embrace your inner Rocky Balboa, only carrying a silver weapon until you reach skill level 50, which allows you to harm normal weapon immune creatures.

content:
er 28, 2016
Product received for free
												How do I describe a game that is so important? So life-changing? This game is the definition of a masterpiece; from the way characters talk to you, recognize your feats ("It's you! The Hero of Kvatch! This is truly an honor!) to the way that you can wander anywhere you like and still experience a challenge; enemies will test you throughout the game. Some people don't like this form of levelling, but I love it; it keeps the game entertaining right through, unlike other RPGs, by which the end of the game I feel like one of, or maybe all of, the Nine Divines. In this game, things are kept challenging and given enough variety with all of the enemy types (Minotaurs, Land Dreugh, and an army of demons). This game truly is special to me. GameplayA first/third person rpg in which you can be any character you wanted to be. Ever dreamed of being a lizard who had a penchant for eating whole rounds of cheese at midnight every Fredas?Ever wanted to be a mighty warrior who enjoys stealing plates and pulling cutlery from dead wolves(?) Or perhaps you want to be something a little more... regular? The combat is probably the weakest part of the game, though luckily it's easy to master and the enemies remain challenging. You can go and talk to any friendly NPC and chat with them about the rumors of the day. Sometimes it's nice to pick up a note about a deed that you've done. "Did you hear? The Fighters Guild is recruiting again." StoryThe gates of Oblivion have been torn open after the Emperor's assassination. All his heirs lie dead, and you hold the Amulet of Kings, the key to this entire dilemma. The world is about to end-! But the world can wait because someone just asked me to investigate a merchant who is selling wares far below the average price... ooh some flowers by the side of the road!Graphics, Atmosphere and SoundThe graphics are looking a little rough these days. The potato faced people look sort of freakish to first time players, but after some hours, you come to appreciate their strange charm and their samey voice actors. The buildings, trees and grass all look nice from a distance, but standing face to face with them, some textures leave room for improvement. The voice actors are indeed all the same pretty much for each species; almost every Orc is acted by the same person, and so on, but you can get past that. The music is beautiful, I can't choose a favorite track. Very peaceful stuff. The atmosphere is impeccable and I love the way arrows bounce off metal surfaces but sink into wooden and flesh, the way characters and their cities look like they are actually lived in. Skyrim does this, but not to the same effect. I feel as though I am right there, in the moment. I am in Cyrodiil as I play Oblivion. That's how good the atmosphere is. ConclusionWait, you mean I haven't convinced you of the merits of this game which makes my day every time I play it?Play it. jmcone's Personal Rating: Essential

												Just a full, rich, amazing game. I dumped well over 100 hours into this, at which point I decided to just go and beat the game because I have a backlog. But if I didn't own many other games, I could have easily played dozens of hours more. A huge world to run around in, various guilds to join and run quests for, various skills to improve through use, some interesting quests, and people in the world that react to your actions. The levelling system (which rewards you with better stats for NOT staying in-class) is blatantly stupid, but aside from that, Oblivion is a fantastic game, and anyone who doesn't hate RPGs should pick it up when it's on sale.

content:
5, 2016
												It is a great game. So far I have around 40 hours on it and I have completed the main quest, thieves guild, dark brotherhood, arena, mages guild and almost the shivering isles. The review will be in 6 sections- graphics, combat/magic, guilds, dlc, main quest, overall.Graphics:Obviously due to its age oblivion is not looking great but it has aged quite well and the graphics does not change the fact that it is a great game. Also this can be touched up with mods.Combat/Magic:The combat is not great and not particularly enjoyable. I therefore enchanted my self an OP bow early that does a ton of damage spread over a large radius(it one hits pretty much everything in a certain radius from the guy that was hit with the arrow). However I like the fact that you can cast spells whilst having other weapons equipped unlike in skyrim.Guilds:This will be an oblivion to skyrim comparisonthieves guild is better in oblivion- you steal more, get better rewards and it is less of the dungeon crawling.dark brotherhood I would say is equal. In oblivion it is long but entertaining whereas skyrim it is short but sweetmages guild is better thsn the college of winterhold. The recommendations can be tedious but the rest is a lot better.fighters guild is do not know about as I have not done it.Arena is better than the s**t bards collegeDLC:This will be a skyrim to oblivion comparisonOblivion has a lot of useless dlc that pretty much equals hearthfire so i will only be talking about Knights of the nine, dawnguard, shivering isles and dragonborn.Shivering Isles is amazing and the best part of oblivion. It at the very least equals dragonborn another amazing dlc.Knights of the nine looks great whereas I did not much like dawnguard.Main Quest:Oblivion main story was a better plot the skyrim and felt more important. However the oblivion gates mechanic and the dragons both got boring. I enjoyed playing through both of them a lot and to be honest if you enjoyed either of them you will like the other.Overall: If you like skyrim do not be afraid to try oblivion. It might be tough to get used to but it is definitely on par with skyrim and if produced tomorrow would probably be a better game.

content:
y 24
												Many mechanics are flawed, the graphics are out-dated, it's buggy as hell, little to no controller support, every enemy is an arrow sponge past mid-difficulty level, and combat is terrible. You may be wondering at this point why I gave this game a positive rating... it's because this game is beautiful. This is the game you bring home to your mother, unlike that trash Skyrim (I love Skyrim). This is the game you cuddle up on a couch to, playing all night on xbox or playstation because you can't cuddle with a mouse and keyboard. This is the game that taught many people, including myself, what an rpg could truly be. This game did not have the extroardinary success that Skyrim had, nor did it redefine how gigantic an rpg could be like Morrowind, but what it did do is further push the standards, raising the bar even further than ever believed possible. This game helped further shape what it means to be an open world rpg today and like all Bethesda Game Studio's games it is a timeless classic that no matter how ugly, old, or broken it may seem; you have to give it a chance. Escape prison, help what was believed to be a simple farm boy become the emperor he was born to be, become a professional thief, help and fight daedric princes, join a guild, explore the world, become an arena grand champion, become a lethal assasin, become a true madman, and CLOSE SHUT THE JAWS...      OF OBLIVION!

content:
9, 2016
												Favorite thing about the game is how easily you can get lost in it. You think you're going to go on foot to reach your next destination, and suddenly you encounter a dozen different things on the way to distract you no matter which route you take. Now you're on a whole new sub-objective, and get turned around. Nothing to do but keep dealing with the other sub-objectives now right?One downside is the main story isn't the strongest part of the game, so it's easy to not care and instead do other things. With that said, if you do all the side missions related to the story, you're going to get a huge amount of lore and background in the game world which does balance out if you're into that.

content:
30, 2015
												I personally think Oblivion is better than Skyrim, though Skyrim is less buggy and better in some ways. Obviously the graphics aren't as good as in Skyrim though they can be improved with mods if you don't like them. There are a few things that make Oblivion better than Skyrim in my opinion:More spell types and the ability to create your own spellsMore weapon/armour typesWeapon/armour degradation (must be repaired with hammers)Better guild storylines (the Dark Brotherhood guild especially is amazing, pure art)Bigger and more interesting cities (Imperial City is HUGE, so much stuff to steal as a thief)Another big deal for me is proper class distinction. Oblivion is traditional to the fantasy RPG genre in that it has set classes (or you can make your own if you wish) such as warrior, mage, thief and many other hybrid classes such as spellsword (mixture of destructive magic and swords) and battlemage (mixture of heavy armour and supporting magic) and so on and so on. This is a big deal for me because in fantasy role-playing games your class is who/what you are. It defines your character. In Oblivion, if you take warrior (with primary attributes of strength and vitality) then you're a warrior, pure and simple. You can use magic and increase your magic attributes if you like, but you'll never be as good with it as a proper mage class, it will merely be a minor supporting aspect. Plus wearing armour in Oblivion makes magic spells less powerful; the heavier the armour the less powerful spells become. In Skyrim, the ability to be every class all at once made me feel like I didn't have a specific class/role. One moment I could be an awesome warrior with a big axe, the next moment I could take my armour off and be an awesome mage, and in the next slip on some light armour and use a bow and sneak and be an awesome thief/assassin. I feel more at home in the traditional RPG custom of specific classes. It feels natural to me because it's what those games have always been based around. Like in real life, everybody has a specific role, making each person feel unique in some way. In real life you have carpenters, salesmen, lawyers and so on and so on and in traditional RPG's you have warriors, mages, thieves, assassins, alchemists - everybody has a unique role.There are some things I don't like about Oblivion though. The ruthless level-scaling means that when you are level 1, every other person/creature in the game is also level 1. When you are level 99, everybody else is level 99. You never feel truly in danger and you never feel truly heroic because everybody else is always just as strong as you are. Fortunately this is fixed perfectly in an amazing mod called Oscuro's Oblivion Overhaul - I highly recommend this mod. I would never play Oblivion without it. It removes level-scaling entirely and makes the world an extremely dangerous and harsh place for newbies, but as you gain levels you become higher level and more powerful. So at level 1, you may run in to a level 3 mage bandit who kicks your butt. But when you get to level 10 he is still level 3 and you can show him who's the boss.

												My favorite game of all time, Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion is truly a masterpiece. I have spent thousands of hours playing through it on the Xbox 360 back when that was a thing, and will likely match that feat again on the PC.The gameplay is stellar, the explorable world is massive, beautiful, and filled with interesting dungeons, quests, and fights, the AI is revolutionary, and overall it is just extraordinarily fun.My only gripes with it are the graphics, which are universally agreed to have not aged well (a problem solved relatively easily with mods), and that Bethesda has yet to remaster it (here's hoping).Don't get me wrong, Skyrim is amazing, a work of art in and of itself, but it doesn't quite compare to Oblivion for me. In fact, no game does, and I hate to think no other game ever will. But whether or not this is the case, I am glad to have played Oblivion in my lifetime.

content:
9, 2012
												Pretty much the very definition of an open-world RPG. Cyrodiil is massive, and is a joy to adventure through and even too look at. There is a lot of detail in the world and it is clear that a lot of time and love went into making an authentic looking, immersive fantasy world. That being said, the most important part of any RPG is the depth of the character customization and leveling, and Oblivion does a fine job at that. You can choose your race and change your appearence with a good amount of customization. The skill customization is deep enough to be able to play as seperate playstyles as a nimble theif who is great at lockpicking and a bow, a knight who wears heavy armour and wields massive battle axes, or a magic using mage. Having your skills level up the more you use them just makes sense, and has your character develop naturally, evolving on how you're playing the game without breaking up gameplay. The other most important thing in any RPG are the stories and sidequests. There are enough sidequests to make your head spin, and a lot of them do have interesting stories to tell. A lot of them I don't want to give away, so you'll have to find them on your own. There is also a great amount of items you can find and loot. From different weapons like swords and axes to different sets of armour, there's a lot to find in this game.Now for the things it didn't do particularly well. The story of the main questline isn't really that interesting, atleast to me. It just felt too predictable, and the segments where you actually travel into Oblivion itself were all really boring. The beautiful thing is, however, if you don't like the main questline, you can just skip it. An open-world game this massive is also prone to have some bugs. There are not a huge amount of them, just enough to warrant a mention. There are also a number of quests that aren't too captivating, but again, with this much content, you can't strike gold everytime.  There also seem to be a lack of voice actors and actresses in this game. There can't be more than ten of them; you will be hearing the same actors speak for totally different characters constantly. Combat also isn't the deepest thing in this game, it's usually just mindless swinging at enemies until they die first. Ranged combat with bows and magical spells fare a little better, but not by much.Now, this is the Game of the Year edition, so it comes with the two major expansions for the game. Knights of the Nine I didn't particularly care, mainly because I didn't find the storyline particularly interesting and it didn't add very much content-wise. Shivering Isles, however... holy crap. That's one of the best expansions to any open-world game ever with a very interesting new world, lots of interesting stories to tell, and overall just tonnes of new content.This game is worth your time and money. Nothing beats going on an adventure that you craft yourself, and Oblivion does a fantastic job at that.

 im only 5 hours in and thought i should make a first impressions review! i have grown up with the elder scrolls games and none have captured me as much as this. the start is fantastic. you awake in a prison, no idea how you got there. you get mocked and made fun of by a dark elf! Assasins have came and killed the emperors known sons and tried to kill the emperor! fortunatly he has been brought down to the prisons by the blades to escape through the secret tunnel in your cell. you are called out and questioned by the emperor but its ok he has seen you in his "visions". you are trusted to escape and follow them down the tunnel. you are then told to stop following and cut through a broken wall. along that way you fight skeevers and goblins. you acquire your first set of weapons and armour and head out. along the way you meet up with the emperor and the blades and help battle along side them.  ***SPOILER*** Unfortunatly the emperor is killed by mythic dawn / daedra and you are given the amulet and told to give it ito jaufree. so fast forward and you close an oblivion gate and dig deeper into the mythic dawn.... The Verdict so far.. so so far im enjoying how in depth thew game is. the combat is actually aged decently well and holds up. the story is capturing and brings you in quickly, the cities and towns actually give you feels. i remember walking around imperial city for the first time on xbox 360 and it meant nothing to me. i was young and only likes killing and stealing :D but now i get a warmish feeling from everyone greeting you and acknowledging who you are! Overall so far its an easy 9/10 only con is that camera angle sometimes and the slow movement until you level it up :D

content:
ry 11, 2015
												I know that Steam says (at the time of writing this review) that I only have about 21.5 hours on record, but I assure you that I put hundreds of hours into this game on my Xbox 360 before I got my PC. This game is undoubtedly one of my favorite and most likely one of the greatest games to ever be released. I can almost guarantee that you will like this game if you are an Open-World RPG fan. Let's open this game up and take a look inside one of the best isntallments in the Elder Scrolls Series. Gameplay:The most important element in a video game is the gameplay, and the Elder Scrolls IV has that down to a science. Sure, this game does a bit more hand-holding compared to its predecessors, which is completely undeniable. This game also has a simplified dialogue system and, in my opinion, terrible voice acting, but do not let these cons detract from the great game this is. Oblivion, being one of the only titles in the series to not be named after its main setting, offers amazing exploration and rewards it nicely, especially for you dungeon-crawlers. With the vast and open world of Cyrodiil at your fingertips, you can explore and discover some of the most beautiful and historical ruins, forts, hamlets, cities, castles, rivers, lakes, caves, mines, and many other dungeonesque sites. you won't just find enemies at these sites, though. Like I said before, exploration is rewarded.As for a replay-value: you will never play this game the same way twice. Sure, with the lack of "radiant" quests that are present in Skyrim (Oblivion's 'sequel') you basically know what's going to happen in any given quest you've already done, but you don't have to approach these quests the same way you did before. Perhaps in one playthrough you are a battlemage that wields a Dwarven axe whilst sending a barrage of lightning bolts towards your enemies, but in another playthrough you are an assassin that wields an Elven bow whilst sending a barrage of poisoned arrows towards your foes. With the class system in this game, you won't ever have to be the same character twice. I have had several different characters in this game, and each time I have played I experienced everything differently than before.Combat:The combat in Oblivion makes so much more sense than it did in Morrowind (Oblivion's 'prequel') in which you would swing your weapon into an enemies face and it wouldn't even phase them, but here in Oblivion, every hit is rewarded with a blade covered in blood and a scream from the other end of your sword. While the game doesn't do a very good job of challenging the player in combat as long as they follow the course provided for them, but there are places in this in which you will be absolutely brutalized if you go in unprepared. This is where exploring and being prepared come into play. Bows and arrows, swords, daggers, magic staves, maces, axes, or your own bloody fists are all at your disposal when it comes to combat in this game. Each comes with its own positive and its own negative, but the more experienced you become with your weapon of choice, the more rewarding your trudge through the cons will be. Choosing a weapon choice and becoming proficient with it is always a great choice, but, of course, you are not forced to do this. If you want to use swords and axes at the beginning and then halfway through decide that you want to use bows and arrows, go for it! You won't be held to the weapons you use in the beginning, it will just make the journey a bit more difficult on your way to mastering your new weapon type.Finally for combat, there is the Arena. This is perhaps one of the most popular features in ES4, and rightfully so. At any point, you can enter the Arena, join the team and fight for glory and money in a gladiator style throwdown. This is a great way to not only get yourself into the swing of things when it comes to combat, but it can also help you level up pretty quickly near the beginning of the game; be careful though, because the further you get in the Arena, the more challenging the enemies become!Graphics:I won't lie to you, the graphics in this game aren't the best, though at the time of its release (I remember very well) these graphics were some of the best I had ever seen! Without the proper mods, this game makes everyone look like they have  a potato-face and makes blood look like a powdery substance rather than a liquid. Fret not, though, like I said, mods are a beautiful thing when it comes to this game. I downloaded a buttload of mods and now my Oblivion looks almost as good as Skyrim. Don't worry, graphics have no effect on the gameplay anyways, unless graphics are very important to you.Immersion:As is the tradition when it comes to Elder Scrolls titles, immersion is a key feature in Oblivion. From the small details like being able to pick a random magical gem off its stand in a random tomb or being able to go for a stroll and pick flowers and mushrooms, to being able to commit murder on any unsuspecting NPC for no good reason and then going to prison because of your vile actions. Your actions have consequences, and almost everything you do will have an effect on how the world treats and sees you.Have a beer, read a book, eat dinner, spend the night in a hotel, buy a horse, ride that horse to another town and repeat the process. Any small action you can think of, you can most likely do it (no f@pping guys...)Performance:Considering this game came out almost 11 years ago, I'm pretty sure everyone on here will be able to run this game on at least the lowest settings and still hit 60 fps, but who knows.-Ratings-Gameplay: 9/10Combat: 8/10Graphics: 10/10 (At the time of its release)Immersion: 9/10Performance: 10/10=Conclusion=Definitely give this game a chance. If you're still on the edge of whether or not you want to buy it, watch some gameplay on Youtube, or look for some streams on Twitch, you are guaranteed to find something online somewhere that allows you to get a glimpse of the amazing game that Oblivion truly is.

content:
ber 28, 2016
Pros Questline stories & characters --- Though it remains straightforward and has a simpler plot that still doesn't quite reach its full potential, the main questline manages to overtake TES3's for presentation alone.	Everything is made up for in the game's countless side quests, which are easily the best in the series. Comical premises and unforgettable characters are plentiful, from helping a Wood Elf with his paranoia to quietly disposing of a mansion's guests by turning them against one another. Even the faction questlines, which were more errand-based in TES3, return with greater depth.	Since all the DLC is bundled with this release, it's also worth praising the Knights of the Nine and Shivering Isles expansions for the amount of content they add to the already immense base game. The latter also contains some of the most outrageous quests and characters in the series and is often considered the best video game expansion of all time. Soundtrack --- Possibly the best soundtrack in the series. The tracks are memorable and greatly enhance the atmosphere, especially in the overworld, where exploration is accompanied by a relaxing piece that always feels appropriate. Dungeons and cities now have their own unique track playlists unlike in TES3. Overworld --- As the geographical center of Tamriel, the province of Cyrodiil has a variety of landscapes thanks to the regions it borders; evergreen forests, marshes, snowy mountains, and seaport beaches. In addition, the Oblivion realms of Mehrunes Dagon and Sheogorath feature volcanic deadlands and an island straight out of a fantasy painting respectively. Visuals --- The textures on architecture and characters aren't the highest quality considering the detail of the models, but the landscape visuals can be stunning due to a graphical style that does not shy away from its color palette. Modding support --- Modding support returns for TES4 with improved functionality for mod creators and users.Neutral Gameplay --- Compared to TES3, its more modern approach makes it more tolerable for newcomers to the series, though at a cost of skills, attributes, and equipment variety. Dungeons --- More atmospheric and filled with more areas of interest compared to TES3. However, there are also fewer distinct dungeon types which may increase the sense of repetition in not just architecture, but enemy types as well.Cons Leveling system --- At higher player character levels, armors, weapons, and enemies become phased out. This leads to a loss in variety and item value when even the common bandit carries some of the best equipment in the game.ConclusionOf the three TES games released on the Gamebryo/Creation Engine so far, The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion is the most well-rounded. The gameplay can be described as "one step forward, one step back" as not everything survived the transition from its predecessor. Judgment on whether the additions are a net positive will come down to each individual player familiar with the series.TES4 also chooses a more traditional fantasy setting for its province as opposed to the imaginative, exotic land of Vvardenfell that was featured in TES3. Enemy types also seem more generic as a result. This is corrected in the Shivering Isles expansion where nothing is constrained by preestablished lore, allowing the developers to implement their wildest creations.While it doesn't have the same depth in its lore and world-building as TES3, TES4's presentation and incredible questlines make it a contender for being the best in the series. With more modern gameplay mechanics and visuals, it's admittedly also one of the best starting points in the series for newcomers.With hundreds of hours of content, it's highly recommended to buy The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion.

content:
er 27, 2013
												I have played Oblivion for about 80+ hours, completed The Shivering Isles and the main questline. I still haven't gotten around to completing EVERY quest in the game, but I got most of it.In Oblivion, you start out in a prison cell after a small monologue and character creator. An NPC mocks your choice of race and then the emporer himself comes to your cell. The Septim line is being attacked by an unknown force, and he is escaping the city to survive. Destiny destiny destiny, tutorial, class picking, bla bla bla... and then you finally are put into the world. When you first step out, you'll either say one of two things: "Wow! This is amazing!" Or: "Wow! These graphics suck!" Oblivion is a dated classic, and doesn't look as good as games do now. But, if you can look past that, you can really find a gem.Like many RPGs, they either leave much to be desired or a years worth of adventure. The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion is full of places to go and things to do. But, this is where some problems arise. With so much to do leaves a lot to be desired, and some quests end up being your typical dungeon crawler. But the idea of having an open world to explore and do whatever you want is overwhelming and terrific. Every 1 in 3 quests though did have a great amount of originality to it, from stealing a prized gem in the imperial castle itself or going to another dimension to stop a man from destroying the world. It really is amazing if you can look past the typical dungeon quests that get boring after a while.Finally, the gameplay; the meat of the review. Oblivion's leveling is complicated at best and very hard to do sometimes. It tends to be stressful, and quite honestly, dull. Skyrim had done it much better. Swordplay tends to be just slashing around a sword hoping to hit. Magic is cool, though, as if you can get into the mages college, you can customize your spells. Archery takes precision and is pretty fun to try out. The difficulty slider in the options menu is literally just "How many times do you want to hit this guy until he goes down?" There is no reason whatsoever to put it up, just keep it 1/4 up to make it better. Fighting is fun in general, TL:DR.In the end, Oblivion is fun. It's really hard to critique this without coming across as a fan. But, I am a big fan of RPGs and you should take this review in the eyes of one. I can't see a huge FPS fan getting this and having as much fun as I did. This is really only a game for people who are not new to RPGs in general and like the idea of them. This game is a great game though, and I do fully recommend it from the eyes of an RPG fan.

												The Elder Scrolls 4: Oblivion is an open world RPG set in Bethesda's original fantasy setting of Tamriel. This was the first Elder Scrolls Game i ever played which was back in 2011 (on PS3) and it got me into the series in general. It was released in 2006 and it was the first of game of its kind I have ever played (open world RPGs in this case) and it was the last in the series to have the class system and the first to not have the dice roll based combat like Morrowind, Daggerfall, and Arena (Elder Scrolls Arena and Daggerfall are both free by the way if you want to try, Daggerfall is amazing).  There are 9 races and you can create your own custom class and this game is very mod friendly as well so if you want to buy this game I recommend you do especially if you are new to the Elder Scrolls series considering it isn't as in depth as the first 3 games in the series.
