y 1
												Do yourself a favor - and don't blast through the main questline. If you do, you'll have the game beat in like 8-10 hours. Oblivion is the game before Skyrim and has a great deal of content to offer you. Explore out in the wilderness, steal some stuff, kill a person because "mother" told you to. It's all there really. Magic is the most powerful of all things in this game, and made more powerful by the ability to craft your own spells. You can make yourself an unstoppable force with weapon/armor from enchanting.Go back to the days where you can find magical equipment that does it's own special thing like a "underwater breathing ring" and explore the vast underwater in search of chests and caves. This game is fun - seriously. The only difficulty I could see with folks, is if they played Skyrim before this - the graphics and such... well... they're worse, which is to be expected. Some find this acceptable, while others run away with eyes bleeding. But really - it was fun, took a good while before I got tired of it.

content:
4, 2016
												Oblivion is a wonderful game for many of the previously stated reasons. It combines decent combat with interesting quest lines and likable npc's. This, however, is not why I would suggest it. Any number of other RPG's have better combat, better fleshed out quests, or more realistic npc's. No, what sets this game apart is it's open world. With many other "open world" RPG's you are still pressed to follow the main quest line and, once it's done, you're done and left with little else to do. This adds to how immersive the game is and, above all else, stresses the "Role-playing" aspect of "Role-Playing Game".  So what the combat isn't as impressive as that of Dragon Age? You don't have to min-max in Oblivion: you just play and enjoy the beautiful vistas of Cyrodill. I would also like to add that there are literally thousands of mods that improve upon every problem present with the game and even improve on the good aspects. (P.S. There's no Workshop support, so you have to use a mod manager and stuff. I personally suggest OBMM (Oblivion Mod Manager) and the use of the Nexus mods webpage.)Just wanted to say, I nominate this game for the "Stands the Test of Time" steam award. After more than 10 years, it's still one of my favourite games.

												[Full Review of The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion]Graphics:This game came out in 2006 so the graphics are obviously going to be dated by this point, but if you've played Bethesda RPGs before, you already know that the graphics aren't going to be the strongest aspect of the game anyway. Aside from graphical quality, the landscape is bright and beautiful as well as very detailed, considering it's size. Certain towns and locations obviously got more attention than others though and the characters look . . . not . . . good. However this game is huge and features a tremendous amount of content so it gets a slight pass. - 7/10Audio:Again, if you've played a Bethesda RPG before (specifically an Elder Scrolls game) you already have a pretty good idea of what to expect. The soundtrack is nothing short of amazing - it always is in Elder Scrolls' games. So, no surprises there - Jeremy Soule is a god amongst men and all that. Sound effects are also good but I wasn't too crazy about the voice acting in this one, though maybe that's just me. Extremely strong audio presentation overall. - 9/10Gameplay:It's your standard RPG with a whole mess of choices to make while creating your character including race, class, attributes, ect. There are many options but it ultimately boils down to the basic warrior, mage, and rogue classes - though you can use any style of weapons, armor, and magic regardless of class, which is a mechanic unique to Bethesda I believe. Combat is nothing special but, then again, it hardly ever is in RPGs. Exploration, however, is one of the strongest aspects of Oblivion and what ultimately makes the game as addicting as it is. You will feel like a real adventurer traveling across Cyrodil saving the world, as well as a few NPCs, along the way. - 8/10Story:So, basically, you are the chosen one and it's your destiny to save the world. Super original right? But in all seriousness, the main quest line is pretty interesting and I found myself completely invested in the story by the time it was over. In addition to the main quest line there are also several others (Dark Brotherhood, Thieves Guild, Mages Guild, Fighters Guild, ect.) in addition to TONS of other side quests. All in all, there is a lot of story here, most of which is pretty interesting. - 10/10Replayability:It's an RPG . . . and it's made by Bethesda. Just those two facts alone should tell you that you are not going to be leaving your computer screen for quite a few days, should you choose to pick this game up. I've personally played hundreds of hours of Oblivion across all platforms and still haven't completed all the quests. Also, there's real incentive to play multiple times since there are numerous races (all with special abilities) and some really fun quests that you'll probably want to replay but not a lot of key decisions to make throughout the game, at least for an RPG. So, yeah, there's replayability here. - 9/10Overall:Oblivion wasn't declared GOTY by everyone for no reason. The explorations mechanics, interesting storyline, and immersive universe all come together perfectly to, once again, give us an addicting role-play experience. If you've never played it for some reason, you need to pick up the GOTY edition like, right now. - 8.6/10

												My first and probably my personal favourite Elder Scrolls game, though I can see why other titles in the series may be considered better. The experience on the 360 was alright, but if you plan on buying it on PC be ready to mod the ♥♥♥♥ out of the game. Some things feel okay for consoles but not so much for the PC like the UI and graphical fidelity, then there are some other quality of life things too you might want. One thing that I found can't quite be fixed with mods is the horrid level scaling. Sure there are a few combat and level scaling overhauls and what not but they're a bit of a pain to install and get working and they tend to either not fix the problem or make it worse by making basic enemies like bandits tough as ♥♥♥♥ from the start. But enough of my rant, either way if you haven't played another Elder Scrolls game you'll probably enjoy this one, but if you have then you will probably want to mod it in some way or another. DEfinitely better than Skyrim though, 10/10 GOTYAY

content:
er 5, 2015
												I recently wrote a very long review on The Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind Game of the Year Edition so this time is the turn of the next chapter in the Elder Scrolls series, Oblivion. I must be honest I had never played Oblivion before I purchased it here. I had played Morrowind for years and ended up jumping straight to Skyrim (both on the Xbox/PS3 depending on which one you are referring too) I don't think this was as much a case of oversight as a little research showed me that Oblivion, despite it being a good game, was just released at a time where RPG games where becoming the norm and the market was flooded with a million sub-par attempts. The same could be said for the precursor to Skyrim, Dragonborn, which suffered a similar fate. Not that it really damaged its' reputation at all as Oblivion is still one of the most highly praised games of the entire Elder Scrolls series. I really settled into this game well. It didn't take long to get going with the first quests of the main storyline which I decided to complete first. It was well laid out and the actual storyline itself was gripping. From semi breaking out of prison to finding the hidden Septim son Martin all the way to the crux of the main storyline where you get one of the most amazing pieces of CGI in a cut scene. I won't go to far into it for those that have not played it yet or have not gotten that far but all I will say is Golden Dragon... (A wimpy girly moment led me to go "ooooh" LOL). Now would be a good time to mention the graphics and scenery which are stunning.After all of that though, which takes a fair amount of time but is no-where near as long as the mainline in Morrowind, you can then go on to do the two extra DLC's which come complete with the Game of the Year Edition. The first one was The Shivering Isles which is by far my favourite part of the entire game. I just loved everything about it. From the insane world created by Lord Sheogorath to the way the guy speaks. I literally had moments during this part of the game where I was in fits of laughter at some of the things he would say randomly whilst trying to help you prevent the Graymarch.The icing on the cake of this one is that you get to become Lord Sheogorath, but don't worry you aren't insane and you can come and go into Cyrodill and the Shivering Isles as you please. The last add on is The Knight of the Nine. This is by far the biggest let down of the whole game. All you do is pretty much run around getting blessings from 9 different shrines and then finding old relics of the Divine Crusader all of which together will allow you to kill Umaril the Unfeathered of which at the end leaves you with a rather large and heavy set of armour and that is pretty much the end of the DLC. This, to me, was just not worth the time put in to find everything (it took a while as this one has little prompt) and was just anti-climatic at the end. Of course after all of the mainline and add ons were completed I set about clearing up sidequests and doing things for the Fighters and Mages guilds. I also went to the Imperial City Arena and became Grand Champion because why not. But I felt that all of the side quests and the Fighters/Mages guild stuff was just all very mundane and boring and really lacked the kind of thought that had gone into the mainlines in such a way where it almost felt like the creators had, had enough at this point and just wanted it finished. All of this is good fun though, even if walking around everywhere being called Champion, lord, hero, knight, sister ect does get a little tiresome, but of course once the mainline and the DLCs are done there really isn't all that much left to do and really in my eyes at least I felt that the game had ended for me.My only major complaint though is that it seems that this game suffers from some pretty irking bugs in the quests. I got stuck numerous times where the game just wouldn't progress despite me doing what it asked only to look it up and find that countless others had the same problem. Of course most of the bugs had patches made to fix them but I didn't have time for that so opted for the slight cheat route of using the Console to force the quest along to the next point which works but of course can end up cutting out a huge portion of a quest or leaving you a little confused as to what to do next, in some cases it almost led me to do a quest backwards getting other journal entries about something I had done previously.I must add that there are hundreds of tutorials and tips and cheats online for the game which do help to make a bit of an interesting character or to get you through a rather tough patch but ultimately it is far more fun to run around and try and do as much as you can for yourself.One last thing.... Keep and eye out for the UNICORN. It's the only one in the entire gamePS. Why make riding the horses so complicated. You have to control it with the keys alone unlike the character which you can control with both the mouse and keys... This would have been a little more helpful as I spent a lot of time getting stuck on rocks and with the horse looking the wrong way despite what I was telling it to do. Also I'm pretty sure being on a horse was slower than running. On the plus side I did end up with a series of horses and people following me around all of which would fight/protect/get in the way if I was attacked which made for some interesting moments.

content:
, 2016
												As someone who almost spend 100h on this game, I can seriously say that to the elder scrolls series, this game is the mario 3 to the super mario games. A formula that works and is fun, but it's just better and a more refined game. I certaintly think Skyrim has made even more improvements to the franchise, but it'll still never catch the charm this game delivered. The epicly crafted open world of Cyrodiil is open, cozy, natural and rural, the way I like it. Dungeons and its loot aren't as unique as Skyrim, yet they still offer great fun. Great story, but I think no one can argue about that, in specific with the dark brotherhood. Character creation isn't perfect, but it's more open than SKyrim, music's top notch and for a 2006 game; it's graphics are great and detailed. So buy it and have yourself an immerive journey through one of the best RPG-games of the 21st century, it's worth every single penny!

content:
r 13, 2014
												As you can tell from the hours I have put into this game, I have greatly enjoyed every moment of it. Although, some quests can be quite challenging, your friendly and not so friendly community will give you information to help you on your way. That of course, you have to build your points in each level you achieve, such as personality, strength, intelligence and so on. The not so challenging, but would I say repetitive quest was definitely the 'Finding Your Roots' quest, where I was constantly being told to collect 10, and then 20, and then 30, and lastly 40 Nirnroots, and dreadfully being told I can  collect more Nirnroot for future references. After spending 3 hours on the entire quest, I think I will leave it be for now. A proud moment for me was when I finally found all the ingredients to cure my Vampirism. Seek that choice at your own cost! But most of all, when you close all the Oblivion gates, that is a great achievement. The game itself presents a lot of adventure, a huge variety of quests, a lot of places to explore and lots of dangerous species to kill which makes the entire game as a whole, a really great game play. As part of the Elder Scrolls, I recommend playing this game first out of the series.

content:
28, 2011
												I loved Fallout 3, and I loved Morrowind, but Oblivion has actually stuck with me more than both. A tour of its most recognisable locations and the early quests would be pretty uninspiring, but if you live in that world for a while, it has an incredible sense of place. And it does feel like living. The total freedom of what to specialise in, what goals to pursue, how to achieve them – none of those things are unique individually, but put them together and you have something that’s more of a world than a game. That will continue to excite me more than anything else in the genre until Skyrim comes along and does it all again.

ber 15, 2016
												Saved Bruma from being demolished by a Great Oblivion Gate... so I destroyed the gate, Daedra invasion stopped. However... that was not the end as the Empire descended into CIVIL WAR whilst Daedra were attacking them all at once, but they paused for a moment all because someone accidentally hit the Emperor, then everyone started to battle each other, slashing swords and clad at everybody and knocking any and all unconcious (or killed) whilst the Daedra just stand there literally watching, with me included.Thought I'd try to talk to one but I got the "BE QUICK ABOUT IT MORTAL" approach. He wasn't very interested in speaking.All I saw was hordes of guards from all the different cities rushing from each end and more and more began joining in the frey, including Imperial Soldiers. In the end, when the Emperor was knocked unconcious, everyone started clapping and celebrating and moved on with their daily lives, while Emperor Martin Septim just laid on the ground, ♥♥♥♥ing comatose. Then, the Daedra and the guards started fighting each other and it started happening again.The Elder Scrolls: Oblivion is just fantastic. lmfao_____So, I have completed the Dark Brotherhood questline. However, I was supposed to wait for someone to assassinate at a certain time in one of the cities. So, I used the waiting option. Ofcourse it wouldn't kill me for just waiting a bit (WROOONNNGGG).So, after waiting, battle music started and I was ontop of one of the houses. I saw someone at the last second, pulling out a bow and firing an arrow straight on my face when I was ontop of a three/four story building. It was such a strong blow that it lifted me off my feet, casted me down to the ground and I died. Bloody hell!Reloaded from the same waiting save, managed to get out the way before it would happen again (lol). Killed the lad, Lucius randomly popped out of thin air when I killed one person and started screaming that I was a traitor I "shouldn't" have exactly killed the person I should have. He preached on about how he was going to kill me and then started to say "Oh, you're confused aren't you. I should be killing you but something tells me I shouldn't be!"So ofcourse, Lucius is blabbering on about a plan to catch a member of the Brotherhood, so I inadvertintly agree, no doubt. So, as I pressed forth, I turn around to see him actually RUNNING OFF into the distance when he's describing his plan. So ofcourse, I wouldn't exactly figure it out because herp-a-derp master of stealthiness just decided to go for a jog.His voice got lower in sound and all I heard was: "The Dark Brotherhood will rise again! NOW GGGOOOooooooooo-" and he then leaves the city. So I do too, heading to my next quest location.So, I realized what I had to do eventually, but in the top left of my screen, it then stated that "Lucius <Insert second name here> is unconcious." atleast half a dozon times over, just after he stated he needed to go into hiding. He didn't get very far, then.Better than Skyrim. xD

content:
1, 2016
												I might be a little biased because this was my first elder scrolls, but Oblivion is one of the best games I have ever played - it practicaly dominated my life in middle school. I use to play it on the xbox 360, and I wouldn't be suprised if I have put 1000+ hours into the game. Its combat system is clunky, its leveling impractical, and its lack of voice actors hilarious - but I love every bit of The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion. If you come from playing Skyrim, beware: this game is not the same as Skyrim, and you should have reasonable expectations of Oblivion. I have had a few friends dislike the game because "it doesn't have smithing?! how am I supposed to get good armor?! This game sucks!" In my opinion the reason that some people don't like this game is because they can't appreciate it on its own, and think that it's not good because it doesn't have some of the features that Skyrim does. Don't get me wrong, the game has flaws. But as I said before, I love this game, and I would certianly reccomend it to anyone who likes a good RPG.

content:
er 2, 2016
												I originally played this game for over 200 hours when it first came out. This is truly one of my favorites of favorites the story and scenery are far more superior to Skyrim, but the graphics are a little dated but well enough (before modding) as well as the game engine a little buggy (I recommend the unofficial patch to fix). I went through another play through and modded it to look better and I can really say it looks better with mods almost as good as Skyrim after I was done with it. I’m also using Xpadder to map the keyboard keys to a XBOX one controller and I seem to be getting great results with it. I would say all and all this game is a great experience 10/10 for an open world RPG with no remorse starting out. you will get lost or try to wander at first, but try to stick to the main quest for a little bit till you get a little more powerful before wandering off.The thieves guild and dark brotherhood quest are some of the best game play in the series to date, and the add on DLCs are some of the best pieces of work I’ve seen take an already brilliant captivating game to a whole other level over and beyond  11/10 what it is and make it that much better. Note: If you played this on Xbox or PS3 Port, you my friend were bamboozled with sub-par graphics and lower res that’s just atrocious and downright unplayable. The PC copy (GOTY) edition with some mods (not to many) to make it look nicer, I’ll play it all day long and revisit time and time again.

content:
1, 2016
												I might be a little biased because this was my first elder scrolls, but Oblivion is one of the best games I have ever played - it practicaly dominated my life in middle school. I use to play it on the xbox 360, and I wouldn't be suprised if I have put 1000+ hours into the game. Its combat system is clunky, its leveling impractical, and its lack of voice actors hilarious - but I love every bit of The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion. If you come from playing Skyrim, beware: this game is not the same as Skyrim, and you should have reasonable expectations of Oblivion. I have had a few friends dislike the game because "it doesn't have smithing?! how am I supposed to get good armor?! This game sucks!" In my opinion the reason that some people don't like this game is because they can't appreciate it on its own, and think that it's not good because it doesn't have some of the features that Skyrim does. Don't get me wrong, the game has flaws. But as I said before, I love this game, and I would certianly reccomend it to anyone who likes a good RPG.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 11, 2016
												This is the game that got me addicted to the Elder Scrolls series. The game is visually stunning and full of appealing colors. The world is gigantic, the modding community is gigantic, and a ton of quests to keep you busy for hundreds of hours. The game however isn't quite perfect, the RPG system isn't that great, the ending was extremely anti-climatic (something Bethesda is known for), and there are a ton of glitches. Fortunately there are unofficial patches that attempt to fix most of these issues, but there's always going to be glitches overlooked. But the game is still more fun than frustrating. I do highly recommend you play Oblivion, it's not as good as Skyrim, but it's at least more appealing to look at.

content:
er 21, 2015
												After Morrowind, this game was a big step forward. Much-improved graphics and gameplay (plus, no cliff-gliders!).  In Morrowind,  I don't think had a truly central story-line. Oblivion changes all of that, giving a core story, many side-quests and the early stages of playing a monk character, which was even better in Skyrim thanks to a mod.Too bad the idea of The Workshop mods hadn't surfaced yet. Thank god for The Elder Scrolls Wiki, which finally gave you a bit of a leg up when you needed it. Good voice acting throughout, with Patrick Stewart and Sean Bean included, just to mention two.  My younger son refused to play the game for awhile, believing Morrowind was "pure" Elder Scroll game. After he got, he never looked backed.I've recently started a new game as I was having issues with Skyrim: Legendary Edition (some of my old Skyrim files still in the library caused it, I think) and i plan on playing this Bethesda game until I can get its sequel program up and running again.One nice thing: nowhere near as buggy as Elder Scrolls 3, with few crashes and I think its playability has stood the test of time. Having the game of the year helps, too.I give a 8 out of ten septims!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 22, 2015
												It hits that sweet spot.You know, that one right between morrowind and skyrim. Morrowind was great, but had just too many unnecessary hoops to jump through. Skyrim was also a platinum quality game, but it's instant gratification based gameplay left out that special something from the deeper aspects of traditional RPGs. Oblivion has fairly well aged graphics (even better with mod support), relatively lively combat, a lot of deeper RPG elements compacted and presented by a user friendly UI, and all that delicious Bethesda game freedom. Other RPGs might beat it in combat fluidity or graphic style, but this is as close as you'll get to ole pen-and-paper fun without sacrificing any ease of use. Doesn't have spears though.

er 5, 2015
												I've been hooked on this game since I was like 9, and I consistently have difficulties pressing the "exit" button and going back to my real life. Thankfully, the game crashes every few hours for no reason, so I've never had to worry too much about it.Still, I just gotta say, the Dark Brotherhood questline in Oblivion is ♥♥♥♥ing amazing compared to Skyrim's ♥♥♥♥ "kill these random dudes anyway you want" spiel. The quests, in general, try not to take themselves too seriously and I'm glad they don't lay it heavy on the Grit. As long as you're not too miffed about the really ♥♥♥♥ing ugly faces (see: Hackdirt Brethren) or some of the glitches, it's a pretty fun game and has high nostalgic value. OH, also, Shivering Isles is pretty interesting visually and story-wise, but some parts of it made me rather uncomfortable (ah... the ableism... like if you have any mental illnesses like me, you'll definitely go "Yikes!" a few times). Buy this when it's on sale because it's not worth its posted $20 for how old it is. Also, practice Safe Saving.

content:
ber 14, 2015
												I originally played this game on Xbox 360, where it quickly became my favourite video game of all time. I can only imagine the PC experience is much richer.Before discovering The Elder Scrolls, I had very limited experience of playing RPGs - the only ones I can remember playing were Pokémon and FInal Fantasy VIII. Both of which I enjoyed immensely, but I still stuck to action adventure games, strategy games and first person shooters.Then Oblivion came along and changed my life. I mean it - this game has affected the way I look at sunsets ever since. Some real sunsets I've seen have almost been as pretty as those in this game.Bethesda's mantra is "be who you want to be" and Oblivion allows you to do just that. The early moment in the game where the protagonist steps out of a linear, grey darkness and into a sumptuous open world of possibilities accurately reflects my own gaming life upon discovering this game.Unfortunately, as has happened with its predecessor Morrowind, Oblivion has become dated and now seems rather clunky and rough around the edges. It might be difficult for a player used to modern open world RPGs to step back and enjoy Oblivion in quite the same way I did. But damn, I just want everyone to feel the way I did when this game's world eclipsed my own.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
0, 2016
												I have really conflicted feelings about Oblivion, and most of my complaints lie where they do with other Elder Scrolls games. Let's be completely honest, the combat in these games aren't the highlight of the show, and Oblivion is far from an exception. What would be excusable for a combat system becomes laughably tedious as the game progresses since all enemies scale to your level. Levelling, as it stands, is incredibly tedious. Instead of an XP based level up system like traditional RPG's, Bethesda opted for a "skill-based" one. To level up, you must progress your seven major skills (which you can pick when you make your class). The only way to level these stats is to GRIND. and GRIND HARD. If you're not inclined to just cheat your stats with the console, you'll be stuck spamming custom made spells that use as little magicka as required to get any sort of real boost. The major problem of Oblivion is it's scarcity in good content. The sidequests are phenomenal, and some of the most interesting and creative you'll find in any video game. They range all the way from dinner party mysteries to vast journeys into unmarked areas. The main quest is, quite simply, boring as all hell. It starts reasonably decent, and the first Oblivion gate was a cool expirience. But once you have to go around Cyrodil, close one or two gates for EVERY CITY, then be the errand boy for the Emperor it gets tedious quickly. The "boss" encounters are underwhelming, characters like Mankar Cameron are just souped up wizards and Mehrunes Dagon is just a big demon guy walking in the background while you run through the streets.Many skills just seem completely useless as well. Acrobatics for example. Sure it's kind of fun bunny hopping around, but the dodge isn't that great and the mastery skill of jumping on water is practically useless. Mysticism, Alteration, and Illusion are practically worthless with the exception of a couple spells, like Paralysis in the Illusion family. The reason they are "empty skills" is because enchanting your armor will get you far better bonuses than the spells and allow you to alot your magick into vital things like Restoration. Athletics can be useful when it's mastered maybe, but running faster and regenerating fatigue quicker? Horrible. You don't really win at all with Oblivion in context to the combat. It's either a spongey mess of mouse clicking, an absolute cheesing with high level destruction or 100% chameleon/shield enchanted armor, or just a bore of sneaking around and getting an 8x bow attack.The absolutely fantastic and beautiful thing about Oblivion however is the immersion. Books laying around referencing ancient battles, Ayleid ruins hiding powerful Liches, or mini events like the Bloated Float Inn being pirated when you sleep onboard. The little tidbits of good content are paced out well to counter the absolute chore-ish nature of the rest of the game. The relief of finishing a long questline of fetch quests like the Knights of the Nine expansion is both satisfying and underwhelming at the same time, because once you realize you just went through the same copy-pasted caves and ruins just with some flavortext to keep you interested, the expirience sours. As with any Bethesda game, mods are almost essential to the expirience. It doesn't have to be 100 different loli-maid mods either, just the basic fixes or fanpatches and graphical improvements are fine enough to keep the expirience fresh. Overall, to somebody that has never played Oblivion or many other RPG's before, it's a fantastic game. You'll enjoy it for many hours over many characters. However for someone that has a lot of expirience with other RPG's with more polish, you'll find yourself disappointed by a lot of it's shortcomings.

												This and Age of Empires 2 were my two first and greatest loves. IMHO the game still holds up to this day, although I might be under the influence of nostalgia. The graphics are still good-looking, and at times even quite beautiful. Both expansions are worthwhile, with Shivering Isles being the greater of the two. There are a lot of interesting sidequests, dungeons, easter eggs. The guilds are fun, especially the Assassin one. The downsides may be centered around the main story, as well as dungeon conception. A lot of dungeons just look alike, and the Oblivion Gates quickly become tiresome to deal with. As for the story, it's not bad, but it's not very memorable either. I never really got attached to the main character, in fact I found some of the guild plotlines more compelling. However this might all come down to personnal preference.Still a great game to explore and enjoy, and I hope you do .

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
ry 23
												Don't let my hours on Steam fool you, I have played this game for thousands of hours on various platforms, (PS3, 360, PC). I started out on PS3 and I absolutely adored it, at the time it was revolutionary and amazing. I have 1,200 hours on just my first character on PS3, and that was without doing some questlines. The game features such amazing quests, characters, locations, roleplaying elements, dungeons, loot, guilds, etc. And it feels like a vibrant, breathing, real world. (Although a little bit on the derpy side.) No other game I have played have I felt like I can live inside of a city inside the game, (except maybe the Witcher 3, just because of the sheer size and realism of cities like Novigrad). This is my favorite Elder Scrolls game (although I still love all of them, Daggerfall is among one of my favorites as well as Morrowind), and one of my favorite games ever. The graphics are slightly dated but have a charm to them, the faces are ugly and the landscapes look a bit like a painting more than a game, but in my honest opinion the landscapes in this game hold up better than Skyrims. It looks gorgeous, (save for the characters and some dated textures). The humongous modding community Bethesda games is now known for started becoming huge with this game, there is an abundance of great mods. From new weapons, armor, quests, cities, and even entirely new guilds and dozens of hours long quests. The modding community isn't as big as it is for Skyrim, but it still has an overwhelming amount of mods. The dynamic AI is both amazing (at the time it came out), and absolutely hilarious. Every NPC in the game can have a conversation with every other NPC in the game, and this can result in some hilariously stupid conversations. Although it is funny and stupid and doesn't work how the Devs intended it, I still think it adds to the world. Hearing people have dynamic conversations as you walk through a city going on a quest or to the inn is very immsersive and adds so much more. The guilds and questlines in this game are insanely good. If you were impressed by Skyrim's guilds they don't hold anything on Oblivion's. I was frankly disappointed by Skyrim's guilds (and NPCs) compared to Oblivions. The Mage's Guild, Dark Brotherhood, and Thieve's Guild especially are really good. And Oblivion even has minor (guilds) you can join such as the Knights of the Thorn or the Order of The Virtuous Blood. Every thing I've mentioned so far you can avoid and not play, most people won't even come across all of the guilds in their first or second or even third playthrough, and they are all optional. Now then, onto the main quest. Oblivion (in my opinion) features the best Main Story besides Morrowind in the Elder Scrolls franchise. You are a prisoner (big surprise) and you are in the wrong cell at the wrong time and adventure ensues. That is all I will tell you, because I enjoyed Oblivion's main quest a lot and wish you to experience it on your own. This game's story progession works somewhat similar to Skyrim's. In terms of in Skyrim the Dragons don't show up until you do a certain quest and kill one, the same thing happens in Oblivion. When you destroy the first Oblivion gate, that is when they start showing up around the map. The great thing about Oblivion though is that you can easily avoid the main quest much more so than Skyrim's. In Oblivion you can leave the sewers and go anywhere and do anything you want without someone going, "You have to go here and do this!" Like Skyrim does, in Skyrim if you go to Whiterun you are basically thrusted to Dragonsreach to advance the plot, if you do the starter Civil War quest you are thrusted to Whiterun to do the main quest. Oblivion never does this to you, you hear about the events happening and it might remind you to do the main quest, but it never thrusts you to the main quest without your approval. Oblivion's expansions add a lot as well, Shivering Isles is known as one of the best expansion packs ever, and I can't deny that. Knights of the Nine is also really good. Now onto the gameplay, Oblivion features the standard mediocre combat with hits that feel like you're using a nerf sword, except for one exception. The magic in Oblivion is extremely fun and diverse, unlike Skyrim it doesn't take up a hand. You can be a battleaxe using, fireball casting, robe wearing assassin. You can also make your own spells in Oblivion, (after a certain Mages Guild quest). The character creation is what to expect from Elder Scrolls, various facial customization, (except beards. . . C'mon Bethesda really?) and all the races. And let's not forget what Skyrim left out, classes. There are preset classes and custom classes you yourself can make and name. They don't restrict what you can do or use. They just enhance your starting attributes and skills, and make certain attributes and skills easier to level up in. Overall Oblivion is an amazing RPG and an amazing game in general. I would recommend it to almost anyone.

content:
er 2, 2016
												Let me preface this by saying I LOVE Elderscrolls games. Love them. Strapped a bedpan to my bum and played this game and Skyrim for months. First thing I do in every game is to get a feel for max difficulty. This game on max difficulty is legit hard. However, the only way to play on max difficulty is to create what I call "The Pokemon Master" build. Physical damage you do is soooooo reduced. Literally <1 damage. So the only way to play is to conjure pokemon to fight for you. Their damage is not reduced. So you let the pokemon fight until it despawns, then throw out another one. Lather, rinse, repeat. It prevents a lot of fun and creativity in a class. Sometimes you can poison your weapons and take them down with bug bites. It is boring.However! This game is GLORIOUS! Graphics may suck, but you will not care. The story lines are what grip you. The combat on everything but max difficulty is fun. The world does feel alive in this game. There is enough to entertain you for hundreds of hours, and that is just on one character. This was the first game in the series that I played back on that old crap box 360. There is a redesign mod that does improve graphics and models by a ton. It's on Nexus Mods. Definitely check that out. All in all, a great game worthy of every penny. It's like dirt cheap now so there is no reason not the pick this one up.

er 19, 2016
												Best game I have played so far.. This game is set in a massive world called Cyrodiil where you can play through the main story line, roam around exploring the world and its hundreds hidden secrets and things to do, or basically anything else you can want to do. If you travel through an oblivion portal you are teleported to an insane world of demons or daedra that hunt you down as you wander through the hellish world traversing its caves deep withinside it or out on the surface trying to climb the top of the towers without getting killed to steal the sigil stone and close the portal. This game is amazing, there are almost infinite things to do, and hundreds, if not thousands of hours to spend in this world. I saw another review of this game that I want to quote "There are games you play, there are games you live in, and then there is Oblivion... Yes, its graphics might not be quite advanced as Skyrim, and maybe the combat isn't quite as good but it more than makes up for it with the entrinsic story line (Yes I know, i probably spelled that wrong), and the amazing sense of how small you truely are in this massive world. This is bethesda's masterpiece in my opinion and I think that If you have played a game like skyrim and loved it than this game will be just as good or better!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 2, 2016
												I originally played this game for over 200 hours when it first came out. This is truly one of my favorites of favorites the story and scenery are far more superior to Skyrim, but the graphics are a little dated but well enough (before modding) as well as the game engine a little buggy (I recommend the unofficial patch to fix). I went through another play through and modded it to look better and I can really say it looks better with mods almost as good as Skyrim after I was done with it. I’m also using Xpadder to map the keyboard keys to a XBOX one controller and I seem to be getting great results with it. I would say all and all this game is a great experience 10/10 for an open world RPG with no remorse starting out. you will get lost or try to wander at first, but try to stick to the main quest for a little bit till you get a little more powerful before wandering off.The thieves guild and dark brotherhood quest are some of the best game play in the series to date, and the add on DLCs are some of the best pieces of work I’ve seen take an already brilliant captivating game to a whole other level over and beyond  11/10 what it is and make it that much better. Note: If you played this on Xbox or PS3 Port, you my friend were bamboozled with sub-par graphics and lower res that’s just atrocious and downright unplayable. The PC copy (GOTY) edition with some mods (not to many) to make it look nicer, I’ll play it all day long and revisit time and time again.

content:
y 27, 2014
												This is my first outing into an RPG that isn't Final Fantasy, and... After going back after playing Skyrim... Meh. It's got it's merits, no doubt. Easiest way to review, would be a point system.Pros:1: Soooo much ♥♥♥♥ to do! I feel it's more than Skyrim, or maybe they're just more densely packed.2: Hard to reach areas. Wanna reach that corner of the map? OK, here's... no path at all! You'll just have to go off road and find your way there, which is actually pretty cool, it gives a much more RPG-ish feel (I made a word!) to travelling. Altmer ruins are a MAZE to get to the bottom of, and you better stock up on supplies, because they are very long in time, and very big, and lots of enemies.3: Travelling feels like an adventure. Unlike Skyrim, which is still good, I feel compelled to actually walk around and explore, despite the boring environment at times, because there is always some cave with your name on it, where as Skyrim just is a slog if you don't fast travel to the nearest location. Without mods in that, you'll get attacked by Dragons every 5 seconds. Where as here, you can stop to just chill for a bit, no enemies for miles.4: Guilds. Aside from the Thieve's Guild, which is really the Robin Hood Fan Club, you actually feel you belong. Dark Brotherhood feels evil, Mage's Guild feels intelligent, Fighter's Guild is Pretty much Knight's Club, Arena feels like Gladiator Fighting, so something for everyone.5: Add-ons. Shivering Isles, Knight's of the Nine, Mehrunes Razor, they're all good Add-ons. And when you've dried the game up, off to Nexusmods you go!Cons:1: Combat is a drag. Later on in the game, you'll be hacking away at an enemy for 10 minutes, and they still won't die, which is really, REALLY, annoying.2: Can't play mage. Wanna be a mage? Wanna go burn everyone with Fire? WELL TOUGH ♥♥♥♥. By the time you have the skills for those powerful spells, they won't be so powerful anymore, making sword and shield the only way to play, really.3: Ridiculous Main Quest. Don't even bother with the Main Quest, go do everything else though. So I gotta go find an old guy who knows where this son is, and doesn't bother saving him? WHAT THE HELL!? Then you go back. So you didn't put the amulet somewhere safe, you dingus?4: Limited NPC personality. "I saw a mudcrab the other day. Annoying creatures." Expect to hear that A LOT. From every NPC ever.5: Lots of awesome but useless items. So you spent ages gathering money for that awesome sword? Too bad it doesn't actually serve much purpose after 5 uses. You're better off enchanting your own stuff.So overall, if you're looking for a fun romp doing exploring, attacking, looting, or just being silly, I recommend this. If you're looking for an incredibly deep, interactive, and moving game, look elsewhere.

er 16, 2015
												I like all the Elder Scrolls games, but there is something special about Oblivion. Many say it's the weakest of the games, I don't agree. There's something to the warm, vibrant atmosphere and the lovable potato faces, the daily banter about mudcrabs and the guards yelling for the criminal scum to stop. It has to be experienced to be understood. Or maybe it's just nostalgia talking. Either way, I recommend this game.
